review: Sicario blew me away. Emily Blunt is engaging, the story is well-told, the cinematography is stunning, and the tension is relentless. It is 2015's perfect film--perfect pace, perfect length, brilliant climax and ending; a deft combination of the thrills of Homeland with the style of Zero Dark Thirty.

It is not very often you get a false film about soldiers that feels so real. "Sicario" is one of those films. The base story is a team of soldiers hunting down the drug cartel. There are more complexities that come from the lawyers and head hunters, but that is the least interesting portion of the story in my opinion. We follow Emily Blunt's character who is not used to this kind of field work, but the team she works for interested me much more. "Sicario" benefits from a very solid script, a tension-filled story, and terrific performances. I do think this film is slightly overrated, but it's concept is worth the price of admission alone. In the end, I really enjoyed watching this film. I did not buy into everything that happened, but in the end, it became one of the more interesting films of 2015.

Blunt plays a taking-no-shit government operative called on to assist an investigation to nail a drug lord. She our doppelganger, our stand-in, who ushers us in into the horror of real life, the horror that horror is necessary. Once we are assured of her street worthiness and credibility - and she's plenty badass - we are then introduced to the real star of the film and the subject of its focus. The movies and their audiences (hey, that's us!) love the Myth Of The Double O's: sauve, debonair, lady killers who can handle themselves in a fight, in a car chase, in other countries, in other languages, with any weapon. Center stage in every scene. "Bond. James Bond." But what might such individuals be like in the real world, not in the movies, but in the world we live in and know? When we meet Del Toro as the secret agent he is most noticeable for his deliberate efforts not to be noticed. "I'm just sitting here. I'm just a regular joe. I'm just like you. Don't look at me." By the film's end we know that this MF is the MF other MFs have nightmares about, and if you notice him, if he is center stage then its already too late for you. A really good film, and with my highest recommendation: worth more than one viewing.

Gritty script, dazzling direction and fortified performances; Sicario is an under-the-radar success that's ruthless as it is real. The film's captivating leads (Blunt, Del Toro) and stunning direction makes an outstanding case as one of the year's best. 4.5/5

I don't think I will remember this movie too well a year from today, but today I do like it. Emily Blunt puts on a very good performance and the story has a unique spin to it. The action sequences create a lot of tension and the directing is very good, I particularly liked the use of infrared and night vision in the final action sequence. Some bits of the movie are overplayed and unoriginal, like the annoyingly coy police character Brolin plays, but some people may like it. This isn't a unforgettable movie, but it is certainly a little better than an average action picture.

Sicario could possibly be one of those movies that require a second viewing, as the first viewing failed to hit the spot for me. On the surface Sicario ticks all the right boxes but ultimately fails before its begun.

This is hands down the best movie of 2015 to-date. You want to see this in a theater, so go see it now. But it is not for the faint-of-heart ... I'd give it a hard-R. But it is a gripping account of the drug war that is going on with the Mexican cartel(s) with great performances from A & B list actors/actresses. One word: Wow.
The tension and drama builds through almost the entire running time. I didn't feel the payoff was the best, but it sufficed.

Much like Soderbergh's Traffic, Villeneuve offers us this riveting and thought-provoking portrait of an endemic social malady against which every effort seems futile, and he invests in a constant sense of urgency and a nearly unbearable tension to place us inside that gritty reality.

The word "sicario" is Spanish for hitman, we're told in a helpful opening text. It's a term that has greater meaning in the landscape of the war on drugs, a war that has ravaged the Mexico and its citizens. Sicario, the film, is a grim and gripping and director Denis Villeneuve doesn't hold back from the brutality of its reality. Sicario is a flat-out tremendous film. It's the most intense film I've sat through since 2012's Zero Dark Thirty, so much so that for long stretches of the 121-minute film I was literally tearing my hair out with delicious anxiety.Kate Mercer (Emily Blunt) is a Phoenix FBI Agent called in by her superiors with a very special offer. Matt (Josh Brolin), a government agent whose affiliation is classified, has a task force that he would like Kate to join. She'll be taking it to the drug cartels by destabilizing their chain of power. Kate accepts the job. Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro) is a foreign agent in alliance with Matt, and he seems to be deeply knowledgeable of the cartel and their practices. As the chaos swirls and the team gets closer to the cartel bosses, Kate has to reckon with what she is part of. Let Sicario be a blueprint for how to brilliantly develop suspense sequences in mainstream cinema. I've written about it before but the key to suspense and horror is simply characters we care about and the worry of what will happen next. Sicario places our characters in the middle of an ongoing battle and serves them up as the change agent, the proverbial stick rattling the hornet's nest of deadly cartels. There's a wonderful sequence when Kate joins up with the team for her first mission. She's been told she'll be based in El Paso but in reality she and a team of Army Rangers are venturing across the Mexican border into Juarez. They're picking up a high-level cartel informant and transporting him back to American soil. The ride into the country sets the stage as the caravan of black SUVs tears through the streets of Jaurez, bracketed by Mexican state police vehicles. We've previously been told at what points a likely trap might be staged, and so we wait, taking in the terrain, the distance, the exits, the personnel. We're already sizing up the Mexican state police cars; is that one on the take? It's at the end that the scene coalesces into an even stronger whole, as we literally have a climax in traffic. The border entrance is backed up, and so Kate and our team wait, all the while identifying some suspicious armed men in traffic lanes parallel to their vehicles. They're told they cannot fire until deadly force is used, and so they wait and we wait. It's a top-notch sequence where you're nervously waiting for the boil, waiting for the explosion. Writer Taylor Sheridan (best known as Deputy Chief Hale on Sons of Anarchy) has taken what could have been an empty Michael Bay-styled drug war thriller and given it a soul. Sheridan's structure is ingeniously tied into his larger message about the moral futility of the escalating war on drugs. As Kate becomes more immersed into the costs of her new role, of the mounting ethical compromises and legal loopholes, she becomes a background player and Alejandro takes center stage. Rather than simply harden up and sacrifice her ideals for the sake of her mission, Kate holds true to her principles, even if she might be the only one continuing to stick to the rules and a need for oversight. It makes her a far more interesting character and it all comes to a terrific climactic scene that hinges upon two characters at a forceful crossroads, each with diametrically opposed viewpoints. For all the action, Sheridan has found a great way for his story to have a character-based climax that hits harder than simply killing the Worst Bad Guy. As we learn more about the reasons Kate was selected, her literal marginalization in the story makes thematic sense, especially as she's unwilling to become a "wolf" in a "game of wolves." Alejandro is that wolf, and in the last act he becomes the film's focus as the pieces of their destabilization plan fall into place. There's a scene with Alejandro that is so cold-blooded yet badass that it made my audience gasp. As the bodies drop and blood is shed, Sicario doesn't lose sight of its characters even to the very end.Sheridan's script tackles its subject with a propensity for acknowledging the messy reality. There are no easy solutions and perhaps the best solution is really one that is at odds with conventional legality. The United States is losing the war on drugs, and innocents are suffering in droves. Matt's cavalier attitude is in response to the overwhelming evidence that the war on drugs has done little except to enshrine certain violent elements into power. He's trying to clear a path for Alejandro, but for what aim afterward is ethically questionable. When you've got nothing but bad solutions, perhaps the best option is still one that's a step too far. Sicario tackles the harsh realities of the war on drugs without ever dragging out a soapbox. The messages and debates are suffused in every frame, every taut sequence, even pained expression. It's a message movie where the morality and the escalating action go hand-in-hand.With Prisoners and now Sicario, Villeneuve has proven to be one of our finest directors when it comes to making adult movies that get your palms sweaty. The execution of these suspense sequences left me breathless. Villeneuve uses long takes of aerial photography hovering over the topography of Mexico and the American southwest. It has the effect of feeling like you're surveying an alien planet. Added with the ominous score by Johann Johannsson (The Theory of Everything), the tension can feel overwhelming at times. The menacing and percussion-heavy score makes it feel like an army is approaching. The movie also looks absolutely beautiful thanks to the cinematography from Roger Deakens. There are several lovely shots lit with the dying rays of sunlight, which I would admire further if my heart weren't in my throat while watching. Villeneuve also knows when to pump the brakes, letting his film breathe, and letting his actors take center stage. There are several moments of restraint that allow the actors to flourish. From top to bottom, Sicario is a technical marvel that impresses as it continues to horrify. Blunt as a badass is nothing new after her killer turn in last year's epically underrated Edge of Tomorrow, but there's way more to her than being a superhero with a gun. She's the moral conscience of the movie and you may discover, as she does, how irrelevant such a stance may be in this underground world. She's trying to make sense of it all, trying to go along with what she thinks is right, or at least making a difference, and swallowing her frustrations. She saves the best for last in a finale scene that pushes her character to the breaking point of her ethics, and Blunt floors you. While Blunt is our entry point into this world, and Brolin is amusing as a cavalier rogue agent, this is very much Del Toro's movie. Alejandro could easily be the slick movie-cool hitman, a soulless killing-machine, but he's a haunted man who knows he's damned and goes about his business with steely resolve. Benicio Del Toro can often be confused for doing little acting because he so naturally underplays his characters, but keep watch and you'll see a man who inherently knows his character. There are subtle shifts and small reveals that open up his character, who is so hardened that this will be all you get. There have been some complaints citing the film's lack of perspective from the Mexican side of the border, which is fair but also overlooking Sicario's complexity. With its fear of cartel war violence spilling over into American neighborhoods, it's not hard to see this film becoming supposed evidence in a xenophobic political campaign. Surely Donald Trump will be talking about Sicario. There is a small degree of representation with a minor character involved in the drug trade. The movie flashes back to him and his family a few times, setting us up to expect he'll return at a pivotal moment later. He's a completely unremarkable character and the brief scenes we spend with him made me anxious to get back to Kate and the main story. I didn't care, and then he did reappear and I was quite surprised to find myself actively caring for this minor character's well being. In a scenario where it seems like there's a lack of vulnerability, this character provides it. He's not a bad person per se as just another cog in a corrupt machine trying to provide for his loved ones. It's a window into the larger ramifications of Kate and Matt's actions. The very last bittersweet image doesn't feel like victory, more like a warning of impending consequences that will befall innocents, and they aren't Americans.It's rare to get a Hollywood thriller that excels at what it does and exceeds lofty expectations, but Sicario is that movie. Here is a thriller that excites, unnerves, provokes thought as well as terrible anxiety that you sweat in buckets over. The general feeling while watching Sicario is one of disquieting dread. The challenging and disturbing reality of the war on drugs blends with the brilliantly executed suspense sequences. The characters don't get lost amidst the clatter of violence, the direction enhances the actors and allows them to better inhabit their engaging characters, and the overall orchestration of all the many moving parts is so polished, so in tune, so electric that Sicario often does more than just entertain, it forces you to react. Leaving my theater was akin to coming down off an adrenaline high and I wanted to tell everyone I knew to see this movie. That's the power of great cinema and Villeneuve has created a compelling feature that deserves to be soaked up and studied. This is exhilarating moviemaking, folks. Nate's Grade: A

SICARIO is a thrilling film that plays like a gradual punch of adrenaline; it places and lingers the tension for a gripping experience - courtesy of the original score's strong presence and top-notch directorial and cinematographic execution. Not for the faint-hearted, this film truly aims to make viewers feel the weight and is great in many ways once some glaring flaws are overlooked (including a script that by the end wasn't as expansive and fulfilling as initially indicated as well as some rushed but important moments of decision and protocol); it employs high stakes and tense scenes that effectively utilize the tools of cinema, and does so in a way that admirably and provocatively explores the conflict between morality and serviceability.

Sicario is a masterwork of filmmaking that gripped me in everything from the performances, direction, writing and action. Directeor Denis Villeneuve has proven himself once again to be one of the best filmmakers in the business, creating a gorgeous world that I completely immersed myself in. Its a very gritty and real film that looks absolutely beautiful in a way that you have to see to believe. Emily Blunt just keeps getting better and better, with her performance here standing out as possibly her best. Its a very emotional and dark role that she absolutely killed, showing new range in her talents. Josh Brolin has only convinced me of his acting abilities in the past, but it's always nice to see him give another great performance. He captures all the subtle characteristics about his character that make him unique, and we always get a feeling he is more than he appears. Benicio Del Toro is the man who steals the show here, giving his best performance in years. His dark, ghost-like performance is unnerving and took me completely by surprise. Unraveling the puzzle of this man was a beautiful little mystery and his performance, and character, were the best in the film. The writing was fantastic, giving us a great and layered story about the hunt for a cartel kingpin and the lengths these people will go to find him. It was a great way to present its themes of morality, control, fear and more. I will admit that sometimes the film could drag, but it was never boring. Sicario is an excellent film and one of the best of the year, delivering a brilliantly styled and intense thrillers mixed with a fantastic

MAY I BE BLUNT? - My Review of SICARIO (3 Stars)Denis Villeneuve has demonstrated an effectively slow-burning, formalist approach to filmmaking in such features as PRISONERS and ENEMY, allowing suspense to build and screws to turn slowly to ratchet up the maximum levels of tension. In many ways, his somewhat classical style reminds me of M. Night Shyamaylan's, only with better scripts. His latest, SICARIO, from a script by Taylor Sheridan, feels of a piece with his prior films, but with more kinetic sequences and a cipher of a lead character highly reminiscent of Jessica Chastain in ZERO DARK THIRTY. Emily Blunt plays Kate, an FBi agent who is enlisted by a mysterious group of men, led by Josh Brolin and Benecio Del Toro, to fight the drug cartels near the Texas/Mexico border. If you're thinking this sounds a whole lot like the short-lived series, THE BRIDGE, you're pretty close. Nothing is what it seems, loyalties seem to shift constantly, and the notion of good guys vs. bad guys goes out the window. Drawn into this plot with a murky plan, Blunt seems to be the driving force of the film, until it starts to dawn on you that as good as she is, there isn't much of a character here for her to play. We know she's divorced, smokes, is great with a gun, and experiences horniness as a weakness...and that's about it. What's missing is the shattering of her world view. Sure, she's world weary, but the rug gets pulled out from under her so frequently in this film, that I expected a shivering mess or a deep catatonic state by film's end. Instead, we're given as rich and emotional performance as is possible when dealing with such thin details. In all actuality, she's our window into this world, but the action is mostly driven by Del Toro's Alejandro. He's great in the role as a Hitman whose actions and motivations reveal layers to his character. He's a brutal man you come to truly understand, and he runs away with the film. Brolin gives a delightfully relaxed performance that lives somewhere in the Lebowski universe, surprising us with a memorably incongruent approach to what is usually a stern, stock character. In fact, there's so much that's great about this film, from the taut, tense opening raid to the night-vision voyage into a scary tunnel, which feels like a nod to ZERO DARK THIRTY's big set piece. Roger Deakins, who shot Villeneuve's PRISONERS, does another great job with this film. You feel as if you know these dusty, burned out landscapes and your stomach is in knots with each taut, stomach churning composition. J�hann J�hannsson's score also adds immeasurably to the tension, reminding us that his Oscar nomination for THE THEORY OF EVERYTHING was no fluke. Here is a composer completely in sync with a director, adding a feeling of dread to almost every scene. Despite surprising scenes, shocking turnarounds, and a fairly propulsive yet controlled style of storytelling, SICARIO comes up a little short for me. There's nothing here that we haven't seen in other drug trade expos�s such as TRAFFIC and MARIA FULL OF GRACE. Yes, we know there is no easy solution to the problem and that innocent victims are continuously caught in the crossfire. I applaud Villeneuve's commitment to his unique style, finding the breathing room he gives his scenes to be refreshing in this time of attention-deficit filmmaking. Had he insisted on spending a little more time and care with his leading female character, this could have been something even more emotionally devastating than what we're given.

Exceedingly bleak, brooding, violent and yet unapologetic, Sicario is a mature film conceived and executed by mature filmmakers. When tensions rise on the US-Mexico border, a task force is assembled, enlisting a passionate yet na�ve FBI agent (Emily Blunt) to aid in its efforts. The goals and actions of the task force represent a departure the young agent is not yet willing to make, yet feels inexplicably logical in an illogical world.With Sicario, talented director Denis Villeneuve takes on the drug war in really an unprecedented way. Its' political overtones, realism, and cynicism is reminiscent of the great Traffic, yet without the overwrought indignation. It's a slow burn, with a methodical build up and a matter-a-fact way of examining the brutality and carnage that cartels engage in, without glossing over government complicity. Vilenueve pulls no punches, and succeeds in making a film that is both enthralling and cerebral. It has a point of view, yet the viewer has to make their own interpretations. Shades of gray abound, a laudable departure from a genre that otherwise can succumb to less nuanced stories.The film's ensemble cast is second to none, featuring marvelous performances from all involved, including Emily Blunt, Josh Brolin, and Benicio Del Toro. Toro, for his part, showed a depth I haven't before seen from him. The chemistry between the cast is palpable and the direction brings the best out of the actors, whose complex characterizations all bring a much needed wrinkle to a the story.Toward the end, one would wish for more exploration of the film's major revelation, feeling a bit unsatisfying in the last act. Yet it still manages to bring something to the table that past genre pieces have not, a very real sense of hopelessness that, if never confronted, will never be defeated.4/5 Stars

Tense and important, Sicario is a film that is relevant to our times. It occasionally suffers from overwrought dialogue, but the tense atmosphere and performances, namely Benecio del Toro, make Sicario a riveting tale. Just don't look too into it as there isn't much under the hood. Rating: 73

First 'Prisoners' then 'Enemy' now this intense taunt thriller from Denis Villeneuve. Much like those two previous films, this film contains exquisite cinematography from the great Roger Deakins, along with outstanding performances from a great cast whilst attending to it's very thoughtful and intense story. I can't even go on to mention how much of a career high point this is for almost everyone involved. The characters played by Emily Blunt and Benicio del Toro are incredibly fascinating and compelling at the same time anyone in a minor role is memorable enough. With incredibly effective thrills, enduring tense character development added to that with such immersive substance, to go with how beautifully shot and neatly directed this film really is. Sicario is not a film not worth missing out on especially on the big screen, as is by far one of 2015's best, highly recommended.

Killing audiences like its Spanish namesake, tightly coiled thriller Sicario might be topical by proxy but boasts a white hot Who-Done-What at its red hot center. If Master of Suspense Alfred Hitchcock made a Mexican terrorism actioner, it would look a lot like this. Call it Crosstown Traffic, Steven Soderbergh's already timely drug drama made even timelier by an escalating narcotics war down south and framed with direction that's every bit as knowing and edgy. Though the set pieces stop your heart, your mind can't help but keep going at a feverish pace, always on the lookout for the next double cross or stray bullet. It constricts you from the get-go for a long con but Sicario's serpentine scheme never disappoints. In this R-rated thriller from director, an idealistic FBI agent (Blunt) gets enlisted by an elected government task force to aid in the escalating war against drugs along the U.S. and Mexico borders. Through the eyes of the sometimes naive but rarely helpless agent Kate (an ace and award-worthy performance by Emily Blunt), Taylor Sheridan's script pits filmgoers in the midst of a deadly war that oftentimes seems pointless but the drive of the characters keeps you fully bullet-proof vested. Josh Brolin and Benicio del Toro likewise give powerhouse performances, though the latter is inarguably the showier of the two. Denis Villenueve's taut atmospheric direction takes center stage, however. The Prisoners' helmer makes a Hitchcockian thriller without a Hitch. It's his own baby, killer turns and all. Bottom line: Wonder Drug

With the plethora of popular fiction devoted to the doomed drug war, it's slightly hard to get excited about a movie retreading the same ground as Traffic or similar films in this genre. But Sicario is, for a lack of a better way to express this, pretty fucking great. The plot centers on a female FBI agent specializing in special tactical breach and clear missions who finds herself recruited by a shadowy team of DEA agents planning to go on the offensive against Mexican drug cartels across the border in Juarez. Emily Blunt subtly and emotionally plays this protagonist as she finds herself in over her head and struggling to maintain her moral compass amid the carnage. Josh Brolin plays a slimy CIA agent so easily that perhaps we should worry about what he does with his time when he's not acting. But it is Benicio Del Toro who steals the show. His icy, murderous double assassin acts as a sword of vengeance and a warning about those who fight monsters. Notably there is a dichotomy between the FBI characters who attempt to operate in civilian legal procedure with arrests, investigations, and public transparency, and the DEA/CIA team who are heavily militarized, use direct force, torture liberally, manipulate the criminal underworld, and engage in Special Forces style assaults.Sicario is a notably beautiful looking film for being so riddled full of grotesque violence and it demands the viewer's attention. While others may find comparisons to Traffic, I personally feel it has more in common with Zero Dark Thirty, in terms of the strong female protagonist, the direction and cinematography, and final night vision fueled spec ops raids. Of course, where Zero Dark had an uplifting, bittersweet ending, Sicario makes a salient point about the failure and futility of the drug war. It's about as on the nose as you can get, but it doesn't prove to be a fatal artistic flaw. The cold, violent nature of this piece may deter some viewers, but the rest are in for a hellish but rewarding and entertaining journey into the heart of darkness.

Denis Villeneuve's powerful compelling dark drama about a naive FBI agent named Kate Macer, played brilliantly by Emily Blunt, in a physically demanding turn here that is filled with true grit, she is a real badass in the role. Kate is assigned to a special elite task force led by its leader Matt, played superbly by Josh Brolin, to help in the never ending bloody battles against the insidious Mexican drug cartels, she crosses into Mexico on a clandestine mission into a lawless border area where headless corpses of murdered victims dangle from highway overpasses, with her mysterious mostly silent team companion Alejandro, a special "consultant" with a tragic past, played terrifically by a scene-stealing Benicio Del Toro. Kate will find soon question everything she believes in and her faith will be tested as the operation continues, in a land where anyone is a potential target or perpetrator. To say anymore about this film is to betray its sense of paranoia. Astute direction by Villeneuve, with magnificent pulse-pounding action-set pieces that are brutally intense and memorable. A taut script by Taylor Sheridan, Roger Deakin's ravishing sun-parched cinematography is very impressive, and Johann Johannsson's grandiose haunting score is superb. "Sicario" which means "hitman" in Spanish is a most remarkable motion picture in every sense of the word. Highly Recommended.

Yep, I gave it a low rating. I hate drug cartel movies, but I watched this because everyone is obsessed with saying how great it is. Well, they are all wrong. I love these actors and yet not a single one of them did a damn thing to warrant all the critical acclaim that is surrounding this movie.
good movie . good story . good making & yes music is also appropriate
Definitely among top 3 of this year!

Beautiful photography, haunting score and good to very good performances, but Sicario is not what it thinks it is. For a film about violence, the way it handles violence is predictable even if it is at times shocking. What's worse is the way it handles the same old cliches and stereotypes we've come to expect with this genre. Ugh.
Unfortunately an actress as talented as Emily has not been involved in the right role in this movie.
Excellent film. Tense, interesting storyline, very well acted. Thoroughly recommend it.

Blunt is the pollyanna American who lives by the rule of law. Brolin is the world-wise version of America that fights dirty in the gray areas. The focus on Blunt's character losing her innocence as the wider world encroaches upon her is genius. Cannot believe it was not nominated for writing, directing, or acting, all of which were masterful. Not even Best Picture in a field of eight! One of the best I've seen in awhile.
With powerful performances all round and a thought provoking, hard-hitting script, Sicario is an absolute winner. Intense and gritty while blurring the lines of morality.
Hints at the complexity of the "war on drugs," although the story is at times oddly hard to follow. Great music.

Gripping, focused action scenes drive this thriller. Benecio Del Toro is the shape-shifting Mexican who is on a mission. He gets cooler--and better--the closer he gets to his prey. Emily Blunt is a SWAT team captain with a Jessica Chastain-like exterior--only better. Josh Brolin delivers some great lines as the sly, flip-flop wearing CIA agent in charge of the operation. This is a rough cut jewel of a movie, and a must-see if the genre appeals to you.
Very good movie that still leaves you wondering what exactly was going on

Sicario is phenomena! This movie will have you sitting on the edge of your seat. FBI Officer Macer (Emily Blunt) does an excellent job as the lead character and just when you think you know the plot - Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro) comes in and steals the plot. Excellent cinematography and views.
Spectacularly well-shot, well-acted, and socially relevant.

Sicario is a really beautifully crafted film. The characters are unique and flawed and the story is one worth experiencing. Word of warning: This is a pretty bleak and unforgiving view of the true ugliness of war. Don't expect any fuzzy feeling by the end.

This solid thriller about a CIA operation to track down a leader of a drug cartel is pretty great. It isn't a generic script, it has a fantastic cast, and some great direction. I much prefer a slow burn, low key action thriller like this than the average blockbuster shoot 'em up. Definitely one of the finer films of 2015...gripping and filled with energy and moments and imagery that will stick with you.
Really liked the ending.

Emily Blunt does a good job carrying this film, but like her character, I'm really confused as to what's going on most the time. Although the action is good, and there's some captivating tension, I don't think the film will leave a lasting imprint.
Well acted, well directed, good flick.
Nothing particularly interested me about this film. The characters, plot, setting, message. Not for me.
Thrilling and captivating.

Until I saw the credits roll, I had no idea that it was Roger Deakins who translated the whole film into one of the most stunning works of 'traditional' cinematography. Of course, Benecio's 'dispassionate quest for frontier justice' was a spectacle to watch.
Sicario may have a lot of downtime as it slowly unravels its plot, but it more than makes up for it with plenty of thrills, a fine ensemble, and excellent work from cinematographer Roger Deakins.

Great movie.. People who wants everything to go BOOM can see transformers or something michael bay else.. SICARIO is freaking awesome and chilling when you think about how far the government can go.. Benicio and Blunt, WOW! SEE SICARIO
Not for the faint of heart, Emily Blunt gives one of my favorite performances of the past year.
One of the best films I've ever seen; non-stop suspense!
Awesome. Tons of action. The final scene completely caught me off guard.

Denis Villeneuve's next HIT film after the success of Prisoners (2013). With veteran cinematographer Roger Deakins, he made something suspenseful.I like how this film brought a simple idea about the Mexican border drama into something scary and very satisfying thiller-drama.Emily Blunt was right for the cast - as a person that can be identified as us, who always tries to do something "by the book". Especially Benicio Del Toro, he made a comeback from playing some high-dude collector in Guardians of The Galaxy (2014). His mysterious character made the film looked more than a simple thriller. My dad, usually predicts what a character might do, but he couldn't predict him. Watch the climax of the film, you'll know what I'm talking about.Also the cinematography was great. The technical side of the film was very complex, but yet looked realistic. The old man really knew what he was doing since the 1980's.Besides that, I really like to hear the film's sound design and foely, it sounded so realistic. It build more of the suspense.As for the writings, there were plot twists all over the place, but the most surprising one was on the climax. We really don't know what Benicio Del Toro's and Josh Brolin's character motivation for 3/4 of the movie. Once we knew it, OH SHIT, this is fucked up.I bet this film would be in one of Oscar's nomination.The Verdict:Sicario is one of the most suspenseful film of the year, with strong cast, plot twists, and technical (cinematography and sound).

Loved this. Terrific confusion displayed by Emily Blunt trying to work out what the whole agenda is, with Josh Brolin and Benecio Del Toro very good at underlining the mystery, the traffic jam scene is great and reminiscent of the central bank robbery in Heat, but the final scene is shocking indeed. Brilliant stuff and the extraordinary score has rightly been nominated.
Bleak as hell, but very thought-provoking.
Best movie of the year, amazing sound and shot selections.

I really don't like high action movies with guns and crap but... I LOVED the way they did this, it was different, engaging, not too emotional. They shot this movie in the most... incredible way. Really loved it. Applause to the director.

How far we should go in prosecuting the drug war is the main concern of SICARIO, the latest directorial effort by Denis Villeneuve. The violence brought about by America's war on drugs is a sensitive one because of the complex motives and casualties on both sides. This film doesn't really offer any answers, but it does provide enough to mentally chew on as the morally gray areas inherent in such an effort are explored. The audience's surrogate is Kate (Emily Blunt), an FBI agent who volunteers for an inter-agency task force that takes her into the heart of Mexico with the goal of finding a top boss in the cartel. Along for the mission is a mysterious person, Alejandro (Benicio del Toro), whose allegiance and motives are unclear (at first). If there's one weakness in the film, it's Emily Blunt's character, unfortunately. While she and her FBI partner provide the bulk of the dramatic conflict, she never really develops satisfactorily, instead relegated to a mostly passive observer. Benicio del Toro's character is by far the most interesting and compelling, and he get most of the best moments and dialogue. From a technical standpoint, SICARIO compares well with Villeneuve's other work and features outstanding cinematography, courtesy of Roger Deakins (who also worked on PRISONERS). Slow and deliberate camerawork nicely complements the slow-burn pacing, which culminates in one of the tensest (and morally ambiguous) scenes in recent memory. If there's one thing that this film does extremely well, it shows that the drug war has far-reaching effects from the top of the food chain down to a cop who is just trying to provide for his family (even if it is on the wrong side of the law). I should also mention the excellent score by Johann Johannsson, although a key element of it is reminiscent of Hans Zimmer's style. If I had seen this last year, it most certainly would have made my top ten. As it stands, it further establishes Denis Villeneuve as a talent to be reckoned with and is suitably entertaining to boot.
The very violent film "Sicario" offers virtually no depth and is plainly outdone by the classic "Traffic" (also starring Del Toro) as well as the 2014 film Sabotage.

A troubling film, not because of the filmmaking, but because of its subject matter. The movie succeeds in realistically transporting you to the US-Mexico border and powerfully superimposing the attending moral dilemmas on your mind.

Intense the whole way through without any of the cheesy subplots or forced character developments you suffer through with other big name actors. Just a damn good movie. If you liked No Country For Old Men, this is a must see movie for you.

For me Sicario was the most unsettling film of the year. I found this much more disturbing and difficult than The Revenant, or even the documentary The Look of Silence.Although technically a fictional story, the film is laced with a gritty, docudrama aesthetic, albeit a beautifully photographed one, and is anchored in real world concerns that plague the various citizens and law enforcement agencies represented. I greatly admire this film. It's a work of art by a very talented group of artisans, it is well told and very intense. That being said, it's not a film I'll return to very often precisely because of how well it does its job. But I can certainly see why it has cracked so many critics year end top ten lists. Don't get me wrong, this is a great movie about a pressing topic that should be seen if you have any interest in films about the cartel, about the drug trade or about Americas various arms of law. All I'm saying is it's unpleasant to watch and to think about. It's very dark and ends quite cynically and as such I doubt I'll return to it often.

This is not a movie that I can pop in anytime and enjoy, but it is a well-crafted piece of cinema.
Horrible movie...Emily Blunt is one of the worst actresses ever....Wasted $6

The movie is slighly better than the standard Lionsgate mediocrity. However, Sicario still suffer from their usual system that builds a lot of anticipation, but short-shrifts with the payoff. It also is plagued by an ending that invalidates the initial setup, as do most LG films. Continuity is alien to them, unless a major studio is involved and driving the bus. Then LG films tend to be quite well done.

Emily Blunt's character was an absolute puss in this whole story. She was the only thing slowing it down. She basically cringes in every scene she's in and fails to do anything really meaningful except in her first scene with the group making a key kill. But she's relegated to the sidelines for almost the entire 3rd act. It became Benecio Del Toro's rendition of Taken for about half an hour, and then BAM here come's Emily again to whine about a guy killing someone's family when she's witnessed endless amounts of horrifying bloodshed for an hour and twenty minutes. She somehow went unhardened in that entire process. She never accepted reality and its horrors, and instead of joining in the fight she just got in its way.It's still a good film. It just could have been so much more. I don't blame Blunt by the way, she was a fine actress in the film. The writing is to be questioned when you put such heavy emphasis on a character without explaining her properly. From the get-go they obscure the reasons behind her hire, making her more of a plot device than an actual character I should care about. But still they push her forward and I DO care about her because Blunt did a great job of interpreting her internal struggle between ethics and reality. Yet they never cashed it in. She ends up being a character who constantly seems in too deep and incapable of handling things. It makes her appear weak and the ultimate message becomes unclear. Is the War on Drugs good? Bad? Are our politics with Mexico sound? Is this good for people or not?Those are profound questions this film had the potential to answer, and it simply passed on them all. With regards to cinematics, it's a beautiful movie that reminded me of Full Metal Jacket and Apocalypse Now, as well as flashbacks from The Hurt Locker. It's gorgeous. But unlike those movies, it doesn't take a definitive stance on what the story really means. I walked away more confused than enlightened and I believe where this could have been art it became shallow and obtuse past the mid-way point. While there are some highlights, the plot just leaves glaring holes filled at awkward times.Check it out, but don't wet the bed in excitement.

I want to divide this review into 5 parts: Directing, Cinematography,Writing,Score and finally Acting.Let's star with Directing - I thought that directing was phenomenal. It seemed that all of the main actors were on the same page as far as the movie should go. And portrayed their roles perfectly. All of the actors worked together like a well made Swiss watch. Denis Villenueve masterfully managed to capture the intensity and suspense of this mesmerizing thriller. The director cemented his name as one of the best if not the best thriller masters in Hollywood today. I would rate it 18/20Cinematography - Was really impressive, and manages to capture the audience from the first shot of the movie and never let go of the viewer. The lightning seems bleak, but that just adds to suspense of the movie. There were a lot of impressive shots, including the very well made aerial shots of the USA - Mexican border. I would rate it 17/20Writing - A movie is as good as it's script. Well in this case it's marvelous. The movie delivers everything it promises and more. It manages to deliver the thrills and sense of intensity from the start. All through out the movie, viewers are encouraged to question every single character, because the line of good and bad in this movie is very thin. 20/20Score - The composer Johann Johannson manages to do a very good job. Score is done to perfection. Every bit of sound seems to fit the frames perfectly and just helps to add the thrills. I would rate it 18/20Acting - A give a very big A plus for all the actors in this movie. Like i mentioned before, everyone fitter the role pretty much perfectly with good casting. All of the actors performed very well, so it is very difficult to mention some in particular. It seemed like every actor added something personal to the role, that made them very memorable. The chemistry between actors was something special, every relationship between characters was really intensifying, and mesmerizing. I would rate it 20/20Now for the MVP of the movie is: Jon Bernthal, who truly might have slipped under the radar. But his performance was both memorable and amazing. Even though he didn't have very much of a screen time, what he did with what he got, was really masterful. He deliver a bad cop, who does not give a bad impression and hides under a mask. His character is like a wolf, disguised himself as a sheep.In Total i would rate this movie - 95/100. One of the best thrillers ever made, and one of the best last years movies.

Something about this one bugged me enough to write a review. Maybe because it is overrated on this site and a couple others. It is not a masterpiece, it is a 3.5 star at best. It had a solid premise, twist, intense scenes, score, and decent into darkness. It also has a powerful message to send about escalation and drug enforcement policy. What went wrong? I think the film relied too heavily on shock and drama to obscure from its shortcomings. The plot moved at a snail's pace for 3/4 of the film where little was explained or happened. Besides that it has one major problem. The lead character was insufferable. She was annoying, clueless, afraid, and amateur, despite this being her profession. Her treatment was also abysmal. She was used, mislead, and bullied by her teammates; threatened into submission. There are deliberate undertones of misogyny, and promotion of violence. Expected considering the subject matter and audience, though are no less disturbing to experience. As for it's realism. Something funny to know is that the CIA, Mexican Government, and town of Ju�rez all called bullshit and denounced the film, even getting it ban in several places, since violent and cartel related crime statistics have been steadily dropping for years thanks to successful DEA, FBI, CIA, Mexican Army and police efforts to quell the cartels. In many respects what is portrayed in the film is still very "Hollywood".

Convoluted, confusing, and ultimately pointless. We never find out who Benicio's character is, or what motivates him to kill a (mostly) innocent cop. Basically the moral of the story is: you can't do anything about the status quo so you might as well perpetuate it. While that may be the current state of affairs in the 'war on drugs' today, it's hardly inspiring to make an entire film based on that premise. Really it all feels like a long slow build-up to nothing at all. It's ultimately anti-climactic and disappointing, and as the credits roll, one is left feeling distinctly underwhelmed. I understand how critics would enjoy such a gritty and depressing movie, but I do not understand the high audience rating. And to call it as a "thriller" is a stretch to say the least. Less than one eighth of the film could be characterized as "thrilling". That's tantamount to describing the latest "Die Hard" as a foreign film because it features 15 minutes of Russian dialogue. Highly not recommended.

Exceedingly bleak, brooding, violent and yet unapologetic, Sicario is a mature film conceived and executed by mature filmmakers. When tensions rise on the US-Mexico border, a task force is assembled, enlisting a passionate yet na�ve FBI agent (Emily Blunt) to aid in its efforts. The goals and actions of the task force represent a departure the young agent is not yet willing to make, yet feels inexplicably logical in an illogical world.With Sicario, talented director Denis Villeneuve takes on the drug war in really an unprecedented way. Its' political overtones, realism, and cynicism is reminiscent of the great Traffic, yet without the overwrought indignation. It's a slow burn, with a methodical build up and a matter-a-fact way of examining the brutality and carnage that cartels engage in, without glossing over government complicity. Vilenueve pulls no punches, and succeeds in making a film that is both enthralling and cerebral. It has a point of view, yet the viewer has to make their own interpretations. Shades of gray abound, a laudable departure from a genre that otherwise can succumb to less nuanced stories.The film's ensemble cast is second to none, featuring marvelous performances from all involved, including Emily Blunt, Josh Brolin, and Benicio Del Toro. Toro, for his part, showed a depth I haven't before seen from him. The chemistry between the cast is palpable and the direction brings the best out of the actors, whose complex characterizations all bring a much needed wrinkle to a the story.Toward the end, one would wish for more exploration of the film's major revelation, feeling a bit unsatisfying in the last act. Yet it still manages to bring something to the table that past genre pieces have not, a very real sense of hopelessness that, if never confronted, will never be defeated.4/5 Stars

For the last few months I have seen and heard a lot of hype surrounding this movie so when I saw this movie I was very excited to see it. After seeing the film it didn't disappoint. The film was gritty, it was dirty and it was tense.Firstly the movie is visually stunning, the cinematography is exceptional and Denis Villeneuve showcases his directorial talents once again after Prisoners and Enemy is showing he can consistently created well directed and captivating movies.The performances in the movie are also magnificent Emily Blunt delivers another terrific performance and is fast becoming the best actress within the action genre after her tremendous performance in Edge of Tomorrow. Her character is the person that we see the movie trough and is probably the only morally stable person in the whole film, and this gives her a feeling of vulnerability because although she can physically handle her self, unlike the other law enforcement officers she is too idealistic and doesn't always have what it takes to get the job done. But definitely the best performance and most intriguing character in the movie was Benicio Del Toro who gives a fabulous performance as Alejandro, he is a mysterious character who's motives are unclear until the end and you never really know who's side he is on. The only minor fault with this movie is that its story and at times very little interesting is happening. Without the tremendous performances and direction the film could have fallen flat on its face but they elevate it from just being another standard drug bust movie to one of the best films of 2015.

Deftly directed and superbly acted, Denis Villeneuve's "Sicario" takes an unflinching look at a brutal drug war. Emily Blunt's performance could be overlooked for its subtlety, but that's exactly what makes it powerful. In "Edge of Tomorrow," Blunt was an indomitable warrior; in "Sicario," she's Kate Macer, an FBI agent trying her best to be that warrior. Kate is steely and pragmatic, but thrust into a situation she has no control over, she's entirely vulnerable, and Blunt balances that resolve and helplessness brilliantly. Equally compelling, Benicio del Toro (the film's titular hitman) layers his ruthless mercenary with a rich complexity and humanity. His character, like others trapped in this morally grey world, cannot be readily defined as hero or villain; they are all victims of a corrupt and lawless system.

Sicario is a well acted and directed phycological, from Blunt's characters perspective, action film starring people like Emily Blunt and Benicio Del Toro.Showcasing the "war" in and around Mexico, with people willing to give up laws for the bigger picture.

Sicario is an intense, thrilling watch, the story slowly builds up the whole time until its final mind blowing release and you never know what to expect next. It's shocking, it doesn't have many plot twists but there are a few moments after which i stared at the screen with my mouth open totally not expecting what has happened. The directing and the cinematography are huge contributors to the movie's atmosphere, the cinematography is probably my favorite part about it. The colors, wide shots, i can't describe how pleasing was it to watch it. My main complaint about the movie is Blunt's character. It was a constant moral battle for me to watch her. Sometimes i loved her, sometimes her strong moral compass pissed me off and i wished she understood what's happening, and then i loved her again for being so opinionated. That's the beauty of it, seeing such complex characters on screen, never knowing whether to love them or be annoyed. The acting both on Blunt's and of course on del Toro's parts is amazing.The most important part though: this movie is scary. Seeing how much innocent people are affected by drug cartels running their towns and at the same time how used they are to it. Gun shots, missing people, dead family members are not treated as a tragedy anymore, it's a part of their daily life. And to think people still live like this in the world. It's terrifying.

Sicario is a unique experience that i couldn't recommend it more. It is a compelling movie.

Review: SicarioWell, it's here. Sicario was one of my most anticipated movies of the year, right up there with Spectre and Star Wars: The Force Awakens. Now that I've seen it, I wouldn't dare call Sicario a disappointment, but I wouldn't label it as my favorite of the year. After Denis Villeneuve's underseen gem Prisoners back in 2013, I eagerly awaited his next major film (he made the limited-release film, Enemy, between then and now-I've yet to see it). The two films share the similarities of being intense, suspenseful and bleak, but where Prisoners featured limited venues and focused more on characters' emotions, Sicario is a globe-trotting film (between the US and Canada anyway) that focuses on characters' actions.Emily Blunt stars as Kate Macer, a young cop who's work in leading teams that hunt down kidnappers and victims hasn't gone unnoticed by the higher-ups. She has a loyal partner in Reggie (Daniel Kaluuya who gets the task of playing possibly the only likeable male character in the movie, and he does a great job). After an investigation goes wrong and two cops from her team end up killed, Kate is eager to find the men responsible. She is afforded this opportunity when a mysterious task force of mixed agencies asks her to join them in taking on a Mexican drug cartel they tell her is linked to the kidnappings she is investigating. She doesn't hesitate to volunteer, leaving Reggie behind at first, but when she realizes she can't trust the strange new men she is working with, she insists on her partner's presence. She has every reason not to trust them. Matt Graver (Josh Brolin) won't reveal what agency he works for. And he's a bit on the quirky side-he wears flip-flops. And his partner Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro) is even more mysterious-he doesn't talk much and it feels unlikely to both Kate and the audience that he works for any reputable agency. It doesn't take long observing their unusual and violent tactics for the normally by-the-book Kate to wonder what she's gotten herself into. The team conjures up a dangerous plan to follow a Cartel higher-up to the leader of the whole thing so they can both be taken down, hopefully putting a big dent in the criminal activities. There is also a side story involving a crooked cop with a heart played by Maximiliano Hernandez. This story feels very tacked-on throughout the movie and it isn't until the very last scene that you finally realize the point to it-but it still feels somewhat unnecessary.Every actor in Sicario brings their A-game and does the best they can with what they've been given to work with. That's not to be overly mean to the script as it is an interesting story, but at times the dialogue seems very generic and some very important characters are often left with little to do. Blunt plays Kate much more feminine than her much tougher roles in Looper and Edge of Tomorrow would have you predicting, but she makes the character feel authentic and she carries the film well-that is until the filmmakers decide to lose her for some time to focus on Alejandro's agendas. This isn't easy on the audience because we're asked to accept him as a protagonist even though he is very violent and unlikeable. Del Toro plays the part well and practically owns the final act of the movie. It is clear Alejandro suffered some horrible tragedy in life-and I wish they would've included a flashback or two to some happier times for him so that we might find it easier to sympathise with him and understand his actions. Other good actors show up for small parts including Victor Garber as Kate's boss, Jon Bernthal as a character I won't reveal, and Jeffrey Donovan as a member of Matt's special task force.Behind the camera, master-cinematographer Roger Deakins works hard to make Sicario a unique visual experience. He's one of the best in the business (12 Academy Award nominations and still no win-Come on Oscar!) and proves himself once again here. Some of the natural skylines he captures are gorgeous and there is an amazing sequence where everything is seen through infrared and night-vision goggles-fans of the compound raid scene in Zero Dark Thirty will love this sequence. Editor Joe Walker makes sure the film doesn't drag too much. When things start to feel a bit slow, watch out-because something intense is about to happen. The score by Johann Johannsson is one of my favorites this year. Director Denis Villeneuve and writer Taylor Sheridan have made a film smart enough to please critics but mainstream enough to entertain audiences.Sicario is a film about moral flexibility. We, the audience, are forced to recognize that sometimes good people do evil things because they they believe it is for the greater good and sometime bad people do bad things to protect those closest to them. Other than some lazy dialogue here or there, Sicario's weakest attribute may be what feels like a lack of purpose. While it does open audiences' eyes to the war zone certain parts of Mexico have become do to these cartels, I couldn't help but feel like "That was good, but what was the point?" when the credits rolled. Still Sicario Is an intense thriller that deserves to be seen. 8/10?

During an FBI SWAT raid of suspected kidnappers in Chandler, Arizona, idealistic agent Kate Macer (Emily Blunt), her partner Reggie Wayne (Daniel Kaluuya), and their team discover dozens of corpses hidden within the walls of the house. While the team investigates the crime scene, an improvised explosive device in the backyard shed explodes, killing two officers. Afterwards, Kate's boss, Dave Jennings (Victor Garber), recommends her to Matt Graver (Josh Brolin), a CIA Special Activities Division undercover officer and Department of Defense adviser leading a team of Delta Force operators searching for the men responsible, including cartel hitman Manuel D�az. Kate volunteers to join the team. On the plane to El Paso, Texas, Kate meets Matt's partner, Alejandro Gillick (Benicio del Toro), and learns that they are going to Ju�rez, Mexico, where they will extradite one of Diaz's top men, his brother Guillermo...Denis Villeneuve is back with yet another fantastic film after "Prisoners" and "Enemy" and his "Sicario" is a tour-de-force thriller that pushes the boundary of where justice and morality are no longer valid. We are driven straight into the depths of criminality and it�s not always clear who is the good guys and who is the bad guys. It all comes down to reaching results and not how you reach them. Blunt, Brolin and del Toro are simply magnificent and in the hands of Villeneuve and cinematographer Roger Deakins we are served an amazing dynamic piece of film that keeps your blood rushing for 121 minutes. The tension is high throughout the film even in more slowpaced scenes and as in "Enemy" Villeneuve works with industrial muffled weird sounds in the background that creates a dark and disturbing vibe that fits the film. Villeneuve shows a situation that is beyond salvation, while showing at the same time that life nevertheless continues no matter what happens in the shady parts of the world. The action is truly believable and you end up together with Blunt and Co while they are trying to understand the events that occur. The role of the observing Macer is by far one of Emily Blunt�s best performances to date. I love as well that Villeneuve isn�t afraid of keeping a distance to his actors and the dialogue like in one scene between Macer and Graver where the camera is several feet away. Great scene. Dan Jolin from Empire gave the film 5 stars, calling it "a beautifully murky, hard-edged thriller. Quite simply, one of the best films of the year." And I can�t agree more. Trivia: While Benicio Del Toro's character is frequently silent in the movie, he initially had more lines. "In the original script, the character explained his background several times to Kate," Del Toro says. "And that gave me information about who this guy was, but it felt a little stiff to have someone you just met 15 minutes ago suddenly telling you what happened to him and who he is." Working with director Denis Villeneuve, Del Toro began cutting some of his dialogue to preserve the mystery of who his character is; Villeneuve estimates they cut 90 percent of what Del Toro was originally intended to say by screenwriter Taylor Sheridan. Like Del Toro, Villeneuve saw power in stripping the character down to a brooding silence, stating that dialogue belongs to plays and "movies are about movement, character, and presence, and Benicio had all that."

Finally a film this year that was brilliant. The film opens with a gruesome scene, then swat team member Emily Blunt agrees to work for a secret unit headed by Josh Brolin. Tackling the cartel directly in Mexico. Along the way she meets mysterious quiet but menacing Benicio Del Toro and the fun really starts. The is a highly tense ride into a dark world. Excellent thumping soundtrack that adds to the tension. Brilliant cinematography and high/long shots of the vast Mexican land scape. All actors are brilliant especially Del Toro who conveys both the sadness and ruthless drive of his character. Blunt is also brilliant but somewhat frustrating as she try's to play by the book in a world where half measures aren't allowed. Some surprises, plenty of violence and tension, great acting, twists and turns, shocking scenes. Great soundtrack and shot perfectly.

Simply put this film is a case of actions speak louder than words. Everyone here is excellent and in top form, from the actors, who do so much with the little dialog available (Benicio del Toro uses facial expressions like a master painter wields a paint brush, Emily Blunt is haunting and powerful), the directing, the score, the cinematography, everything comes together here to give a gritty reality to a dangerous part of our world. The action is exciting, but reserved, and absolutely thrilling. I understand why it's been placed on so many top 10 lists. I think it's biggest flaw is pacing. There were enough lulls in the narrative that I found myself getting distracted. That's probably more of a critique on myself than anything, but since I'm reviewing what I thought, I think 4 stars out of 5 is about right.

Sicario is a thought-provoking film which examines the dark realities of the US-Mexico border and the on going drug wars in Juarez Mexico. Juarez which was once known as the murder capital of the world makes for a grim setting where US CIA operatives launch a secret dirty war against a Mexican drug lord and his cartel. The film is well crafted and at times, feels so real that it creates a certain sense of paranoia. It's without a doubt an important contribution to cinema but it's harsh realities may leave one feeling depressed long after the movie is over.

Not good.If you want an example of how Hollywood farts out movies and then accurately markets them watch Scicario. The first 25 - 30 minutes of the movie is traveling and BRoll shots, just the three of them riding in the SUV's to Mexico and then driving around in Mexico. Must be nice to get paid $10 million to ride around in a car for a third of the movie. Emily Blunt, Josh Brolin, and Benecio Del Toro must have delivered at most 100 - 200 lines of dialogue between the three of them, and to add insult to injury, the movie isn't mixed properly so you can't hear/understand anything they are saying without headphones on. The whole thing just seems like a mash up of scenes where they just wanted to try to do cool shit that has nothing to do with anything, or is going anywhere or adds any direction to the movie. A majority of the scenes were of the actors contemplating, or preparing for a raid, walking around, or traveling in cars.I'm a stickler for knowing what the names of the characters are, I couldn't tell you one.You only need to watch the last 30min of it because that is the only period where it gets suspenseful and interesting, but I couldn't tell you how it ties into the rest of the movie because all the scenes preceding it are self contained and drive the story no where.I'm not sure how this movie has an 87% from the audience or a 93% from the top critics, but that is just a testament to how Hollywood can cut a cool trailer and can sucker people into going to see something that has no substance or story.

An excellent movie that obviously benefits from some fantastic performances from Benicio Del Toro, realistically, this might be one of his best and Emily Blunt. Though, honestly, I will say that this is the type of movie that doesn't really reveal all its cards until the last act. That makes watching the film, not necessarily difficult, require a little more patience from some of those in the audience. This approach, however, I think really adds to the movie, because you're just as much in the dark Emily Blunt's character is. You learn things as she learns them and not a moment before. The character work in the film is top-notch as Kate, Blunt's character, is doing her damnedest to try to do things by the book as everyone around her goes about doing things the way they want to and the way that would get the desired result, which is to bring Alarcon down. Kate, and Alejandro points this out in the ending of the film, is trying to traverse a world of wolves without the necessary skill set to do so. Not to say that she is a sheep among the wolves, but she is far too idealistic for the type of tasks that the people she's working with are doing. In fact, realistically speaking, Kate is essentially useless to the task these agents are trying to accomplish. I don't mean ineffectual, like Kurt Russell's character in Big Trouble in Little China, I just mean that her contributions, as sound and as smart as they may be, will never be considered by the team, because she is there simply so they can carry out their operation, nothing more. And I think that's one of the things this film does so well. It gives you this character, that's supposed to be the moral compass of the film, the only person who, seemingly, wants to do things the way they should be done and she, even with all her efforts, is unable to change the way things were done. It wasn't a lack of trying, it was willful ignorance from those who are higher up above her. She, to them, is just a small pawn in a clearly larger game. So I thought that was a a really interesting choice to take the character and one that, again, adds to the movie tremendously. As mentioned, the acting is pretty fantastic. Benicio Del Toro is quietly menacing in this film. He doesn't have to show a lot of emotion or communicate a lot, but you know that this man has seem some shit and would probably kill his own mother if he felt that she was getting in the way of his progress. It's also interesting seeing his character arc and witnessing how he ends up in the movie and what really was haunting this man for all this time. As mentioned, Emily Blunt is also excellent as well, and her character, from a narrative standpoint, is probably the most interesting in the film as she slowly realizes what she actually adds to this mission. So, yes, this is an excellent film, but one that's just not gonna show all its cards right off the bat. That makes it more rewarding to watch as a viewer. I'd highly recommend this, might be one of my favorites of last year.

Seeping with existential dread, you cannot help but grip the sides of your seat as the story unfolds. I feel like there are times where first time screenwriter Taylor Sheridan falters, such as the scene about an hour in where we first get to engage with the character of Kate Macy as she walks into a bar. After watching the film for an hour and having it make no attempts to get me to connect to this character, rather simply using her as a vessel for the audience (which I'm fine with) when she finally does walk into a bar and show her human side it completely jarred with what I was expecting to happen. Nevertheless, this sequence is used to propel the plot forwards at the same time and so this complaint quickly disappeared as I was watching. What the film gives us is a timely message about large, faceless branches of government doing what they want and answering to nobody, told through the eyes of a few key characters that it switches between at certain points. Typically beautiful visuals from Deakins, characters are created through the performances (del Toro being very good at this) rather than expository dialogue, haunting score, and a screenplay that accomplishes what it wants with very little dead weight.

Denis Villeneuve's powerful compelling dark drama about a naive FBI agent named Kate Macer, played brilliantly by Emily Blunt, in a physically demanding turn here that is filled with true grit, she is a real badass in the role. Kate is assigned to a special elite task force led by its leader Matt, played superbly by Josh Brolin, to help in the never ending bloody battles against the insidious Mexican drug cartels, she crosses into Mexico on a clandestine mission into a lawless border area where headless corpses of murdered victims dangle from highway overpasses, with her mysterious mostly silent team companion Alejandro, a special "consultant" with a tragic past, played terrifically by a scene-stealing Benicio Del Toro. Kate will find soon question everything she believes in and her faith will be tested as the operation continues, in a land where anyone is a potential target or perpetrator. To say anymore about this film is to betray its sense of paranoia. Astute direction by Villeneuve, with magnificent pulse-pounding action-set pieces that are brutally intense and memorable. A taut script by Taylor Sheridan, Roger Deakin's ravishing sun-parched cinematography is very impressive, and Johann Johannsson's grandiose haunting score is superb. "Sicario" which means "hitman" in Spanish is a most remarkable motion picture in every sense of the word. Highly Recommended.

Almost a perfect film. The only thing that really irked me was how heavy-handed it was at times, really taking away from just witnessing the experience. Otherwise, a nigh perfect film. The action sequences are very visceral and tightly filmed, but the main draw is the relationship between Blunt and Del Toro. Really well done. Villeneuve is one of the best directors of today and has a very clear stamp on how he does movies. There was one scene in particular where the soldiers are going into an underground tunnel and their bodies are silhouetted against a red desert sky and the pitch-black earth. As they move forward, the camera is still and the silhouetted bodies seemingly disappear into the earth, seemingly swallowed into the depths of hell as it were. It was a stunning scene.

Sicario is a bit two-dimensional in its effort to pull this "We're just as bad as the bad guys" motif out of its hat. The two-dimensionality trickles down to the characters who mostly just feel like cliches, which is a shame, and the remarkable cast does the best they can which, coupled with the outstanding cinematography and Denis Villeneuve's deft hand make it a compelling film. It mostly plays like a lesser Hurt Locker/Zero Dark Thirty and a less shaky Paul Greengrass film, and Villeneuve knows when and how to perfectly ratchet up the suspense on the film's explosions of violence. Benecio Del Toro has shades of Javier Bardem's character in No Country for Old Men but is somehow more terrifying, even given his hokey, flimsy backstory that feels like it never evolved after the script's first draft. The script is the main issue here. The subject matter is fascinating, and I just can't help feeling that this could have been an outstanding film were the characters given the requisite amount of depth to make you care what happens to them and the script stripped of the action/revenge/vigilante tropes that cheapens the film.
