There is a real coldness so far in Denis Villeneuve's films (almost Kubrick-esque), and Sicario keeps the trend alive. That coldness has kept me removed and from getting into his characters. Emily Blunt gives another strong performance.

Pretty intense movie, but someone needs to develop a microphone that amplifies Benicio Del Toro's voice just a bit more than everyone around him. I mean, I don't like raising my voice either, but damn man. Project a little.

I really liked this movie. I went in kowing virtually nothing about it and immediately got hooked on del Toro's character.The movie had a realism and a believable bent. Over the top??? I don't know. Our law enforcement has been trending that way.
Best movie i have seen in awhile. Very real.
Cinematography was really good. Slow moving story but lots of surprises lay around each corner of this "by any means necessary," get the bad guy.

Emily Blunt and Benicio Del Toro lead an excellent cast and crew in Sicario, a thriller depicting the State's war on drugs and the grey matter between the truth and whats written in the final report. Blunt in particular is amazing, and her excellence is even more critical in a film that doesn't provide a whole ton of dialogue.The film actually doesn't feature a ton of action. But its combination of music, photography, and prolonged set-up scenes build up incredible suspense. I was never bored.With an intelligent plot, a dark but emotional theme, and a striking ending, Sicario is the best film of 2015.
Great movie, bit gorey, but if you are interested in Mexican cartels and were a breaking bad fan this is worth seeing.

I had high hopes for this film which is winning awards and getting someOscar buzz. The cast is amazing and the storyline is very interesting.However, there are some very gross flaws in the direction andcharacters in the film that caused me to give it a 7 (maybe even a 6)out of 10. The handful of great moments of intensity make it worth a 7,but this is not a best picture nominee. Without giving away anyspoilers, I can say the following:THE BAD: * Emily Blunt character does (or fails to do) what you expect she would. She fails to ask questions or show some basic skills you would expect for someone in her position.* She is not believable in her professional or personal behavior. Wedon't really get her. Yes, she's conflicted, but there are 4-5 timeswhere it makes no sense. * The story gets confusing and convoluted. Who are they going after and how and why and how does it all work out.Beyond implausible, it's like they edited 50% of the film away and leftus with some gaping holes. * Governmental agencies are jumbled and confusing to an absurd level. * A few action scenes are absurd. * Random locations with random people where you do not know who they are nor why they are there.What I love about feature films in theaters is the level of realism,acting and storytelling is generally FAR superior to any TV show ormovie. In this case, the director handles the character development andaction scenes more like a TV movie. The cave scene being the mostabsurd and the main character (Emily Blunt) feeling like a poorlywritten TV character. Benicio and Josh Brolin have their moments of greatness, but theircharacters are too gruff to care much about them. There isanother storyline about a Mexican police officer that is also poorlydeveloped. THE GOOD: You will feel like you understand the complexity of theMexico-US drug crisis. For those who feel doing illegal drugs does notharm anyone, this movie will give you a clear picture of the dangers tosociety and the corruption that exists along the border. Clearly, wehave major issues that must be addressed.
a normal nice Action/ Adventure movie

Utter tension the entire running time. Gorgeous photography. Killer action sequences and that feeling you're there! Stellar performances, outstanding directing kept you intrigued as the little crumbs of info reveal themselves slowly to a gran finale.Best movie I've watched in 2 years.

I think this movie would be rated higher upon a second viewing. The movie explores the drug trade, and the war on drugs between Mexico and US. It explore many different moral themes from different angles.It's the movie that leaves you asking quesitons, and really wondering about things after the movie is over. I think it's those kind of movies that are the real good ones. The narrative is somewhat complicated but not too difficult to follow.The acting is of the highest order here. Emily Blunt is fantastic and you truly believe her performance. She is asked to join a task force to try and take down the highest members of a Mexican Cartel. Yet she is uneasy at what her role truly is.Josh Brolin is the leader of the team..a brash, cocky veteran of the biz who uses whatever tactics necessary.The star to me was del Toro...when on screen he has a sense of mystery around him. He is steady, no nonsense, and really hardcore. He obviously has a difficult past and has bee morphed into a different kind of past. His role is also unknown throughout the movie as we learn more as it goes.The movie really asks questions about how the drug trade operates, the true purpose of the United States, and how corrupt things can be to maintain order.It's an eye opening film featuring 3 fantastic performances. There are scenes or extreme realism that is fueled by fantastic direction. The movie isn't really concerned with being an action piece, more of an eye opening piece.
Very suspenseful, Benicio del Toro extremely authentic in his role as a Cartel hitman. Very creative story line keeps you on the edge of your seat.
Incredibly dark, violent and sharp-edged thriller. Highly recommended.
its a pretty good movie

This was quite the serious drama. Excellent performances by the three main leads, especially Benicio Del Toro. The usual slow bits you find in just about every drama, but that was to be expected. It also gets pretty dark as well, but considering the subject matter here that was also no surprise. Not bad.

Great action thriller. Surprisingly nuanced with different strong willed characters at odds, but no one side presented as definitively correct. Emily Blunt's character could have been unlikable, or worse someone the audience is required to side with, instead she ends up as something like the Starks in Game of Thrones. Someone who's too forthright and honest to fully comprehend a world without rules. I love how even some of the smaller bad guys are not even shown as conflicted and human instead of monstrous. But what I like best of all is the presentation of a wider conflict as many of the characters and groups peripheral to the main characters have lives and wits of their own and do not exist solely for the main characters to show up. It reminds me of Heat in a great many ways, and is one of the only movies I could call a worthy successor to that (which is my favorite crime film).
Beasts are born from beasts and that's who one needs to be to take on other beasts....at least that's what I got from the film
Just finished watching it. One of the best drug movies since Traffic. Bencio Del Toro did a hell of a job acting in this one...5 stars all the way.
Extremely tense thriller that at times isn't very confusing, Sicario does give a very very satisfying conclusion that'll keep your head spinning for days.

Sicario is one of the gems of 2015 that many people didn't see coming. The slow burning feel to the movie and the crisp look made it engaging. Every character was perfectly written and you could really feel the pain Emily Blunt was going through. The scene before they go into the drug tunnels was probably one of the most well shot sequences I've ever seen. Denis Villeneuve and the cinematographer did a glorious job.

Soo many good rating. So I watched it. Sadly I was expecting something else. Don't get me wrong, the movie is amazing, especially the beginning. But sometimes boring, and I would like to see the main character having a better place in the scenario...
Acting was good, movie started good, ending sucked.

The following review was created using notes I took after watching the film several months back. A bleak, pitch dark, hopeless, disturbing, and violent movie. Filled with an unrelenting tension and suspense (It's a film that turns rolling down your car window into a tension filled event). It's almost a dark horror film. It exists in a grey area. Nobody is good (Except for Emily Blunt and Daniel Kaluuya, who plays her buddy), but nobody is really bad either. Most are just grey, or bordering on bad. It's expertly shot, with cinematography by Roger Deacons. It deserves an Oscar nod/win for that alone. Emily Blunt has a flawless American accent and is beautiful in a normal, everyday way. She is our eyes into the film and she acts as our moral compass. Benicio Del Toro is what I like to call The Dark Angel of the film. Both he and Blunt deserve Oscar nods, him especially. He's a mysterious but very likable character and it is Blunt and him that are our main characters. Daniel Kaluuya is also fantastic. The opening scene is one of the best scenes in film this year. It's fantastic and gripping. Sicario is certainly a tough watch, and it's almost a downer of a film (Really, not a happy film....but what were you expecting?) but I applaud it for handling it's subject matter in an adult, mature way.
The early gripping sequences and suspenseful cinematography are simultaneously traumatic and the dramatic, but Sicario is ultimately a brutal movie with little else to offer than brutality.
Josh Brolin and Benicio Del Toro stole the show in this amazing thriller.
Good flick, not great, could've been with more action, recommended
C'est fort ,tr�s fort , excellent film
Great acting, Great plot, Great film.
A movie that is both compelling and presents a harsh reality. Blunt once again shows she's capable of any role thrown her way.
On the edge of the seat thriller. Beautifully shot & directed.
One movie as good as Elite Squad. Recommend watching it.
builds tension that goes to some dark places, Del toro's character is terrifying with some great supporting actors, one of the darkest, hard hitting drug war films ive seen in a long time.

Finally got around to seeing this one and I was not disappointed. Solid performances around although a bit hollow in the long run. Suspenseful and gritty Sicario delivers where it matters the most with tension building throughout.

Ripped right out of today's headlines, this is the very gritty story of an idealistic FBI agent played by Emily Blunt who must learn from and trust Josh Brolin and Bernico Del Toro. Josh, maybe...Bernico, no way! This is the story of the drug wars on the U.S-Mexico border. The only thing missing is Donald Trump building a wall.

I am honestly struggling to see why this film is quite so critically acclaimed? It is painfully predictable at the best of times, seriously, the underlying 'twist' was about as transparent as transparent can be. Emily Blunt also appears to be in my opinion a completely superfluous character. Considering she is supposedly the lead role in the film. It is really quite difficult to see the point in her actually being present most of the time as all she seems to do is cry, a lot. From what i can work out she is only there to constantly remind us that what is going on is most defiantly bad. Seriously. And as for thrilling, it's a joke. I can honestly say there wasn't a single moment I was even close to the edge of my seat, quite the opposite in fact, at one point struggled to actually stay conscious. This may be due to the poor character development throughout the entire film all of whom have the most minimal backstories I have come across in recent memory. Meaning I felt literally nothing for them throughout and frankly could not give a toss what happened to them or not. The only character I felt any sort of connection with was the father, who, of course, predictably died. I would say this is a spoiler but the entire movie is so transparent I don't feel this would be justified.The only saving grace is the excellent work done from the films camera crew which helps, as at least it gives stunning scenery shots to distract from the rest of the content.Thoroughly disappointed. There is a absolute wealth of great quality films out at the moment. The Martian, The Revenant, The Big Short to name but a few. Go and watch one of those instead and don't bother with this!
Great performances but a bit over the top in the Mexico parts. Overall felt flat to me.
Good movie despite Emily Blunt's character making no sense.

Subtle, great acting, and a killer opening. The movie drags a tad and never reaches the height of its opener, but it's entertaining. The movie essentially lies to you the same way Kate is being lied to. It's not really about the drug cartels as it is about finding out the angle(s) of those pursuing them.!

I'd say this movie is more style over substance, but damn if that style isn't amazing. Denis Villeneuve and Roger Deakins killed the look of this movie. I was a huge fan of Prisoners and looked forward to another great slow burn from this duo. It did not disappoint with its grittiness and realistic take on the War on Drugs. The shots of Juarez, the open skies and other scenery were breathtaking. The tension was built up excellently and there were many suspenseful moments, particularly that traffic scene. The action was handled really well in between the slower parts of the movie. The acting was all around great, but the character development was lacking. Benicio Del Toro easily stole this movie and was the most interesting character by far. Emily Blunt did a good job but I wasn't a fan of her character. She didn't really develop much and was kind of bland. Josh Brolin did a great job of playing a confident, gum-chewing asshole. This is where this movie fell pretty short of Prisoners for me. I was so invested in multiple characters in that movie and in its story. The story in this film is rather passable. Not bad, but nothing special or that memorable. It was a good look at the debatably immoral, but necessary means needed to fight the War on Drugs and the impact it has on the inhabitants in Mexico. The last scene of the movie really stood out to me and made me feel such sadness for the Mexicans living among such violence. This movie has its powerful moments here and there, but the story and characters could have been a lot stronger. Still worth a watch though, because it looks absolutely incredible.
I must admit I was impressed by Blunt's acting. Benicio is haunting too.
Intense and very scary. I'd clear out a whole Costco of adult diapers if I had to do what these guys and gals do in this movie.
Pace was a little too slow for me, fell asleep during part of the first half of the movie. It got better but wasn't blown away by it.
Well directed and shot with tough subject matter and great performances.

I was hoping for more from this movie. It has a No Country for Old Men feel, but there are is not real driving force in this movie. It feels like you are just watching a very good documentary reenactment. This was great cast, but the material is just weak.

It is not very often you get a false film about soldiers that feels so real. "Sicario" is one of those films. The base story is a team of soldiers hunting down the drug cartel. There are more complexities that come from the lawyers and head hunters, but that is the least interesting portion of the story in my opinion. We follow Emily Blunt's character who is not used to this kind of field work, but the team she works for interested me much more. "Sicario" benefits from a very solid script, a tension-filled story, and terrific performances. I do think this film is slightly overrated, but it's concept is worth the price of admission alone. In the end, I really enjoyed watching this film. I did not buy into everything that happened, but in the end, it became one of the more interesting films of 2015.

There are parts that are very disturbing and the film delves into the human core at what drives us and are we really making a difference in the world.

Despite being filmed in a "serious" documentary style, there's a lot of silliness so it's actually a really well executed revenge film that Arnie/Willis or any of the expendables would star in back in the day. Raw, intense, and violent. To those who have no idea how the war with the Mexican cartels are, this movie is as close as it gets. I'm an avid reader on the topic of Mexican cartels/war on drugs, and I can say in reality it's way more violent than you could possibly imagine.

Things I liked: Really good cinematography. Awesome shots of Juarez and the sky near the border. Sick music that matches the suspense.Things I didn't like:#spoileralertEmily Blunt didn't really have much of a role. Her job was: Being attacked by a corrupt cop, smoking lots of cigarettes, trying to figure out what's going on.Josh Brolin's character trying way too hard to be a cool guy. Why not simply tell Emily wtf is going on, rather than speaking in euphemisms.Benicio Del Toro turns into Rambo towards the end of the movieSome clear plot holes:1) What would Alejandro have done had the cop car not been there?2) Why did they need to care about the tunnel at all? They already had a drone on the Mercedes, so why not follow it all the way to the drug lords home?3) The drug lord wasn't hiding. He was out in the open, in a huge mansion. This would make him pretty easy to find in the real world!4) Why did they have to go in and out via Chevys? Why not fly in and out of Juarez with Guillermo?

"Sicario" only proves that Denis Villeneuve is one of the greatest upcoming directors! "Sicario" tells a generic story about an FBI investigation on a drug cartel, that is elevated through Villeneuve's fantastic direction and Roger Deakins' gorgeous cinematography, both Oscar-worthy in this film. The entire cast gives great performances, Benicio Del Toro gives his best performance in years and Emily Blunt gives what is possibly her best performance. Josh Brolin is also very good as this charismatic police agent. This film shows its story in a very realistic and gritty way, making for some very strong scenes. "Sicario" is one of the most powerful and one of the best-looking films of 2015!

Sicario. Kate (blunt) is a strict no hold bars talking FBI agent who is pulled away onto an operation to nail a big Mexican drug lord. Lead by Matt (brolin) who is consultant with the FBI who has a very questionable past and way of thinking Kate believes that maybe this mission is not a good idea. Story is well wrote and very well told. Alejandro (del toro) is excellent in his abilities and portrays his role will brilliance. Gritty script, dazzling and very much a storyline which has crept under the storyline of that of a big blockbuster.

This is an excellent crime drama and a well made film, but do NOT expect a happy ending. You're going to see a good movie, but not feel good. It does put things in perspective and make you think-almost a reality check on how messed up this world is that we live in.
The Border itself is the horror movie villain in this beautiful ultra realistic masterpiece.

Sicario is a very realistic and disturbingly gritty thriller. The movie follows a team of FBI agents, as well as some others, but I'm not really all-knowing about this sort of stuff, who are trying to uncover the biggest cartel business in Juarez. Emily Blunt plays a very careful agent who tries to do everything by the book and when she's given an opportunity to help other agents to infiltrate this cartel, she immediately accepts the offer, but what she doesn't know is that the people she agreed to help are people who don't do anything by the book and are keeping secrets from her. That's the story in short, I don't explain stories very well in these reviews, but I feel like I have to... Anyways, the story is very intriguing and I was hooked from the very beginning. There are many disturbing and brutal scenes that will leave you breathless! The ending is, especially, unsettling. And while it does at times seem like it's something you've already seen before, you certainly won't think that once you see the ending. The acting was fantastic! Benicio Del Toro and Emily Blunt are the absolute best in this movie! Benicio Del Toro's character is very mysterious and has a very dark past and once you find out his actual intentions, you're gonna be quite surprised. Emily Blunt's character, on the other hand, seems like one of the only reasonable characters in the entire movie. The movie looks terrific! The entire movie has this orange/sepia sort of filter and it really works well with the scenes. All in all, one of the better movies this year and one certainly worth watching!

If this film does not win best picture then its a real shame. The score is perfect, reminds of the great work trent rezone and atticus ross are doing at the moment. The two leads are fantastic but the real master here is Dennis Villeneuve. He is one of the most impressive filmmakers around at the moment and this is hands down his best work. The cinematography is wide and beautiful when it needs to be and the balance of camerawork in some of the most gripping set pieces i have ever seen is extraordinary. BEST FILM OF THE YEAR.

Flashes of brilliance, Villeneuve really good at creating moods, making you feel like you're there. But somehow it felt anticlimactic. Maybe it's how I kept thinking of ''Heat'' or ''Traffic'', or the climax of ''Incendies'' and ''Prisoners'', but the build up didn't lead to that. Felt like a 3 hour film edited into 2. Was nice to see Benicio though, and Emily Blunt was great too.

Sorry I didn't like it much, sorry because many people seem to love it, it's just not my cup of tea. I loved the cast, the brutal parts too but I didn't quite understand everything, was a bit tough to follow.
Del Toro and Brolin are a joy to watch. Blunt irritates by design -- in the role of the naive counterpoint. Great movie.
Watching CSI is a better experience than this.

Blunt and Del Toro both deserve nominations for their gritty and powerful performances. Would not be surprised to find Del Toro winning a best supporting Oscar in a couple months. Villeneuve continues to improve with every film (Incendies, Prisoners, Enemy, and now Sicario). One of the most promising/exciting directors in the field right now.

In the blur grey horison of rights and wrongs, Sicario unfolds its story. The Mexican-US border of drugs runs with blood, guns and money. Here Villenueve grasp this tension very well, embarking it into a dark manifestion tale. Visually this is a incredible journey, audiocally its even better.
awesome. dark but very entertaining
Amazing perfomance by benicio del toro, great cinematography, and a great thriller film that captures the horror of mexico

Showing different perspectives of the drug war in Mexico "Sicario" is a neatly directed thriller led by great performances by Benicio Del Toro and Emily Blunt. One of 2015's best, no doubt about it. 4.3/5 stars
filmishte! eden od najdobrite za 2015!!! nema utka so Denis Villeneuve,site filmovi mu se top!
As the movie progresses, the viewer feels a lurking evil and impending doom. These feelings make the climax more than worth it.
The directing is visionary and the storytelling very interesting with an unexpected angle that makes a certain amount of sense, but also never would have considered. Excellent film!

Supported by assured performances from all actors, Sicario delivers a striking, more nuanced take on the drug wars that afflict the American Southwest and Mexico. Thanks to stunning visuals courtesy of the esteemed Roger Deakins, the film draws in the viewer early on and never lets go. Denis Villeneuve pulls no punches with raw, gritty shots punctuating the movie, and delivers a very real image of how crime has ravaged these locales. An ambivalent ending will seem abrupt to some, but one can be sure that the battle rages on from the continued eruptions of gunfire in the streets.

Relentless from the opening scene, Sicario is a tense ride with some grueling turns. Blunt is magnificent in an emotionally-demanding role. Brolin and Del Toro are excellent a casts and Villeneuve provides great direction in another powerful film (I highly recommend his other films Incendies and Prisoners), this one being one of the best thrillers of 2015. 9/10

"In Mexico SICARIO means HITMAN"'Sicario' is an Action Thriller / Crime Drama that follows an FBI agent who gets thrown into a war against the drug cartels operating along the border of the US and Mexico. Apart from the stellar cast leading the film, i was most excited to see this film because of it being directed by Denis Villenueve. For those of you who don't know, he directed 2013's 'Prisoners' and 2014's 'Enemy', both are incredibly fantastic films that were directed to near perfection and you should definitely check out. This was still a fantastically directed film by Villenueve, but compared to those films i just mentioned, this one has many other flaws that didn't make it quite as intense as i hoped it would be from seeing the trailers. If you are looking for a fast paced, high octane action thriller, this is not it. Much like his previous films, this is a very character driven story where the film at times is carried on the backs of the amazing performances by Emily Blunt and Benicio Del Toro. Despite these praises, there are elements of the film that i didn't enjoy and harmed my overall experience with the film. The film started off very promising, it showed off some some of the thriller elements whilst also introducing our characters and the main overall plot of the film which was pretty meh up until the last third of the film. I was initially intrigued by what was going on and wanted to find out more about what is really going on behind the scenes, especially with Del Toro's character. But for almost the entire second act of the film, i found myself checking my phone a few times because it dragged on and on and didn't look to be ending any time soon. It had some short moments that were quite interesting in terms of character development and getting me a little more interested in the plot. But overall, the second act wasn't all that compelling to watch like the rest of the film was. I feel like they tried to do a lot to set up the finale, and just the way it was structured became an issue for me. A lot of scenes didn't quite make sense and took me out of it a bit. It all ran at a fairly slow pace which i was expecting but there were no dramatic or intense tones to get me engaged with what was going on, apart from one or two moments. A lot of this middle section relied purely on the performances of Blunt, Brolin, and Del Toro, and even though they were fantastic it wasn't enough to make me enjoy this section. It's hard to explain, but just a lot of the writing in this section looks and sounds good on paper, but the execution wasn't great. That being said, the last 30 minutes of this movie....... SPECTACULAR. Not going to give anything away but shit hits the fan from a storytelling standpoint, a character standpoint and an action thriller standpoint and this really saved the film for me. All of the little bits and pieces that were set up throughout the film come full circle and you realise a lot of things that maybe didn't make sense earlier make total sense now, such as 'why is the film even called Sicario?....... **You know what, stuff this, i'm gonna revoke some of the things i have mentioned so far MID REVIEW but not edit it out, because thinking about the end, and then thinking about what happened earlier is making me realise that this film was a lot smarter and well crafted than i thought it was 5 minutes ago. I obviously can't talk about any of the things i am thinking about, but this is probably going to make me watch it again like i did with 'Prisoners' and 'Enemy', and i reckon i might enjoy it more the second time, only time will tell. But as i mentioned before, the performances of Emily Blunt, Josh Brolin and Benicio Del Toro were all absolutely fantastic. I am not necessarily surprised because they are all incredible actors but in this film when they came together no-one took anything away from the others' performances. One did stand out well above the others but it didn't make me love the other performances less, if anything each performance added to the others. There is also quite a bit of talent in the supporting roles but due to the scope of these three large actors always commanding the screen they will most likely go largely unnoticed. In the end, Sicario is a film that definitely not everyone will appreciate. It is more than an action thriller and incorporates great amounts of drama, and plenty of intense moments. The second act of the film whilst watching it did really hurt my enjoyment of the film in the moment, but as i mentioned, it didn't bother me nearly as much and i actually now praise some of the decisions they made. If you like Villenueve's previous films this one is not quite up to par but you can still see a lot of his signature all over this film and that is what i enjoyed about it. - 7.2

"Sicario" is a realistic interpretation of the drug trade in Mexico as seen through the eyes of a slightly ignorant FBI operative. The film did not arrive with the same pomp as "The Martian" (which opened the same weekend), but it left an equally large impression on the critics. It is dark, gritty, and the only thing more disturbing than the imagery of cadavers hanging in the streets is the idea that the residents of Juarez have accepted this atmosphere as a part of daily life. The story seems a bit overdramatic but a little research shows this portrayal to be chillingly accurate. Moreover, the main reason that Juarez has descended from its rank as the most violent city in the world is because one drug cartel has defeated its rivals. One would hope that the police and military had brought order to the area, but that is simply not the case. Director Denis Villeneuve has made a bold statement about the government corruption and drug violence that rule this area. Most of the critical praise surrounding "Sicario" has involved the acting. Emily Blunt and Benicio del Toro turn in impressive performances through subtle but powerful moments. I could see either of them receiving an Oscar nomination but neither performance is good enough to win. Josh Brolin also gives the high-caliber performance that we expect from him. I do feel that the film moves a bit too slow, especially after a riveting opening sequence, but the pace gives you a chance to reflect on the unfortunate circumstance of the area. The film focuses on situational development more than character development so that, in the end, you feel a greater attachment to the story than the characters within. "Sicario" accomplishes its goal of bringing awareness to the drug violence in Mexico through strong acting performances and a story that is so unbelievable that you have to believe it.

It's taken a few films, but Denis Villeneuve has finally made the film we knew was in him. This slow-burn thriller recalls all the very best hallmarks of Steven Soderbergh classic Traffic, but intensifies and contemporizes this unstoppable war with frightening reality.You'll see it in the fluidic cinematography; the insane prisoner transfer through the streets of Tijuana is one of the year's finest scenes. Johan Johannson's ominous score adds to the continual overhanging sense of pointlessness of this war. But it's the trio of performances that really give Sicario its integrity. Brolin and Del Toro are both excellent, displaying the varying elusive and ambiguous qualities of their respective characters with great depth. But its Blunt's in-over-her-head FBI recruit who is the heart and soul of this film; its the two qualities completely redundant and wasted in the cyclical, cynical hopelessness this war weighs down on those with any humanity.So, not an uplifting film by any stretch, but a tensely accurate thriller that reminds us all that some wars are unwinnable.

Denis Villeneuve may just be the most exciting and original film maker working in Hollywood currently, he recent psyche crushing thrillers have been a marvel to behold, if not ever so slightly flawed in the smallest of places. Sicario is his latest release before bringing the Blade Runner sequel to the big screen, and although many hardcore fans wait with bated breath, Sicario can act as a solid piece of entertainment to give them some confidence. Going bolder than ever before, Sicario follows the growing turmoil between the border of USA and Mexico, with cartel's massacring all walks of life for money, boredom or drugs. Presented with an opening to find the man in charge of such travesty, a covert government task force enlist the help of a by the books FBI agent, which she is all too happy to comply with, until she uncovers the corrupt and game changing mentality such a force need in order to succeed. From the moment Roger Deakins glorious cinematography lights up the screen and the pounding score breaks in, you instantly know your in for something thrilling and disgusting and Sicario doesnt let you down. The film continually throws you off guard by playing up a typical genre movie, only to snatch your expectations from underneath you and force you to endure a different breed of film. The performances in this film are stunning, Emily Blunt is beyond wonderful as Kate, our protagonist, Josh Brolin does what he does and to great effect, Benecio Del Toro almost steals the show and Jon Berenthal shows up to be an asshole for a brief amount of time. Sicario deals with some horrendous themes and subject matter, so having the cast downplay their performances really allows the grit of the piece to come through, especially when we question the force's tactics only to have them explain what needs to be done to win this war. It's harrowing and it manages to cause a range of emotions from disgust to anger, paranoia to fear and this is what sets Sicario apart from its competition, the film will have you on a razor blade throughout its 2 hour run time, managing to craft some of the most intense sequences you can imagine from the most unlikely of places, without spoiling anything, a traffic jam at the Mexican border will have you reaching for the valium. Its a wonderfully shot and excellently conceptualized thriller which plays the long game, rather than place all its eggs in one basket. Sicario's weakness is sadly its rock solid body armour, the film is so bleak and dank, so full of double crossing and back stabbing, its pretty hard to fully connect with. There are points during Sicario you will either feel lost or have an odd sense of deflation, quite possibly from being on edge constantly, and although if it were intentional this feeling would be acceptable, it happens all too often and for no good reason. Luckily Villeneauve bookends these moments with moments so shocking and pungent it almost makes up for it, almost. Sicario isnt perfect, but its stunning, gripping and darker than oil, an intense ride that will alienate some but further cements a director who may just be about to move up to another level entirely.

Emily Blunt and Benicio Del Toro are powerhouses in this movie. This movie is just plain cold-blooded. The soundtrack as well is just pummeling. A powerful piece of work from director Denis Villeneuve. More than that, it's nearly a masterpiece of sustained and unbearable tension, the sort of movie that gets the audience to feel that something truly awful could erupt at any moment. It's a grim and unflinching film, one that is unafraid to make the audience witness some very intense and unpleasant realities about confronting the drug cartels along the border. As the lead, Emily Blunt is incredible, delivering a performance full of depth that completely sells this by-the-book character's realization of the gravity of the situation she finds herself in; this is Blunt's finest hour, and it is one of the standout performances of the year. She's equally matched by Benicio Del Toro's subtle and enigmatic turn; it's not a showy role, in the traditional sense, because Del Toro plays everything incredibly close to the vest, and he makes what could have been a one-note character into the page into a dynamic and magnetic presence. Roger Deakins' cinematography is fairly stripped down, in contrast to his usually painterly style, but his photography here matches the harshness of the subject matter perfectly (and still finds a way to include some legitimately beautiful compositions, to be sure). If one wanted to nitpick, the plot specifics are - at times - a bit murky, but this appears to be by design. With this, PRISONERS, and ENEMY, Villeneuve has firmly established himself as one of the best thriller directors working today, and while it might be too downbeat for some to stomach, SICARIO is an engrossing and frightening movie, and an experience that won't be easy to shake.

I can confidently say that 'Sicario' is one of the best movies of 2015. This movie exposes the bitter reality we desperately tried to hide, and by doing so, it makes us question about the fundamental values we have taken granted, so far. The most remarkable and charming point of 'Sicario' is it's complicated characters. There are neither perfect heroes nor utter villains in the movie. Each character has their own strengths and weaknesses, and we, the audiences have much trouble in separating the sheep from the goats.  There are several critical issues that the movie requires the audiences to think about. The first one is about the law and the justice. Matt is very competent CIA agent, at least in the war against the drug. He frequently breaks the law, and sometimes, even makes us to question whether his acts are justifiable, but ironically these are the main constituents of his ability. In some sense, he is the most dangerous character in this movie. As the movie progresses, we are somewhat persuaded by him, and begin to think that maybe sometimes, to root out the great evil like the drug, it is allowable to cross a line. Like 'for the greater good' thing. However, is it? Who is entitled to allow such violence of law and injustice?  Kate is the complete opposite of Matt. She is faithful, righteous, and principled FBI agent. She is qualified for the typical protagonist, and we can say she was a good police officer in Phoenix where the rule of law still existed. However, ironically, in this fierce war against the drug, she is helpless and even incompetent because of her faith and morality. I wonder whether she is a 'good' police to deal with the drug problem, because she could not solve anything. This irony itself is what the movie requires us to think about the law. Law is the basic rule which we, by ourselves, made to live on the straight. However, if the law is helpless and incompetent to eradicate the evil and corruption of people, then, where is the place for the law? What is the meaning of the law?  Alejandro is the most complicated character who hides so many secrets. He helps Kate in critical moments. On the other hand, he ruthlessly killed the innocent woman and children for his personal revenge. He was originally a prosecutor, which means that he knows the law, and understands the very meaning of justice and morality. However, the extreme experience made him to do such cold-blooded thing. Can we judge him, and criticize him whose wife's head was cut off, and whose daughters were thrown in hydrochloric acid? To make our society healthy, we must think that even so, this behavior is unjustifiable. However, in the bottom of my heart, I am not sure. Then, what is justice? Second one is about the evil. To be precise, the banality of evil. From the beginning of the movie, it intermittently shows Silvio's everyday life with his son, right after Kate's life in work or home. At first, I thought these scenes are meaningless, but now I understand the meaning of them. In my opinion, this character, Silvio represents the banality of evil. Silvio is an ordinary man, diligent police officer, and good father who cares about his son very much. On the other hand, he works for the cartel, and delivers drugs which destroys millions of families. That is, he is also the part of the evil that should be eradicated. This is the essence of evil. Not every bad guy looks like a monster. He or she is usually among our neighborhood, and can be good mother or father for their children, and outside home, destroys millions of families. No one is born evil, and looks like devil. No one is designated to be evil. 'Sicario' is the movie that sets an extreme condition and require the audience to continuously question about the most basic rule and faith of our society. It does not give answers to these questions. Perhaps, no one can. I believe finding an answer is an obligation of all of us 'who lives in the lands of the wolves' I'd like to finish this plain review with the quote from 'Mad Max : Fury road', another fabulous movie of 2015 : "Where must we go, we who wander this wasteland, in search of our better selves - the First Man"

Sicario is a bit of a tough movie to watch because it seems like the producer wants to desensitize the audience when it comes to murder and humanity. The fact that there are bodies hidden in the walls and hung across the tunnels in Mexico and Kate's lacking facial expression when she sees these atrocities shows that mutilated dead bodies are somewhat normal. This movie relates to the movie, Border Town, because of the misrepresentation of Mexico. Even though drug cartels exist, it seems like producers make these type of films to highlight the negative aspects of the country. City officials of Juarez even stated that this movie was depicting the city in a bad light. They also stated that criminal activities have declined since the movie has been made, so it appears that the producer wants to milk the criminal activity in Mexico as much as he can in order to make a masterpiece of a movie. Although one of the themes in the movie tries to portray the glorified murders in Mexico, an interesting theme in the movie is how they assigned a female to play the part of an FBI agent. Just like in the movie, Border Town� when Jennifer Lopez's character was assigned to play the lead role in solving or documenting a murder case, Kate, the FBI agent, is seen taking a stand and trying to figure out how to solve the case even after she was told that she wasn't needed anymore. Kate relates to Jennifer Lopez's character in Border Town after her boss decides not to use her information because he wants to sell out. These female characters are often assigned important roles in order to be demoted into the character that is no longer needed. This is borderline sexist because movies like this seem to be allowing the female characters to get a taste of being superior and to be considered as one of the guys when in reality they are just being used by the white men to gain access to the valuables. This movie proves itself to be sexist as well as devaluation of humanity because of the displays of dead bodies everywhere and that one female character who is considered to be of no use after the white men obtain what was needed. This movie appears to be insensitive to the people living in Juarez because they are communicating to the audience that this is not a safe place to visit or be. Sicario can influence a viewer to believe that the city of Juarez is dangerous and should be avoided at all costs.

Director Denis Villeneuve (Prisoners, Enemy) has proven to be a dominating force in cinema. Sicario is an another outstanding achievement in his career. This time, Villeneuve takes on America's war on drugs. From start to finish, Sicario is a tension filled spectacle. If ever think the film will ever ease up, don't hold your breath. Sicario follows a FBI Special Weapons and Tactics Teams agent Kate Macer, played by Emily Blunt. During a drug raid, a bomb goes off killing two fellow officers. She meets Matt Graver (Josh Brolin), a Department of Defense adviser who is setting up a team to capture those responsible. Kate is offered a spot, which she accepts. She soon meets Matt's mysterious partner, Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro). Kate begins to discover Matt's and Alejandro's unorthodox and illegal procedures. Sicario is dark and gripping tale held together by a strong direction, screenplay, and acting. Emily Blunt gives an outstanding performance that should earn her an Oscar nomination. Much like the audience, Kate is in the dark about Matt's and Alejandro's agenda. As the film progresses, she is given more light on their agenda, but is morally conflicted of how they are going about it. She wants to capture this drug lord, but at what cost? One of Blunt's strongest aspects of her performance is her facial expressions. It highlights her confusion and frustration with the situation. Brolin is stellar as the cocky team leader. Matt's one and only goal is to take down this drug lord in any way he can. He doesn't lose sleep about the way he goes about it, it's just business. The most mysterious character is Alejandro. Del Toro gives bone chilling performance. It is also his most captivating performance since Traffic. Maybe films about illegal drug trade is his calling. The unsettling direction by Villeneuve is brilliantly captured by cinematographer Roger Deakins. Deakins uses actual darkness to capitalize on the film's gritty nature. If I had to give one warning about Sicario is that there is no shining light at the end of the tunnel. The film does not give the viewer anything or anyone to hold on to. Sicario commits in being dark. You feel like you have to cleanse yourself afterwards. But while you are watching the film, you will be glued. Dennis Villeneuve continues to deliver and proving to be one of the best up and coming directors working today. A very well put together film with great cinematography by Legendary DP Roger Deakins. Solid Performances by Emily Blunt, Josh Brolin and Benecio Del Toro. A gripping thriller that definitely keeps you engage throughout the whole 2 hour runtime. An average film. Nothing particularly gripping, just very violent. It seems as though some of the violence depicted is based on the real life events/violence going on in Mexico. However, a lot of the plot seems rather unrealistic. For example, I thought Emily Blunt's character's relationship with the Swat team should have panned out differently because of both her attitude, voiced opposition to the unruly behaviour/operations of the Swat team and also when she goes off on her own during a live operation. You would have expected some harm to come to her. The other thing I did not get was how Emily's character and that of her partner who seem to be both in position through political correctness rather than ability, no matter how much the film tries to say otherwise, are able to just slot into the Swat team's operations. Just not realistic at all, almost stupid. A bit like joining the Navy Seals for an operation with no training at all. Then Del Torro fails to deal with Emily Blunt's character in the manner consistent with his character. Similarly, the last scene involving Del Torro and the Drug Lord is rather silly to say the least. Hasn't the director seen Scarface. In short, there are some good parts to the film and some ridiculous, almost lazy parts that the director could have sorted out if he had a bit more balls. Scorcessee would have made a classic out of this. It was begging for it.

Fade from black the film start with a legend, the true definition of Sicario.latin term is a hitman, a person responsible killing by contract. But in Hebrew, Roman kill Zealots. With this title we been presented a blue print of what about too see. FBI agents Kate Macer (Emily Blunt) and Reggie Wayne (Daniel Kaluuya) raid the house of a suspected kidnappers. The team finds more than dozen of bodies hidden on the walls of the house.After this operation Kate's boos recommend her to Matt Graver (Josh Brolin) a CIA Special Activities Division to join the team. Matt is searching for a cartel boss who presumably was one of the responsible of the murders found by Kate and Reggie.Kate character is a green agent who still learning the vicious cycle inside FBI and CIA. Throughout the film she start discovering the corruption, manipulation, abuse of power of this federals agencies, but she is unaware of who is the real enemy. Kate is a strong woman on the outside, vulnerable for been alone and also divorced, it's also supporter of ethics and respect in the force, one of her biggest enemies in this war against corruption. Arriving to el Paso, Texas in a orchestrated operation lead by Matt Graver, Kate meet with Alejandro Gallic (Benicio del Toro) an advisor who seems to have ties with enemy. Alejandro is very sketchy person, and Kate figure out the first time she see him.Besides all this red flags Matt use it as his primary connection to get the cartel people capture.Sicario is a thriller but also a great film about the hard reality of drug traffic in US borders. Masterfully directed by Denis Villeneuve (Enemy, Prisoners) the movie immerse you in a harsh terrain where only the strongest succeed. Villeneuve engage with the audience with a rollercoaster of emotions by manipulating the senses. Sicario have constant moments of silence, also supported by the impactful original score by J�hann J�hannsson and the intense sound crafted for this film. The visual style is borrowed from films by Steven Sodergber in Traffic, also Jonathan Demme in Silence of The Lambs. The intense and long aerial shots are powerful and serve as another character for the movieAfter carefully you finish the film you came to the conclusion who is the enemy and who are the zealots. You care for Kate's character but not so much for Matt and Alejandro. The true meaning of sicario is the search for fanatical and uncompromising pursuit of ideas, that could be religious or political, you just need to pick one.

One has to love brilliant acting from Emily Blunt and Benicio del Toro, the most brilliant soundtrack which creates pounding tension and proper suspense, cinematography to create proper tension among sequences, etc. The story about drug trade is not new at all. After all these years' war on drugs, we are still fighting drug cartels, or drug cartels fighting one another, and so on. There is no black and white anymore as we might get the hint from Benicio del Toro' s character. And you know what? It is true. And who are we to judge what is right and what could possibly be definitely wrong?One of my top three movies in 2015.

Sicario achieves the reality of drug wars that is often traded for the Hollywood effect; a reality where there are no losses or winnings, only trade-offs, and no heroes or villains, only victims. Intensely action packed from beginning to end, Sicario will have you at the edge of your seat while showing the astounding and brutal reality of drug wars and how powerful drug cartels really are.Directed by Denis Villeneuve, Sicario is a film about an FBI agent who is enlisted by the government on a mission to bring down the leader of a powerful Mexican cartel. The flawless performance of Emily Blunt and Benicio del Toro, along with stunning cinematography, create a heavy and suspenseful atmosphere throughout the movie.Most importantly however, is the story and its relevance to the real situation. As someone who lived in Juarez / El Paso while the worst of the drug wars was taking place, who watched news stories after news stories of brutal assassinations, shootings and kidnappings, and who saw how the city became deserted as people moved out and businesses closed due to fear, I got chills while watching this movie. One just had to innocently be at the wrong place at the wrong time to have an unlucky fate.Sicario portrays the reality of a very cruel but important issue. While this film will not leave you with a warm feeling or a happy ending, you will be immersed into a very dark place and be surprised by how deep you will go.

-Sicario is een 2015 Amerikaanse crime thriller film geregisseerd door Denis Villeneuve en geschreven door Taylor Sheridan. De film sterren Emily Blunt, Benicio Del Toro, en Josh Brolin. Deze film werd gekozen om te strijden voor de Palme d'Or op het 2015 Cannes Film Festival.-In december 2013 werd aangekondigd dat Denis Villeneuve een Mexicaanse grens drama zou dirigeren, Sicario (het Spaanse woord voor Hitman).--Kritische reactie:-Sicario wordt alom geprezen door critici. Recensie aggregator website RottenTomatoes, de film heeft een goedkeuringsscore van 93%, gebaseerd op 184 reviews, met een gemiddelde waardering van 8.1/10.. De site's kritische consensus leest. "Geleid door uitstekende werk van Emily Blunt en Benicio Del Toro, Sicario is een strak, stevig gespannen thriller met veel meer bezig dan aandacht trekkende decorstukken." Op Metacritic, de film heeft een gewogen gemiddelde score van 81 uit 100, gebaseerd op 41 critici, met vermelding "success". Op CinemaScore, publiek heeft de film een gemiddelde cijfer van "A-" op een A TOT F-schaal.-Richard Roeper heeft de film een tien, noemt het een van de beste van dit jaar, en bejubeld del Toro's performance, zeggende: "...er is del Toro, die loert over de marge van de actie voor het merendeel van het verhaal, en dan in actie springt in een handvol sc�nes in een verscheidenheid van manieren die laat geschud laten - en dankbaar om een zo mooi donker werk gezien te hebben'.-Dan Jolin van Empire heeft de film 5 sterren en noemt het "een prachtig duistere, keiharde thriller. Gewoon ��n van de beste films van het jaar."-hoewel haar personage Kate Mercer niet plausibel is, Emily Blunt "brazens uit eventuele onrechtmatigheden met grote actering focus en front".- "kunstig en spraakmakend" en "onberispelijk realistische momenten", heeft een aantal tekortkomingen. Ten eerste, de federale agenten".agressieve tactieken en overtredingen in regels in Sicario zijn veel meer nodeloos dan eender wat hij getuigde in zijn verslag. Ten tweede is er een gebrek aan invallende Spaanse rechtshandhaving agenten, zoals personages, in de film in verhouding tot die momenteel in het echte leven werkend. Tenslotte de film richt zich overwegend op het Amerikaanse oogpunt in de war on drugs.-heeft de film een B-, waaruit blijkt dat het gebrek aan karakter ontwikkeling was een afknapper ondanks extreem sterke cinematografische en stijlvol regisseren. Hij voegde er nog aan toe dat "Sicario wellicht ��n van de meest melancholische, moreel failliet, en ethisch inhoudsloze mainstream films die dit jaar is uitgebracht; toch, zulke zwaarmoedigheid komt met het grondgebied van het huidige, politicus-gebrandmerkte 'war on drugs'.-Chris Ryan van Grantland vergelijkt Sicario met de film Apocalypse Now geregisseerd door Francis Ford Coppola. Hij stelt de gelijkenis van de visuals met betrekking tot de respectieve narratieven van de twee films. Hij schrijft ook dat de karakters Alejandro Gillick, en Matt graven in Sicario zijn vergelijkbaar met die van kolonel Kurtz en William Kilgore, respectievelijk in Apocalypse Now.--Reactie van ambtenaren in Ciudad Ju�rez (Mexico):-Sicario's portrettering van Ciudad Ju�rez werd bekritiseerd door functionarissen van die stad, die dachten dat de film hun stad in een kwaad daglicht stelde. In de film opgenomen sequenties die kadavers opknoping aan downtown viaducten en nachtelijke vuurgevechten in de stad vertoont. Deze ambtenaren zijn van mening dat op het moment van de release van de film, de intensiteit van criminele activiteit in de stad aanzienlijk waren gedaald ten opzichte van voorgaande perioden.- Bestudering van de Amerikaanse War on Drugs:-Volgens Sebastian Rotella, Sicario onderzocht vele aspecten van de oorlog tegen drugs door de Verenigde Staten tegen, meestal, drugskartels in Mexico, Zuid-Amerika en Midden-Amerika. Een perspectief nemend als een Amerikaanse, zo merkte hij op dat de film illustreert hoe de Amerikaanse war on drugs is "wat ons in het bijzonder tot monsters maakt die wij proberen te verslaan." Bovendien is de situatie in Mexico, met betrekking tot de illegale drugshandel, gestagneert voor twee decennia, zoals van de film's release. Dit punt is herhaaldelijk door het personage Matt Graves gemaakt in de film.

Daniel Villeneuve's "Sicario" is a brilliant film that features beautiful direction, some great performances, and stunning cinematography from Roger Deakins. But however perfect I want it to be, this movie still has flaws. The characters aren't too unique or interesting in their own right, they're all just tropes, and the scenes near the end that focus on Benicio del Toro's character, while great, feel out of place with the rest of the movie. Despite the faults that it has, all its accomplishments are enough to outweigh them and to make this the best major motion picture of 2015 so far. A mainstream North American film that is subtle and challenges the audience? Who could've thunk it?

The spiritual successor to Traffic - and a worthy one - concerns itself primarily not with the why but with how the war against drugs is managed when everyone knows its futile. Unquestioned career bests from the three leads (the main impediments to del Toro's second Oscar will be the erroneous assumption that he's re-hashing traffic and Brolin splitting the vote) and the judicious use of violence keep this a cut above the TV procedural it occasionally threatens to resemble.

Very dark movie. Slightly misleading to given that I thought that the protagonist was Emily but she turns out to be more of a main character than actual protagonist. It's a solid movie though and it does keep it interesting however, i found the lack of theme and structure to be a big time fault.

The excellently directed Sicario is something I haven't seen in some time. Blending an almost majestic quality to the scope and span of the lands between Mexico and the US, which in simple terms for Sicario, the entrance to hell. The three lead performances of Josh Brolin, Emily Blunt and Benicio Del Toro are remarkable and mesmerizing to watch, with Blunt's traumatized protagonist leading us through a greenhorn's look at across the Mexican border and into a dark and violent world where law is forgotten and a distant idea. Brolin is likeable and charming as the commander of the squadron, Blunt is remarkable in her depiction of a woman thrust into a very real side of cruelty and injustice, but Del Toro steals the show with his as what I can only call the sicario, or hitman. His character's deeply troubled backstory adds to the disturbing nature of the somber and calm way he handles himself and commits atrocities, making you truly question what he stands for. The action scenes are incredibly thought out and the growing tension and suspense is Hitchcock level in how the scenes are set. The soundtrack adds a dark, ominous and thrilling atmosphere to an already chillingly grim and real movie.

Sicario can be summed up in one word: intense. From the explosive first scene to the pulse pounding conclusion, the film is unrelenting in both its imagery and pace. This does not, however, hide the fact that the lead character, played by Emily Blunt, is a weak willed female being dominated by her male counterparts. This is a shame, as in the past, Emily Blunt has portrayed very strong female leads, such as in Looper or Edge of Tomorrow. I was looking forward to her dominating the screen, but instead found her crying more than she was helping her mission. The story is interesting, but once everything is set in motion, it is hard not to predict just what is really going on behind the curtain. It would be a mistake not to commend Roger Deakins on his brilliant cinematography, as there are some brilliant shots of Mexico that are haunting in their beauty. The soundtrack also helps to lend a sense of weight to the proceedings. I'm alway impressed with Denis Villeneuve's direction, and this is no exception. If it weren't for the disappointing lead character, and the predictable plot points, this may have been up there for my favourite film of the year. If you enjoy dark thrillers, action films or dramas, this should definitely be on your short list for movies to watch this year. 4 out of 5 stars.

Sicario does not hold the audience's hand. In fact, even Emily Blunt's character is mostly left out of the loop as Denis Villeneuve dives into the unknown of crime and corruption. The build-up of tension is thus more impactful, with excellent cinematography that captures the sprawling environments which would be explored. The intertwining subplot is only occasionally seen, but it is there to further the ripple effect that the main plot causes.While Blunt and Josh Brolin are solid, Benicio Del Toro is one to look out for, as his character has a lot on his mind. The actors in general do display bits of comic relief to ease the film's stressful nature. Nevertheless, Blunt's character is purposely treated in a sexist manner, only so that she can properly manifest her opposition to the unethical procedures being ran by the team with whom she otherwise thought her methods would be useful.The lack of soundtrack of course adds more tension to demanding scenes, while the music that does play is visceral. And off-screen sound plays a key role in the alienation of the plot towards us and Blunt's character.Denis Villeneuve is however no stranger to tackling unconventional methods of storytelling, and thanks to his and his crew's fine work, Sicario proves to be a mysterious, daring, competent crime thriller.
Roger Deakins' fantastic camerawork really elevates the material and the actors are top notch. Definitely deserves to be viewed on a big screen.

I was not a fan of director Denis Villeneuve's first two efforts ("Prisoners" and "Enemy"), both of which I felt suffered from weak writing.� Luckily, with this film, Villeneuve finally found the right material to suit his style.� Everything hits right in this movie, it's the perfect storm of an excellent script, sharp directing, and a stellar cast.� The actors are all at the top of their games, particularly Benicio Del Toro, who is in peak badass form.� The film has the same stylized look and ominous tone as Villeneuve's first two features, but as a composition, this one is far superior.� The film starts with a bang (there aren't even any opening credits) and grabs your attention right out of the gate, I was hooked within the first 5 minutes.� The story skims along nicely and maintains high-tension throughout, and makes excellent use of music to help pile on the tension.� It's not easy to watch, but it's to be commended that the film does not pull its punches, and it's all the more affecting for it.�� There are some pretty disturbing images and concepts here, but that's really the point.� This movie does not give you the typical "good guy/bad guy" scenario that we can all sit back and be comfortable with.� Instead, it's a full-tilt exploration of moral ambiguity and challenges your ideas of what being a "good" or "bad" guy even means.� But more than anything, it's a depressing confirmation that the 'War on Drugs' is hopelessly unwinnable. It does lose some points for a having a female lead who, in typical Hollywood fashion, ultimately has to be saved by a man.� So that was disappointing, I would have liked to see the so-called "strong female lead" save herself for a change.� But that's really all I can say against it.� This is an intelligent, atmospheric, gripping, and thought-provoking psychological thriller, that's also incredibly well made.� It doesn't give you the warm fuzzies, nor should it, but it should be seen.

One of the best movies of 2015. At the border of the United States and Mexico lies a lawless land where justice is not always black and white. A young FBI agent Kate Macer (Emily Blunt) is working with the FBI to catch drug trafficker with a violent record. Sadly, she finds that the scope of the corruption is beyond her understanding. She is recruited by Matt Graver (Josh Brolin) to be part of an Undercover Team to pick up a witness across the Mexican Border, and bring him back to the United States. Kate meets Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro) who is a Consultant that she doesn't understand his job. As they cross the border, everything she believes is tested and her loyalties come in question. Their mission to find a notorious Drug King Pin turns into a bloody path with no real distinction between wrong and right. This movie is such a brilliantly directed movie with a perfect cast. Emily Blunt is so convincing as the naive FBI agent & Del Toro steals the screen with just one look. I expect this to be one of the contenders for awards season.

SICARIO - an emotionally driven thriller where actions speak louder than words. I saw this in a packed theatre on Sunday night after the Walking Dead... just when I thought I was desensitized to violence, I was rudely awakened and nearly walked out on the movie when my date complained that we were sitting too close and the violent imagery was too intense, but the artistic filmmaking was captivating and we stuck through it. There's not much to say about the plot, since it's more about emotionally exploring the world of drug cartels on the other side of the American border. Through terrible events that occur around and directly to the main character, an idealistic white woman (an important storytelling decision), our sense of American law, order, and justice is crushed. This movie is not for kids and its full impact is best experienced in a dark movie theatre...

The biggest war that America needs to win isn't in the middle east or South Asia. It is deep within its heartland where the drug lords of the Mexican cartels have spread the highly influential poison and there is no sign of it ceasing. Tons of illicit drugs pass through secretive tunnels beneath the borders of USA and Mexico, accounting to some very wealthy and powerful cartels while scores of Americans perish under their harmful effects. Parts of Mexico are literally the most violent places on Earth and while Denis Villeneuve's 'Sicario' showcases all these realities between the borders, it serves merely as a backdrop to the true motive hidden beneath the story's surface. This covert war on drugs by America is completely in the gray area of morality and justice of which, Kate (Emily Blunt) is an exponent. She is, however, only learning to cope with the reality around her which alters itself brutally and that, makes her the perfect proxy for the audience. The cartel has pushed deeper into American soil with Manuel Diaz controlling much of their trade through his legit businesses. While raiding one of his properties for a kidnapping investigation, FBI agent Kate discovers several decaying bodies hidden behind the walls of a house in Chandler, AZ and a subsequent explosion in the backyard shed leaves two of her agents dead. Determined to bring Manuel to justice, she agrees to volunteer in a covert CIA mission led by Matt Graver (Josh Brolin). On their way to El Paso, she is introduced to the mysterious Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro), whose shady background keeps Kate on guard but whose sharpness on field soon gains her respect. What follows is perhaps the most tense, suspenseful sequence where the agents extradite Guillermo (Manuel's brother) in and out of a prison in Juarez. Brilliantly executed with escalating build-up, aerial cinematography of chaos and a thumping background score, this has to be among the finest moments in recent cinema. Emily Blunt's performance thereafter, portraying Kate's disbelief in the irresponsible engagement with the cartel members at the border in the midst of civilians, is outstanding. Throughout the film, she shows her righteous side that upholds justice, procedure and law. She is vocal about the ambiguity of the mission but as the events unfold, she is left with no choice but to become part of Matt's anarchic team. They soon track down Manuel and initiate a plan that would require him to meet the Cartel's head in Mexico to answer some questions. Against the backdrop of an incredible sunset, the team discovers the tunnel that would lead them to the cartel but Kate sees things she wasn't supposed to. Josh Brolin really gets into his character as he enlightens her about the reality that will be too much for her to handle. He is a bad-ass agent who isn't shaken by the guns firing around him as he chews his gum. Brolin depicts Matt's coldness but with purpose as he sets himself to pursue the bigger objective of the mission. Between Kate's idealism and Alejandro's darkness, Matt is simply a reality check for the situation and Josh Brolin delivers that superbly. Mayhem on a personal level ensues after the tunnel episode and without revealing much of the story's twist, it should suffice to say that it all makes sense in the end. Benicio Del Toro revisits the cartel world after 'Traffic', 'Che' and 'Escobar'. His insight into Alejandro's character seems naturally easy with a rock solid composure under any circumstance that is a result of his dark past. We will never know what he precisely did with the 10 gallon water container that he took into the interrogation room where Guillermo was held and that, is the level of intrigue held by Del Toro's performance. Screenwriter Taylor Sheridan doesn't just focus on the menace of cartel activity on the streets. The film also goes into its effect on a completely normal family of Silvio, a police officer in Mexico who gets his hands dirty for that extra income. Kate's evolution as a special agent in the war on drugs is in sharp contrast to Silvio's journey. The cinematography by Roger Deakins truly brings out the thrill of imminent danger with vast aerial shots, wide sunset shots and close, dark encounters in the tunnel sequence and the minimalist background score by Johan Johannsson's simply augments the effect. Villeneuve delineates this covert war on drugs without the typical mainstream approach. He shows monstrosity taking over both sides, resulting in total neglect of judicial process, law and morals. Benicio Del Toro is the manifestation of this monstrosity in a laudable performance that should win him a nomination for the Oscars. 'Sicario' isn't triumphant for society but it truly is one of the best thrillers that shows the merciless environment created by the cartels on both sides of the border. 8.987 on a scale of 1-10.

Slow paced, behind the times and surprisingly uninterested in utilizing its capable cast, Sicario is an out-of-touch waste from start to finish that has been propelled solely by undeserved pre-release hype.

Mexico's gruesome cartel wars makes for a bleak and deeply unsettling subject, but in recent years it's been mined by a number of directors and yielded a slew of terrific films. Sin Nombre, Cartel Land, Narco Cultura and a few others come to mind. Sicario has now firmly planted itself in that group. Probably best described as a cross between Zero Dark Thirty and No Country for Old Men, this movie borrows some of the best elements of both films to paint a brutal, deeply cynical portrait of "The War on Drugs" and its gruesome human costs. Without delving too deep into the story since you should see it - tonight if you could - but Emily Blunt gives a terrific turn as strong-headed, by-the-book FBI agent overwhelmed by an amorphous moral morass she finds herself in. Benicio Del Toro has always been a versatile actor - and he's been one of my favorite character actors since The Usual Suspects. He's been in enough cartel movies to be dangerously-close to being typecast. That said, he always brings something extra to these movies and he does amazing work here as a world-weary, mysterious enforcer. The past few weeks have been great for devastatingly-bleak films about real-world issues anchored by phenomenal performances (I saw this shortly after watching Beasts of No Nation which saw Idris Elba and newcomer Abraham Attah deliver awards-worthy work). Like that film, much of Sicario's haunting power comes from its rootedness in the ugliness of the world we live in but often choose to acknowledge.

Gritty, intense, beautifully-filmed and undeniably powerful, Sicario is an absolutely riveting piece of cinema that sticks with you well after watching it (which you should seriously do, ASAP, because it's spectacular). It's less the kind of exceptional film that leaves you raving hours after leaving the theatre, and more the kind that genuinely makes your jaw drop and leaves you speechless to describe it.(On a side note, MAN has this month been good to us for movies this year. When you have not one or two but SIX high-grade films released within the span of a month, it's like an elusively rare slice of moviegoing heaven)
Riveting! An almost perfect film.

A simple drug trafficking plot presented in a style; gripping music, Ariel view of the hunt, powerful performances from all and screenplay which has tense situations through-out makes you glue to the seat.

A pure mood piece. Stellar acting, a nervy score and assured pacing make Sicario the best thriller of the year. Without hyperbolising, this is an utterly visceral experience, with Villevenue gripping you tightly and holding you down, forcing you to witness the atrocities, which, whilst mostly played with nuance and style, are undeniably vile, with the revulsion pushed to the limit by the end of the film. This is a brutal, cold, unflinching and often breathtaking thriller, with awards-worthy work from actors Blunt and Del Toro, as well as covertly masterful cinematography from veteran Roger Deakins. If there's one flaw it's that, whilst Sicario may seep inside you as you watch, the wider point it makes about the situation in Mexico is rather unsubstantial if you consider it a few days later. No matter, this is pulse pounding thrill ride and any other clich� I could put here to close the review. It's good - watch it.

This is exciting storytelling. It definitely is not for everyone. If you liked TV shows Breaking Bad, Narcos, or The Bridge, this movie is an excellent accessory to these programs. If you have never heard of these shows don't go to the movie. The movie shows the horrific ends that the Mexican drug cartels will enlist to get their drugs to market. I don't know if there was a back on my seat in the theater. I was on the edge of it throughout the movie. Emily Blunt is outstanding. All business. Will probably get an academy nomination.

Denis Vilneuve is an expert in tension and atmosphere - this much I know. Sicario is a story highly worthy of being told. A very entertaining and flawlessly executed movie that made me hold my breath multiple times. Sometimes I felt so tense, that any little sound made me jump out of my seat. It's a gritty examination of Mexico's dire drug problem and its effects on the USA. Outstanding cinematography - of a landscape that is character in itself- and music that heightens the tension combine with Villeneuve's superb storytelling and intense performances especially by Emily Blunt- who holds her own in a tough male dominated world. Del Toro and Blunt both deliver outstanding performances, but Emily Blunt has an edge of steel. She brings off a mix of confidence, bewilderment and vulnerability. If you don't wanna watch this movie for its story, watch it for her. She ralmost knocks everyone else unconscious in this movie.Sicario is the kind of drama/action movie you wanna (or should) see. The tension and emotions are present 110%. The whole time I could not stop asking myself the question ''Who will pull the trigger first?''. You don't really trust anyone except Kate (Emily Blunt) - who is not trusting anyone either. Every time an ally is met, that ally either dies or betrays someone. Sicario is a completely engrossing, beautifully shot, terrifically acted thriller that exceeds expectations. I won't give away the opening scene, but I'd find it hard to believe that you're bored after seeing that. It's ultimately disturbing, kind of dark in a way, but that's also one of the reason why it succeeds: it reaches out to the audience and plays with your emotions.Villeneuve's taut direction, combined with beautiful cinematography, and an amazing score, make Sicario one of his best in his constantly growing filmography. The end result is a great movie that will hopefully get recognition at award season. A tense drama that is engaging yet leaves you feeling helpless at the end.

Enemy, Prisoners and now... Sicario; Denis Villeneuve proves once and for all that he is one of, if not, THE most talented new directors to hit our screens in quite some time. For me, Sicario is one of the most grounded and realistic films i've ever seen. Every gunshot, every stand off and every corpse you see feels tactile, has gravitas and feels important. Rather than a story about the "War on Drugs", Sicario is much more a comment on the war and american foreign policy in general which originally took me off guard but I believe offered a much more deep and rewarding narrative for a film of such defined scope. The direction by Villeneuve is remarkably immersive as you the audience are treated just like Kate (Emily Blunt's character) as you are thrown into the story, out of depth and unsure of what lies ahead trying to negotiate the morality of what you see before you. Emily Blunt and Josh Brolin are remarkable while Benecio Del Toro is simply superb and deserves a nomination for, what I feel, is a career defining role as the troubled and enigmatic Alejandro. The moody, steady paced and brooding tone of the picture is matched by Roger Deakins' signature flawless cinematography where images of the vast landscape of Juarez and El Paso flow like liquid and where nighttime shots ACTUALLY look like nighttime!!! The thumping composed score by Johann Johannsson feels like that of a horror movie and keeps tension as high as possible during gripping build ups to shootouts between the cartel and the FBI. To conclude... Sicario is a film where it's weight doesn't hit you until you step out of the screen and really contemplate what you've just witnessed. One of the best films of the year and a real treat.... GO SEE IT!!!!

I just saw and completely disagree with the description, it is a violent, movie with foul language instead of dialogue and very choppy editing so it becomes very jumpy - very suited to pre teens used to doing everything in 5 second bites.
