Dirty things happen in a dirty war. For all it's superficial down and dirty credentials, full of mumblecore and meaningful looks, it's still in essence, a flagelistic, formulaic, police procedural. Emily Blunt plays the moral compass, she quivers, she smokes, she spins, she smokes again. Benicio del Toro represents the outcome with baggy eyed authority whilst Josh Brolin's amoral character view represents the problem. As a cake, Sicario's ingredients are crude but it has an icing of great accomplishment.

Benicio Del Toro was fantastic!!! But the main character Emily Blundt is written as naive and unbelievable. Anyone who deals with that world of corruption and drug trafficking should not be a I'm going to tell on you if your not 100% by the book in procedures. These are not construction workers-these are people who work for the Mexican drug cartel who would shoot you without a second thought and say its not personal. But your going to turn in the people who saved your life for not being kind to murderers. Time went quickly and Del Toro will get a deserved Oscar supporting actor nod.

Great performances by the main trio of Blunt, Brolin and del Toro anchor the film as it takes a pessimistic stance on the war on drugs and the direction it is heading in. If you know the word sicario, it's probably from Narcos. Like that show, this is a perfectly competent movie ruined by another clueless gringo protagonist who is totally out of their element. Sicario is so far one of my favorite movies of 2015 so far. The acting in this film is outstanding. His character was just scary and a badass. I really do think Benicio del Toro is Oscar-worthy. Same thing goes for the score and cinematography. SICARIO is a thrilling film that plays like a gradual punch of adrenaline; it places and lingers the tension for a gripping experience - courtesy of the original score's strong presence and top-notch directorial and cinematographic execution. Not for the faint-hearted, this film truly aims to make viewers feel the weight and is great in many ways once some glaring flaws are overlooked (including a script that by the end wasn't as expansive and fulfilling as initially indicated as well as some rushed but important moments of decision and protocol); it employs high stakes and tense scenes that effectively utilize the tools of cinema, and does so in a way that admirably and provocatively explores the conflict between morality and serviceability.

This movie...THIS MOVIE, never lets off the pedal from the go. It is a rare film in todays market that is absolutely great every single moment. Absolute must see. Go enjoy yourself.

A violent and dark thriller with some very intense and suspense-filled moments, this is an effective and often powerful film with a political message after the carnage has settled. Emily Blunt's performance stands out, much in the same way as Jodie Forster's did in Silence of the Lambs, as she is not only the main character but the only female character in a sea of male testosterone - which makes the decision strange when she was sidelined in the finale confrontation. I suppose that this is illustrative of the film's insistence on realism and grittiness over contrivances and for that, I do applaud, but as a result, the downbeat and disconnected ending feels less than satisfying but maybe the gender unfairness is the point here?

Emily Blunt and Benicio del Toro put in two excellent performances in this thriller about the war on drugs between the US and Mexico. Directed by Denis Villeneuve (Prisoners) this is well executed film with some very tense set pieces. The story focuses on Kate Macy played by Emily Blunt, an FBI agent who has been hand picked to join an elite task force headed by Josh Brolin. However Macy is kept mostly in the dark about what her job is and it is this separation that the audience also feels. If Macy is the moral and righteous core on the flip-side you have Benicio Del Toro, who plays Alejandro, a Colombian consultant with some questionable methods of interrogation. And like Del Toro must of the characters in the film are unapologetic about who they are and realistic about the situation they are in which just adds to the whole sense of alienation and griminess of the film. Although it is a film that very well made it isn't one that you'll instantly want to watch again. However having said that you do feel that this part of something more epic.

Brolin is making a habit of playing what would have been a Tommy Lee Jones role 20 years ago. He does it well, but one gets the feeling that it's being phoned in. Del Toro is mysterious and frightening. One wonders what No Country for Old Men would have been like with him playing the role created by Bardem. Blunt is quickly becoming a feminist action star. I really want to see what she's got next.

Sicario builds and builds, keeping you on edge til the very end. Though the story is not necessarily "original" the meticulous creation of it is. Go see it.

It is unclear why this film was made except for Americans to beat off to yet another mindless action-adventure that the studio tried to make legitimate by including Emily Blunt in the film. The development of the characters in this film likely occurred in ten or twenty minutes with the screenwriter arguing with the director over a bologna sandwich. Matt is the typical brash but yet relaxed government agent of unknown origin, who is somehow made into a complete character here by giving him flip-flops so we can see his relaxed side. Alejandro has all the charisma of Frankenstein uttering lines that would make Tom Cruise blush, such as "You are asking me how a watch works. Just pay attention to the time." There is more drama and legitimacy in any episode of CSI or NCIS than this turd of a movie. We are supposed to believe that Blunt, who appears to have a passive and unnatural role in a kidnapping squad is brought into the inner circle of homeland security/CIA to tag along with special ops and so forth. In her work with the FBI she has likely used a gun once or twice and now is carrying a machine-gun down a tunnel into Mexico. I had to laugh when Alejandro brings Blunt's character a piece of paper at the end to sign to approve of what happened. Sure, sure, that's how it works, there is some piece of paper that CIA or special ops carries around and so long as it is signed, then everything is fine, and how convenient to create an ethical dilemma for the character. The comparisons here to Michael Mann are comedic -- this film is not worthy of the dirty toilet paper used on the set of a film like Heat. There are too many cliches in this film to count -- the slightly overweight slap-happy military types. The older bravado US Marshall types who are OK with joking about drinking to make your hand steady. The older White man Washington insider serious types. The field agent with more of an ethical awareness type who is brought into a world of greater moral ambiguity. The classic American bar scene where you get a couple of beers and have a honky tonk dance but be careful not to get double-crossed rape by border control agent gone rogue who happens to look like a Hispanic version of Bruce Springsteen with his nose broken. And how tragic that those little plastic-y wrist bracelets that everyone wears for cancer awareness and such can now apparently tip us off to anyone with a heart of evil. Josh Brolin steals a lot here from Jesse "the Body" Ventura's work in Predator I. How about the scene where Alejandro carefully folds his white linen jacket to add some complexity to his character. I can just imagine the director asking the writer to fill out the character a bit more and the writer comes up with idea of having him fold his jacket. If you want to see a Michael Mann movie, see a Michael Mann movie. If you want to see a two-hour version of CSI Mexico, then you might enjoy this.

Nihilistic, postmodern, depressing art house thriller, similar in feel to Killing Them Softly. Don't expect Traffic, which has a more typical hollywood-ish narrative arc and ending. The movie brought up many difficult and thoughtful questions about our "drug war", but it showed so much ugliness. Don't watch it and expect to feel uplifted.

I was looking forward to seeing this, due to its high ratings by both critics and audience, despite it having a bad trailer. But all I can say after watching it, is "why?". The characters were more of just robots than fleshed out people with interesting backstories. The main character was a naive punching-bag, and might as well have been and audience member who also had no idea what was going on. I might have cared about the story or the tension more if I cared in the slightest for any of the characters. The one character that was more than a guy who "does this" or is "Mr. I'm Mysterious", was Kate's friend who was at least funny and cared about her. To add on to that, there was never a moment where something went wrong. Everything went way too well through the entire movie. Not a single character offed, no unexpected mistakes made by the police, no plot-twists (if it can even be said to have one in the first place).The "plot" follows an officer who decides to help out some people catch this cartel guy who is bombing places. She is left in the dark about everything, which could have been good if we actually knew anything. After all the shooting and proving that she doesn't know what she's doing in this corrupt place, it becomes a revenge story for the last fifth of the movie. After the "Revenge Guy" unsurprisingly kills off the "Cartel Guy"s family, the movie ends with solidifying how much of an ass all the other characters are to Kate and showing that she will just willingly take everything up the ass, like the rest of the film. No development, it didn't even feel like something changed by the end of the film, nothing felt different.All I have to say about the good in this, is that the acting was good for what they had, the choice of audio was great, and they didn't rely on flashy action scenes when there was action. Maybe most people could self-insert themselves as Kate because the shock factor of having decapitated people and dead children did them in, but it's not that shocking. I saw this and thought, "Ok, just another day of brutal criminal activity in Mexico". It's not that different to the stuff that drowns throughout the news every day. This movie is relying too much on us for a reaction.Overall, the characters are boring, the story is left a mystery as to what the point is, the acting is good but what it was used for was not, the effects and audio were great, and the mexican kid at the end was neither sad nor completely oblivious to the fact that his father is dead, which leaves the scene pretty pointless. If the point of this film was to show how big of a problem the cartel is, the entire story should have been surrounding how much Kate was against it and not waver from that. But in the end, she's just a wuss who just accepts the shit and doesn't really make the people watching it think that it is more than just another crime film.
Some nice visuals but i just dont get the hype - clearly not my type of film!

Starting with a scene that even D.I.Y S.O.S would not want to fix this unexpected Gem kicks off to down the dark path on the war against drugs.When F.B.I Agent Kate Macy (Emily Blunt) is given the opportunity to be part of a elite task force that includes team leader Matt (Josh Brolin) and the mysterious Alajandro (Benicio Del Toro) to bring down the drug cartels she has to deal with what's the law and what needed to be done to win the never ending fight against drugs and as things carry on the question of what side Alejandro is really starts to show the deeper they go.Director Denis Villeneuve does a cracking job of keeping the tension following the deeper it gets. the acting all round is superb especially De Toro and though some scenes do go very dark at times this is definitely one of the best films of the year and will surely be up fr a Oscar or two next year! ?????

Just one more dumb American who realizes what the stars and stripes really do to the rest of the world. (At least, though, it takes a critical view of the U.S.'s involvement in foreign affairs instead of just spewing more propaganda.)
This is a solid film but no the masterpiece the positive reviews would suggest. Good performances. Like the war on drugs, not a satisfying ending.

Denis Villeneuve has made two amazing films in the past few years. Prisoners and Enemy were both on my top ten list for both 2013 and 2014. Sicario, is another fantastic accomplishment from Mr. Villeneuve. Sicario looks beautiful on the big screen and has an amazing, Oscar-worthy performance from Benicio Del Toro. This film is intense, shocking, and unpredictable. I had no clue what was going to happen. Each scene has a sense of dread, which, in this case, is a good thing, because it added to the suspense. Sicario is also beautifully shot by Roger Deakins. Sicario was ALMOST a masterpiece. But, then there's that one itsy-bitsy little flaw that keeps it from reaching that kind of status. And that flaw is our main heroine. Now, Emily Blunt gives a terrific performance, but, the character is just very irritating. She is constantly questioning and not following orders and it just really doesn't work. You can't connect with her. But, other than that, I had no problems with this film. Sicario is one of the best films of the year. I can't wait to see what Denis Villeneuve does with the new Blade Runner film.Rating: A

Undoubtedly one of this year's best movies.Action packed, suspenseful, mindblowing thriller about the mexican drug cartels.Reminds me of traffic but takes it to the next level.Benicio Del Toro as Alejandro, an enigmatic figure who is the sicario of the title ( hitman), makes a hell of a come back in this movie...

Buttressed by competent performances all around, "Sicario" is most successful when it constructs tightly-wound action/suspense sequences and allows them to go their merry way.Where it falls short is in its didactic attempt to address Important Issues. In this it is much like director Denis Villeneuve's previous film "Prisoners", which presented the post-Iraq world with Dick Cheney's torture dilemma; namely, if faced with a "ticking clock" scenario, is it ethically permissible to use whatever means necessary (torture) to beat the clock (terrorist attack, but in "Prisoners", a hostage scenario)? We the viewers are led to believe that this is an impossible, "Sophie's Choice"-type decision. But this is a nonsensical dilemma, as it is founded on false premises, namely, that torture is a reliable method for gathering accurate, "actionable" information. Similarly, "Sicario" presents its audience with quite a predicament: either we act outside the law (violating Mexico's sovereignty, torturing prisoners, assassinating cartel members on behalf of other cartels, using CIA operatives in domestic operations, etc), or else the flow of drugs across America's southern border will be unhindered! Left unanswered (or unasked, really) is the rather pertinent question "Why would that be a bad thing, exactly?" If "Sicario" weren't attempting to apply "Zero Dark Thirty" [sic] reasoning to the contemporary Mexican Drug Wars, one wouldn't think twice about the omission. But alas it does, and one does. "Sicario" nails its action/thriller/suspense aspects, but it's not nearly thoughtful enough (in contrast to, say, Soderbergh's "Traffic") to get away with lecturing any viewer with a functioning cerebellum.

A great action Movie.Realistic, border life and current drug war played.Del Toro is totally believable as A Sicarioand I loved the Delta Force boys kicking ass!About time the Bad Guys got theres.Emily Blunt was the Whiny Homeland Security dopewell played by Ms. Blunt. A great movie to see.

Good cop, bad cop, that could resume the plot of this film, a little overrated I think.Benicio del Toro and Emily Blunt gave good performances. After "Edge of tomorrow" Emily Blunt is making more action roles, good for her.
Zeer sterke film met een schitterende manier van filmen, beelden weergeven en het meenemen van de kijker in het verhaal. Top 5 2015!

Told with true vision and stunning cinematography, Sicario is an excellent study in filmmaking techniques - though its characters aren't as deep as we need them to be to truly sympathize or like anyone.

Blend a bit of Traffic, Training Day and a pinch of Se7en and you're on your way to getting the vibe of this super-slick thriller.Roger Deakins' cinematography contrasts the scorched, barren landscape of the U.S./Mexico border and the shady, midnight dealings of the FBI to great effect. The atmosphere created continues to ride a murky grey line between the two worlds, highlighting the conflicting attitudes of the central characters portrayed by Blunt and Del Toro.The war on drugs theme gives you the sense of Soderbergh's Traffic, but the quandary suffered by central character Macy (Blunt) as she is thrust into the slimy world of Matt & Alejandro (Brolin and Del Toro) is very reminiscent of Training Day. There's the great acting of both those films, as well as the superb acting, but Sicario succeeds in having a female character that be considered both weak and strong.Early on Blunt is shown to be a women just getting by in a man's world - always one step behind, having to ask questions and not quite in a powerful enough position to do anything about it. I thought it an illusion of a strong female character; portrayed to be strong because she's holding a gun, cussing and smoking. However, as the gripping story powered on it became clear that her strength came from still fighting for her ideals against a brick wall of secrecy and dirty deals.Some of the set pieces are very taut and the whole piece is very well directed. However, I found a few times I predicted quite a few moments that were intended to be shocks. This should in no way take away from screenwriter Taylor Sheridan and director Denis Villeneuve, who have delivered a fine film, that kept my attention throughout, in an time where mediocrity is so easy. Benicio Del Toro hasn't been this good in years (with the exception of Che) and Blunt and co. add to the universally great performances.Well worth a watch. Four and a half *'s
Loved it. Would suggest it to more people
Best movie I've seen in years. Amazing

Well-structured story with great characters make this Incredible action-thriller a best watch. This film works brilliantly on the leading actor's standout performances. the music and sound design of the movie added to the much needed tension. it was powerful on screen.Director Denis Villenuve teams with cinematographer Roger Deakins to take advantage of the desert, the weather, the landscape, the terrain, and use them as silent supporting charactersEmily Blunt was amazing in her character as a good FBI agent so as Josh Brolin done good to his roale but the actor who stole the show in Sicario is Benicio del Toro whose character Alejandro, is a mystery that unravels slowly through the film, done both subtle and dramatic by Del Toro. Every time he was on the screen even when he did nothing he was doing something.Overall, a very entertaining drama/thriller, full of technical brilliance, and Definitely worth a watch.

Denis Villeneuve has followed up "Prisoners" and "Enemy" which were 2 high quality films in itself with this absolutely brilliant film which has to be his best so far. This film delves into the dark underworld of America's war against drugs specifically from the cartel angle. The cast is great as Kate (Emily Blunt) is enlisted to aid this war led by ego driven Matt (Josh Brolin) and ice cold mercenary Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro). The plot is unforgiving and may be hard for some to stomach but its such excellent filmmaking and worth watching over and over
Tight and tense from start to finish.
This is an amazing movie. So many great things to say about it. Acting, cinematography just outstanding in every way.

Definitely my favourite film of 2015 so far. Denis Villeneuve is fast becoming one of my favourite directors, and I think this is his best work yet. I don't really want to get too detailed about it because this is the sort of story that constantly unfolds and you have no fucking clue where it's going. What I will say is it doesn't mess around, it's as ruthless as its characters and there are some truly brutal moments in this that gave me such a warm feeling of satisfaction that films rarely give me these days. There are no "good" guys or "bad" guys, everyone operates within shades of grey with their own agendas and motivations, you know, like real life. There's no pandering to the audience, no cliches and no Hollywood ending. Basically everything I want from a film. Emily Blunt is great, but Benicio del Toro steals the show. He's excellent in every possible way, and he doesn't even have to try.
While Emily Blunt's character seemingly gets lost in the shuffle, this movie will keep you tense from the first frame to the last. It never lets up.

The horrors of the drug business are blindingly clear in this film. Centered on the border between El Paso, TX and Juarez, CH the drug business sucks in the rich, the poor, the poor that become rich and adds moral uncertainty to the roles of the FBI, DEA and any other person or agency sucked in by its vortex. Most conflicted is an FBI agent played by Emily Blunt who is allowed to join, what amounts to a paramilitary organization, because of her knowledge of some of the drug cartel's key players. It's a difficult role to play because anyone in it is going to be conflicted between FBI legalistic mind-set and the atrocities of the cartels. In a way, it's too bad (or done on purpose) that a female was given the role of the goody-two-shoes in the all-male (who looked like a Delta team) group of hunter-killers. Benicio Del Toro is just right as the team's 'consultant'. Josh Brolin comes off like the American tourist you don't want to see on vacation, but emerges as a guy who knows his deadly business. I think I held my breath for the entire last scene.

A tad 'slow' but gripping enough to keep you interested. I enjoyed it and I recommend it. There is some really good blocking in the movie where scenes appeared to be out of a play and the movement of characters and camera played a role in the experience and context of the film. Acting was spot on. All characters in the movie think and that was amazing. The context, thought and objective of each character was a joy to watch. It is a serious movie and should be watched with that intent.

First 'Prisoners' then 'Enemy' now this intense taunt thriller from Denis Villeneuve. Much like those two previous films, this film contains exquisite cinematography from the great Roger Deakins, along with outstanding performances from a great cast whilst attending to it's very thoughtful and intense story. I can't even go on to mention how much of a career high point this is for almost everyone involved. The characters played by Emily Blunt and Benicio del Toro are incredibly fascinating and compelling at the same time anyone in a minor role is memorable enough. With incredibly effective thrills, enduring tense character development added to that with such immersive substance, to go with how beautifully shot and neatly directed this film really is. Sicario is not a film not worth missing out on especially on the big screen, as is by far one of 2015's best, highly recommended.

'Sicario' Misses the Target'Sicario' is a U.S./Mexico border drama about...well...I'm not sure what it's about, and that's the main problem with the film. It lack coherence and focus. The film starts off centered on F.B.I. Agent Kate Macer and her desire for revenge. Then it becomes a film about the questionable morals of federal policing agencies on the border. Then it mutates into a revenge film about a completely different character. That might work if the plot was not so logically flawed. It might also work if we had more of a back-story on the characters. In one scene, Agent Macer takes home a Phoenix cop. It's clearly a set up, and we are expected to believe a trained F.B.I. agent would fall for such an obvious ploy. There is nothing to suggest that she is easily fooled or that the people behind it are that clever. Besides, the plan relies on coincidence and there is no guarantee that it would work. It is based on stereotypical notions of female weakness and illogic and clashes with the notion that Macer is a tough agent. If we knew she had made mistakes of judgement in the past, it might have been more credible. However, almost no backstory is provided for her character. Macer is a patsy, which is fine, but then why make her the main character? And if she is the main character, why move away from her entirely during a large portion of the film? It is because the film, for all its pretense at making a smart, complex drama is plot driven and the characters are secondary. Thus, the actions that the plot dictates don't make sense for who the characters are. Visually, the film looks flat. Certainly, part of that is because of the filming in low-light situations. I wonder if it is also because some of it was filmed in HD video, or was it? The music is good, meaning, I didn't notice it. What holds this film together at all is the acting. Brolin, Blunt and Del Toro are as good a trio of actors as you can find in film, and they deliver. Too bad none of them are let off the reins so we can appreciate their talents. Critics are fond of discussing the film they wanted to see and then slamming films for not satisfying their preconceptions. So, here it goes. The film needed to focus on either agent Macer or Alejandro (Del Toro) and complete their tale of revenge. Neither of these characters' actions are clever and in fact, they are quite predictable. Good thing the drug lords are easily duped and overpowered. Rating: Rent it.There is no reason to see this in the theater, except perhaps the beautiful overhead shots of the border between El Paso and Juarez. The film attempts to address large themes of betrayal, honor, corruption and revenged, but it misses the target. Peace,Tex Shelters

This was definitely not 93% and 8.1/10 in my book. I give it a 70/100 and no more. We've seen all of this before, so it is not fresh and/or new. Emily Blunt reminded me of Sansa Stark, always emotional and sad, which she does fine, but her performance did not stand out from what one would expect in this role. Del Toro and Brolin gave better performances but they had more interesting characters. The movie was "mumbly" as well. In real life, we do not enunciate every sentence to make sure it is spoken clearly and easily understood. So, in that way it is realistic, but you also may miss a few lines. BBC's Sherlock also does this to my annoyance. The pacing was agonizingly, glacially slow. If you take a five star movie and add 15 minutes of non-essential material, it will lose a star. They advertised it as a thriller, but it dragged so much I stopped caring what was going to happen to anyone, and was yawning way more than I wanted to. Like The Hobbit, it would have been much better if it was edited more tightly. What also was annoying was the film focussed so much on the Emily Blunt character, but the real story is about the Del Toro character, which made the storytelling uneven. I was disappointed and I do not see what the critics or the 28K users who really liked it see.

4.5/5 This was very near perfect for me. It's quite dark and realistic in ways most movies in this genre tend to avoid. Director Denis Villeneuve is quickly becoming Canada's David Fincher in some ways, or in other ways, a relative to the Coen Brothers. That all being said, this was my least favorite of Villeneuve's films so far that I've seen of 3 (this, Prisoners, and Enemy). Comparisons aside this was easily one of the years best films and Villeneuve may very well get his first oscar nomination for this one or at least some of the cast at hand here. Especially Emily Blunt who has never been better than she is here. The atmosphere and everything about this film was quite unpredictable and you really never know what is going to happen. There is shock value here and realism that may turn off some viewers but all in all it's an incredibly rewarding experience for film lovers. This is one not to be missed but also not one for the faint of heart.

Movies about the drug wars are becoming quite popular, what separates Sicario from some of the others is how well executed this film truly is. The performances are first-rate, as expected from this cast. Benicio Del Toro in particular is outstanding. The great set pieces do a good job in portraying the brutality and the horrors in the cartel world.

If Steven Soderbergh's "Traffic" (2000) narrate the illegal drug trade from multiple points of view, then Denis Villeneuve's "Sicario" deliver you to the frontline of the US-involved Mexican drug war - tensely, grippingly and violently. Arguably one of the year's best flicks - and of course, Benicio del Toro is a true "sicario".

Drug movies have always been films of real intrigue for me. I don't know why but I just really get fascinated by how a drug system works or just a character or organizations stuggle in the midst of that dangerous world. Sicario is a brutal no holds barred picture that tackles the drug cartel in mexico but looks even deeper into human psychology, motives and desires, and just shows a war on two fronts if you will. Emily Blunt, Benecio Del Toro and Josh Brolin lead in this impactful story directed by the man behind the Sinster prisoners flick Denis Villenueve.  Kate Macer is an Idealistic FBI Agent who is good at what she does. She is a woman agent in an intense and highly dangerous environment. She gets word that she will be placed on a special task force to find a drug kingpin who is elusive, and has been killing and selling drugs for the longest time. She meets Matt Garver and the mysterious Alejandro. As the film progresses and she goes into the field she witnesses that something fishy is going on and that the guys are going beyond the required jurisdiction.This was just Gritty real and straight up hardcore. It's a film that challenges morality and what could very well shake your moral code. Nice directing from denies villeneuve his style from prisoners carries over here. Sound editing was superb here veeeery real Emily Blunt did a really good job here. Kate represents hope and a very idealized kind of individual almost the ideal FBI agent. Only problem I had was with her character development I kinda wished she was a bit stronger of a female character I mean I was kinda hoping she was more like linda Hamilton here and I was hoping she could be more mentally tough because she got broken down on both fronts for a good chunk of the film and it kinda disappointed me a bit but not to much she still did a very good acting job here. Josh Brolin did a fine job but the real highlight even beyond blunt is Benecio Del Toro. By the end of the film I came to reeeeally love Benecio del toro's anti hero character alejandro. He lost so much and in such a brutal fashion. He almost is like mirror to kate as they seem to have once been the same kind of person despite working different professions at the time. Del toro portrays such a cold character who has thrown his own morality out the window and is honed in on achieving his goal. He is like a wolf with rabbies that just needs to be pointed in the right direction. Wonder who would win in a fight whitey bulger or alejandro?Despite the Emily blunt deal the writing was real neat it sort of a film that builds in excitement and intrigue. Lot of reaaly good shots cinematography wise. Great score too. Sicario is incredible...nothing else really needs to be said.. go see this when you can!

Considering the subject matter (a specialist drug-busting unit, murky operatives from the FBI and CIA along with gangland warlords) you could be forgiven for thinking you have seen it all before. Actually you probably have, just not done quite as well. Right from the opening scene when you find your heart beating to the same drum as the music score provides (the music is so atmospheric and original), this draws you in, clamps you in its jaws and only lets go with its closing titles. In fact there is nothing to criticise here at all. The casting and therefore the acting is superb. Direction by Denis Villeneuve (comparable to Kathryn Bigelow's style in The Hurt Locker) is needle-sharp. Scene after scene has you on the edge of your seat. Not a film for the squeamish, but still stylish and not unnecessarily gory, this is surely set to be one of the films of the year.

Sicario is a slow burning film that rewards the audience's patience with a whopper of a finish and a curt philosophical message that cuts to the core of this drug land thriller. There are no easy answers at the end of this film, only hard truths. On the one hand we want to combat cartel violence and curb the import of drugs into the country, but how do we maintain stability when socio-economic realities dictate that many will try to fill that void? When there are no perfect outcomes, we value order over chaos, and as long as there is a 20% drug usage rate among U.S. citizens there will always be a need for someone to maintain that order.

'Sicario' was a term used about the Zealots in Jerusalem who would attack the Romans who entered the homeland. This is director Denis Villeneuve's 3rd American/English (Prisoners, Enemy) film since his film and one of my personal favorites of all time 'Incendies' received a Best Foreign Language Film nod back in 2010. He doesn't shy away from showing the gruesomeness that result from real issues (here drug trade/war). His films such as this one are heavy to take in, doesn't make light of human life and its cost. Director Denis Velleneuve brings us his latest thriller with the new film Sicario, an extremely well made film that boasts a great story with even greater performances. The last time we saw Vellenueve have a major release was in 2012?s Prisoners which took us to new depths of a kidnapping investigation and here he does it again with a very layered look at the cartels in Mexico. There are a lot of things that make this movie work but here there is a tag team of greatness between the writer Taylor Sheridan and Denis Vellenueve. Sheridan's writing here is beyond superb as we follow FBI agent Kate Macer who is asked to join a task force that delves deep in Juarez, Mexico as they attempt to take down a major cartel. However not everything is as it seems when a mysterious member of the team, named Alejandro, has an unusual influence over the investigation and Macer dives deeper and deeper into this world. This story has very deep layers of mystery and intrigue that dive into the very foundation of Macer and Alejandro and you just can't help but get caught up in how complex and meaningful these character's actions are and the dialogue actually serves a purpose rather than just having characters spout of lines of random dialogue. Vellenueve's direction of this film takes center stage and takes this fantastic script and shows us how violent these cartels are as well as how intimate these characters can be when dealing with these horrific realities. There is a sense of suspense that never falters and makes the more intense scenes more exciting as well as powerful. His eye for the sense of setting here is even more impressive with each scene being filled with the perfect amount of atmosphere that really makes us feel as if we are in Juarez while these events are taking place. The cast here is absolutely phenomenal with Emily Blunt as Kate Macer. Her delivery in this movie is nothing short of masterful and as the film progresses we get invested in her and we truly learn to understand her. We also get to see Josh Brolin deliver as the team coordinator and Victor Garber does great as Macer's boss at the FBI. However the real standout here is Benicio Del Toro as Alejandro. Del Toro gives one of his best performances to date here as his screen presence just makes scenes both suspenseful and exciting. His portrayal as Alejandro is so complex and deep that we hang on to every action he makes as well as every word he utters. Simply, Del Toro steals the show. While all these things are beyond great there is an issue that holds back the film and that is in the pacing. Some of these scenes really drag at times and the plot becomes a bit convoluted at times/ There are some points that could have been shorter or cut all together, but as it is Sicario is still a phenomenal film. This movie tells a truly deep story that is filled to the brim with realism as well as great character moments where we identify with nearly everyone in this film. Sheridan's script is amazing and Vellenueve's eye for filmmaking is second to none with this movie. I highly recommend this film, there are some pacing issues but they are made up for with the great cast and great characters. Sicario is simply a movie you have to see.

In Hollywood's Mexican drug war answer to the Steven Spielberg war epic Munich, the chance to castigate evildoers responsible for unspeakable atrocities yields for its idealistic main character an opaque path paved with deception, chaos and disregard for protocol. Emily Blunt is devastatingly magnificent as incorruptible, perhaps quixotic FBI agent Kate Macy. Not even a best actress Oscar nod would do her tortured performance justice. Take your opinion of her previous best work and multiply that by a million. Blunt scores with vulnerability in a harrowing, soul-crushing and impossible situation. However, even the esteemed actress cannot outshine a riveting, distressing turn by Benicio Del Toro. The truth of his character unravels inch by inch until the climax when he is terrifyingly naked with nothing else to lose. If he does not at least garner a best supporting actor nomination, you should boycott the Academy Awards. Josh Brolin also merits a mention for some superb acting. The gore is grotesque and the depiction of extremist cartel violence vomit inducing. If you want a feel good fall story, stay the bleep away from this film, which packs gut punch after gut punch with no apologies. Sicario leaves a haunting aftertaste that may linger forever.
This is an excellent film! Villeneuve direction is spot on, and the performances are killer, especially Del Toro. I was tense throughout the whole film Definitely recommended!

Killing audiences like its Spanish namesake, tightly coiled thriller Sicario might be topical by proxy but boasts a white hot Who-Done-What at its red hot center. If Master of Suspense Alfred Hitchcock made a Mexican terrorism actioner, it would look a lot like this. Call it Crosstown Traffic, Steven Soderbergh's already timely drug drama made even timelier by an escalating narcotics war down south and framed with direction that's every bit as knowing and edgy. Though the set pieces stop your heart, your mind can't help but keep going at a feverish pace, always on the lookout for the next double cross or stray bullet. It constricts you from the get-go for a long con but Sicario's serpentine scheme never disappoints. In this R-rated thriller from director, an idealistic FBI agent (Blunt) gets enlisted by an elected government task force to aid in the escalating war against drugs along the U.S. and Mexico borders. Through the eyes of the sometimes naive but rarely helpless agent Kate (an ace and award-worthy performance by Emily Blunt), Taylor Sheridan's script pits filmgoers in the midst of a deadly war that oftentimes seems pointless but the drive of the characters keeps you fully bullet-proof vested. Josh Brolin and Benicio del Toro likewise give powerhouse performances, though the latter is inarguably the showier of the two. Denis Villenueve's taut atmospheric direction takes center stage, however. The Prisoners' helmer makes a Hitchcockian thriller without a Hitch. It's his own baby, killer turns and all. Bottom line: Wonder Drug

There is no clear resolution (which develops the meaning, but not the story), and many motives are unclear.This isn't the movie to watch with your friends, and it's not the most entertaining of movies. Instead, you get a depressing movie about things happening today. It was well-directed and well-acted, but the story just didn't live up to the rest of the movie.

Well done but came away disappointed. Mostly in the way emily Blunt's character was written. Most of the time she stood by watching perplexed. At the end I'm not sure where her character was headed-what arc did she have.? I would have much preferred the movie without her character.

Gripping. Exposes a world of poverty, violence, misdirection, hate and inhumanity. In the corners is family and the desire to do good, to make a difference. There is no resolution here. Blunt and del Toro are amazingly present and believable.

I turn on my TV this morning to a generic horror film shot on a handicam. The camera's shaky and makes no sense, and is really boring and lacks any visual motivation. Sicario is a welcome reminder of how great a film you can make with just putting the camera down and setting it up to move in motivated directions to capture tension and drama. Also great performances from everybody, especially Benicio Del Toro, doesn't hurt. Looks like Oscar season is off to a pretty great start.

Sicario is a great example of what a modern thriller should be. Amazing direction, screenplay and cinematography make the audience feel like they're there with the characters not to mention the low budget making the film more grounded. Every single performance was solid, but Benicio del Toro, Emily Blunt and Josh Brolin all did outstanding work. Only minus is the fact that the story doesn't move as forward as I would have liked to. Still though, this is oneof the greatest movies of the year.

I understand the praise this film has received up to a point. It's a very well-made and well-acted film, stylish and suspenseful and timely in a way that would suggest the possibility of valid insights into the dealings of the cartels in Mexico - the fact that it fails to deliver on that final point is the issue here.I don't have a problem with the construction of this film at all; the substance is what's objectionable, a fundamentally misguided defense of unethical, illegal, and hyper-masculine actions in dealing with the cartels while simultaneously ignoring the larger context that would nullify this defense entirely. American domestic policy regarding the prohibition of drugs contributes significantly to the prevalence and pervasiveness of these cartels, creating an illegal system that allows these drug networks to thrive. The fact that the film condescends to those who it would perceive as being "weak" for not wanting to engage in the actions it portrays as necessary evils is baffling and supremely ignorant.America is not the hero this film makes it out to be, one willing to get down and dirty in order to solve problems that idealists like Blunt's character can't handle (the fact that they've provided the moralistic, "weak" role the the film's only woman is a disappointingly sexist misstep); we are actively contributing to the problems that plague Mexican citizens, and people like Brolin's despicable character are not "strong" realists for engaging in their morally dubious actions while ignoring the larger picture. This fundamental problem seriously hinders what could've been an excellent political thriller, and its portrayal of torture as well as an indefensible rape joke thrown in among this misguided narrative only contributes to the bad aftertaste it all leaves in your mouth.Villeneuve seems to have a serious conservative streak in him (Prisoners had similar issues with attempting to justify illegal, despicable violence by simply pointing to the existence of evil), and its holding him back from creating something truly great. His technical prowess is undeniable; if only his ideology wasn't so retrograde.
Absolute quality from start to finsh.

Imagine you're in a tunnel and you start to see a glimmer of light towards the end. You labor for hours, walking an incalculable distance. And by the time you've reached the light, you realize it's a fa�ade to bring you back to the beginning of the tunnel. That is "Sicario".

Sicario - relevant and really gripping - emotionally harrowing whilst still being a 15 certificate, - great performances from the leads - cinematography and soundtrack are first-rate and as much an integral part of the film as the plot, which is saying something - it's an action drama that informs and challenges and never drops into violence as entertainment. It loses half a star for a couple of minor plot twists that felt contrived, but I am being picky. I would love anyone who ever takes cocaine as a recreational drug to see this film, and reflect.

Emily Blunt packed a huge punch, and Del Toro was amazing, with great support from Brolin. The characterization alone said a lot about the story, without saying anything at all. The sound and score was the next most amazing part of this film. It hit you at weird moments, and only seemed to augment the craziness of the situation, or morbid sensation you already had from the visual the director presented to you. Overall though, I am going to have to go back, and watch it again. I was hoping for something a bit more fresh to it(with its 93% rating... and I'd expected a bit of the "weird" from Villeneuve) and didn't have that feeling while I watched it. It seemed as though we just floated along, unsure what was going on, just like Blunts character(but again, I will definitely give this film another watch).But for everything said; -acting was superb(A+)-cinematography(B+)-production design(A)-story(B)

Sicario is a grim tale of crime and murder that pulls no punches in the violence department and is bar none the most beautiful, dark-themed movie I've ever seen courtesy of the brilliant cinematographer, Roger Deakins. The acting is incredible with stellar work from Josh Brolin and powerful performances from Emily Blunt and Benicio Del Toro; the latter completely stealing the movie with his uncertain alliances and solemn demeanor. The film is helmed by mastermind director, Denis Villeneuve who gets right to the grit in the opening scene and sets the tone early that this is going to be a bumpy ride and it's beyond impressive. However, after the spellbinding first act that was non-stop tension, I found the story slowed way down and took a little bit too long to pick up again as what was happening in between wasn't all that interesting. I also take issue with the eventual reveal about Blunt's character who you realize didn't matter at all in the grand scheme of the plot and she's actually absent for most of the climax; which annoyed me as she was being built-up so well to be an amazing character. The climax is insanely well-done though beginning with a Zero Dark Thirty-esque night-vision raid that keeps escalating until Del Toro's character, Alejandro takes matters into his own hands and does what it takes to bring down the villains. I'm a bit mixed on the impact of the film because I believe the story wasn't all that remarkable, but it's undeniable that I was riveted through most of it, Roger Deakins can make the ugliest of scenes gorgeous, and the performances, especially from Del Toro, will keep you engaged until it's final moment.

Sicario: 9.5/10This is the best movie to come out of Hollywood in 2015. It's my favourite movie to come out of Hollywood this year, at least.It's the story of an idealistic FBI Agent Kate Macer (the gorgeous and brilliant Emily Blunt) getting sucked into a dangerous, drug cartel-busting assignment with Matt Graver (Josh Brolin, in what could be one of his career's finest performances) and the ice-cold man-with-a-death-stare Alejandro Gillick (the ever efficient Benicio Del Toro). And it begins on an ominous note, with the message: "Sicario is a word for zealots in ancient Jerusalem, who hunted down and killed Roman invaders. In Mexico, Sicario means hitman."Giving away any more of the story is a disservice, because Sicario is a film that must be experienced. This is one of those non-sci-fi non-gimmicky films that ACTUALLY deserves to be screened in an IMAX theatre, so you can lose yourself in Roger Deakins' jaw-dropping, trance-inducing cinematography. That, coupled with the chilling, yet calming score of Johann Johannsson, makes this one of the finest cinematographer-music director collaborations, to help with Denis Villeneuve's brilliant direction.It isn't flawless though. Sicario comes with a not-so-tight script that takes away from the experience. Denis Villeneuve is the man who's given us Incendies, Enemy, Prisoners, Polytechnique and the like. Compared to those, this feels like he's played a little safe with the script. The screenplay slows down in the middle, especially to the point of the intermission. But his direction still makes this an edge-of-the-seat experience. It makes all the slowness feel like a live, ticking bomb.I also had a problem with Emily Blunt's character, Kate Macer. Throughout the movie I was expecting her to do things differently, and most of the times I was left disappointed. I wondered, 'why isn't she as strong as she can be? Why is Emily Blunt playing such a weak character?' But then, with wisdom from my friend Achyuth Sankar, I realised that Kate Macer is actually a reflection of the human race - given the same circumstances, we would react exactly the same way. And that is what pissed me off more than anything else - that in life, when you're powerless, you truly ARE powerless and there's nothing you can do.Talking about the human race, there is someone who's not-so-human in our midst. How does Benicio Del Toro do it? How does this man straddle between English and Spanish with so much ease? How does he manage to be so ice-cold, almost Anton Chigurh-like, and yet make you root for him in a weird way? He has all the best lines in the film, especially these:"Nothing will make sense to your American ears, and you will doubt everything that we do, but in the end you will understand.""Finding this man is like finding a vaccine."Moving on to the third important cog in this wheel, Josh Brolin. Right from turning up in the meeting room in flip flops to his wisecracks and quips at Emily Blunt, Brolin has had a ball of a time, and this might be one of his best performances.Hey, you know what HBO? Cast Josh Brolin and Benicio Del Toro in a season of True Detective. Set it in the heart of Mexico, preferably Juarez. And get Cary Fukunaga to direct, with Roger Deakins as the cinematographer. OH YEAH.All I'd like to say in the end is, well done Denis Villeneuve, Roger Deakins, Johann Johannsson, Emily Blunt, Benicio Del Toro and Josh Brolin.Go and watch Sicario people. You should not miss this one in the theatres.
Great film about our failed drug war. Academy award nominations for best actor Benito Del Toro, best musical score, best original screenplay, and maybe best picture.

Get ready for nomination and awards galore for Sicario, it deserves every bit of success it's gonna receive.

While it's not quite as good or original as some of the early buzz might have you believe, there's still a lot to like in Sicario, director Denis Villeneuve's followup to his (criminally underrated) 2013 thriller Prisoners. Though treading fairly familiar narrative ground, Villeneuve knows how to stage a suspense sequence as well as anyone, with two scenes in particular here ranking as among the tensest I've seen all year. Throw in a trio of great lead performances from Emily Blunt, Josh Brolin, and Benicio Del Toro, a pulsating score from J�hann J�hannsson, and cinematography from the ever-reliable Roger Deakins, and you've got a film that more than warrants two hours of your time.

Sicario is probably one of the best films I've seen this year. Without giving away too much (it's best to go in as blind as the protagonist Emily Blunt) it is one crazy ride. Dark, brooding and oppressive sums up Sicario, The movie starts with a FBI raid on a suspected drug Cartel's home and the discovery of what actually the house contains. It then moves along into darker country as it shows the other end of the law enforcement practiced by those with little morals to get the job done. Emily Blunt's character (Kate Macer) spends most of the movie looking appalled at the lengths Matt Graver (Josh Brolin) and Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro) go to take down the Cartel and anyone involved with them. There is a point when Blunt's character asks 'What is our mission?' To which Brolin replies 'To dramatically over react'. Which gives you a idea where this is going to lead. The end builds up to a predictably conclusion of whether Alejandro (Del Toro) will get revenge on the Cartel's leader.

An extremely grim thriller that successfully blends some fairly conventional plot developments with some genuinely unexpected elements. It's both satisfying as a genre film and quite unnerving. In the film's opening, a title card explains "In Mexico, Sicario means hit-man", immediately setting a tense tone throughout the film. French-Canadian director Denis Villeneuve (Prisoners, Enemy), working from a dark and dangerous script by Taylor Sheridan, steps into the haunting world of America's war on drugs. The subject matter and this story in particular could have easily turned into a generic, fast-paced and dumbed down Hollywood production, but Villeneuve's execution makes the film stand tall as an exhilarating crime thriller. The film is set on either side of the U.S. - Mexico border, but in this narrative, the border is more conceptual than anything. It is a place of anxiety, violence and moral compass.Kate Macer (Emily Blunt) is an FBI agent assigned to tracking down kidnapping victims of Mexican drug cartels in the American Southwest. Early on, it is suggested that she volunteer - she can't be officially assigned- for an interagency joint task force. She joins in hopes of making a bigger difference and quickly finds out nothing is as she was told it would be. Matt Graver (Josh Brolin) is a government agent of shadowy provenance, officially an "advisor," yet as a playful provocateur he seems to have vast resources at his disposal and free rein in the field. Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro) is introduced first by Graver as a "bird dog" but reveals himself to be much more than that. Moving freely back and forth between the U.S. and Mexico, the trio are trying to disrupt the flow of money and drugs in hopes of causing higher-ups in the Mexican cartel to make a mistake and reveal themselves.Villeneuve, who stepped into similar moralities in Prisoners, maintains a masterful balance between the brutal and violent world of the story and deeper ethical ambiguity. The film is shot once again by the legendary cinematographer Roger Deakins (who worked with Villeneuve on Prisoners), and it is absolutely wonderful. The shots are steady and wide with beautiful colour pallets. It gives the film a fantastic sense of the world we are witnessing on the screen, the vicious and cruel world where morality seems to be lost forever. A haunting score by Johann Johannsson heightens the film's ominous mood and gives it a personality. This is the work of someone who has an opinion on this subject, and truly believes in his film which recalls Michael Mann's Heat and Steven Soderberg's Traffic. The pacing is slow and steady but the tension is endless with a smart script that manages to be simple enough to follow and plenty of surprises along the way. The film portrays the so-called war on drugs not as a battle to be won but as an existential minefield, something that changes people with the best of intentions and turns them into monsters. This is both a nail-biting action thriller and a social commentary on a world in which right or wrong have become essentially irrelevant.The acting is superb across the board with Emily Blunt showcasing one of her best performances to-date. Her character is reactive and underwritten in some aspects, but her performance makes up for this problem. Her character is both emotionally affecting and athletically adept, ultimately becoming the movie's heart and soul in a story where having a moral conscious seems irrelevant. She manages to create some of the film's highlights including the nail-biting opening sequence and a slam-bang action highpoint in her apartment. Benicio Del Toro is also fantastic as the mysterious Alejandro, who guides the team in their operations. His character is cold and brutal, making some of the tense moments even more watchable. Their chemistry is where this story truly shines because morally, they are polar opposites but they are circumstantially linked to the same world of crime and violence. Among the many things discussed in Sicario is the cyclical nature of violence and how feelings of hope and logic factor into its endless turmoil for better or worse. Alejandro is light years away from the idealism that Kate exhibits and how they try to unravel one another is an absolute joy to watch.Sicario manages to do pretty much everything it sets up and rarely misses a step. This is a slow but tense thriller full of intriguing characters and scenes that would be remembered for a long time. The top-notch acting, a mesmerizing score and camera work that is surely among the year's very best, all make this a must-see for film lovers. The subject matter is also timely and relevant as an increasing number of Americans have come to realize that the war on drugs has corrupted everyone involved. The film's bleak and nihilistic ending offers no hope that it can ever be won, or that the corruption won't continue to win over. When Kate argues that the strike team's actions are legally out of bounds, a superior sets her straight: "The boundaries have been moved," he says. And will clearly continue to be.

Cops and cartels, midnight raids and public shootouts, blood vendettas and hidden agendas, and a whole lot of dead bodies literally walled up in a house of horrors. If you told me all of this sounds like it belongs in a trashy detective novel, I'd probably agree. If told me it all sounds like it belongs in a trashy movie I'd say, "Hold the phone! Who says the movie has to be trashy?"And of course, it isn't. French-Canadian director Denis Villeneuve insinuates and executes all of these familiar genre tropes with hitman-like precision in Sicario, delivering one of the most cringe-inducing, butt-clenching, downright excruciating films of the year... And I mean every one of those in the best possible way.Working from a twisty screenplay by actor-turned-writer Taylor Sheridan (Sons of Anarchy), Villeneuve has crafted an excellent thriller that's every bit as refined (if not more so) as the glossy biopics and period pieces that angle for adult dollars at the multiplex every fall. Along with 2012's Prisoners and last year's Enemy, Sicario further embosses his reputation as a filmmaker capable of elevating even the pulpiest story material with his surgical attention to form and construct.Emily Blunt headlines as Kate Macer, a straight-laced federal agent caught in a crooked system. Frustrated that her Sisyphean campaign against the drug trade is going nowhere, she eagerly volunteers for a special task force designated to take the fight to the cartels.Now under the direction of an unnervingly casual Dept. of Defense adviser (Josh Brolin) and his mysterious partner (Benicio Del Toro, quietly intense as ever), Kate can only hold on for dear life as she's thrust onto a whole new battlefield in the war on drugs; One made up of gargantuan, writhing border towns and dark, winding tunnels, where her enemies are hiding in plain sight.An apt casting call for this highly physical role, Blunt exudes just as strong an action-movie presence as her Full Metal Bitch from Edge of Tomorrow. It's an unfortunate shortcoming that she's written less as an active participant in the story than as an audience surrogate, mostly watching it unfold while dodging bullets.We are meant to be as nervous and appalled as she is by the unethical back channels and by the blind eyes of her superiors. "You are acting within bounds," insists her FBI boss (Victor Garber). "The boundary has been moved." But as Sicario spirals towards its bloody climax, it seems more and more that the boundary has been completely erased, leaving us to contemplate who are more monstrous; The traffickers or the feds?Villeneuve is a master of mood, with a penchant for suspense that rivals Hitchcock. His timing of the film's first jump scare instills the viewer with an enduring dread of what sudden horror will startle us next; A dread which allows him to stretch the tension tighter than a drum for prolonged (practically agonizing) periods of time.Master cinematographer Roger Deakins (probably en route to Oscar nomination #13) composes every frame with grace and grit. His camera shifts elegantly between POV to objective angles, sometimes within the same shot. When coupled with the atmosphere of Tim Ozanich's sound design - which superbly integrates J�hann J�hannsson's stealthily scary music - these images put the viewer square in the danger zone with the embattled narcs. You don't merely feel that they are unsafe. You feel unsafe.It's more than enough to keep us perpetually rapt, even when the script goes sadistically dark. It's true that the morbidities of Sicario may well cross the line for what general audiences would consider "prestige drama", but a director of Villeneuve's caliber proves that great storytelling knows no genre. The boundary has been moved.***1/2 out of ****

The thriller film Sicario, by Dennis Villenueve, had me at the edge of my seat in the opening act. Emily Blunt, who is a lead FBI agent, of the kid-nap response team in Arizona, has discovered an unusual case of kid-naps. Emily is not entirely sure what is going on after a gross, but sickening discovery of dead bodies found in the walls of an Arizona home. With confusion and anger, after a bomb explosion that lead to two agents dead, left Emily anxious for answers on who was responsible for so many murders. Josh Brolin, a drug enforcement chief recruits Emily for her outstanding experience in the field. She is misled and confused on what her actual position is with the narcotics team. She elaborates that she is a specialty in the field of abduction. But, with her shaky vibe of the recent discovery of over 20 dead bodies; she is determined to catch those responsible of those who caused the explosion and the death of two fellow co-workers. She meets with Benicio Del Toro, on a private jet provided by the agency, just some of the perks for working with the big guys. But, Benicio remains mysterious throughout the film. She is misled by thinking she is working on a case in El Paso, Texas. When on the jet, she is somewhat informed that she is actually going to work on a case in Juarez, Mexico. Emily is still confused on the purpose of her position on the case. Josh Brolin, reveals the necessity of Emily working with the drug enforcement team up until the near end of the film. Brolin and Del Toro are two sneaky individuals that show no remorse on their actual intensions. Brolin and Del Toro are two individuals that play the game their way. Jurisdiction is not a word in their vocabulary. The title of the film Sicario, means hitman in Mexico. It was difficult to make some connection with the title of the film, throughout the movie, up until the end of the film. Sicario had me wondering before the ending, on why the film was named Sicario. I love the structure of the film and the way it had me wondering throughout the film. Towards the end it was still unclear on what was behind Brolin's motive. Del Toro was later revealed as a character that explained the title of the film. Brolin was still a mysterious shot caller that never actually revealed himself and the reason for why he was willing to work with Del Toro. It would be nice if there was some clarity on who Brolin really is. I can say, the story line was clear and interesting. Emily's performance was utterly compelling; she played a victim in some sense, but was a scared agent overall. There is no error in the story line, but this film had a trailer focused on action. Sicario, was a film more on the suspenseful side with little action to relate to its trailer.

Sicario is a Spanish term for hitman. This was introduced to the audience at the beginning of the movie. The movie focuses on Kate, an FBI agent who volunteered herself to capture the people in charge of operating drug cartels in Mexico. As they arrived in El Juarez, Mexico, the agents faced reality of how drug traffickers took over the land. Dead bodies were hung by rope over a bridge and gangsters drove through the streets to patrol the area. The agents knew that they needed to act quickly in order to clean up the mess.  "Sicario" was a suspenseful movie where the director, Denis Villeneuve, did a wonderful job on tackling the relationship between the movie and reality. Portrayed by actress Emily Blunt, Kate joined a mission without knowledge of what was going on around her. She came from a background where she learned to be on top of every mission and knew exactly what happened in her surroundings. However, Kate struggled to follow the assignments given to her because she was not aware of the specifications of her duty and new endeavors to overcome. Higher authorities were often bribed to run deliveries, protect dealers, and hint information to cartel members. Denis Villeneuve attempted to portray accurate the views on state police members. When a dealer went through the tunnel and needed a ride, a state policeman was usually the one that gave him a ride. The corrupted officials often gave cartel members information on what was going on around the states. If any whistleblowers were to be caught, the cartel members would send people after their family.  This movie brought out the best in all the actors and actresses. From an audience member's point of view, each cast member acted out their roles perfectly. Cast members were able to depict their characters' lives, allowing the audience to truly understand the lifestyle in the movie. In addition, the cinematography captured every aspect of El Juarez to the smallest details. I did have a critique about the movie. If there were to be a change in the movie, I would suggest to add or remove the bar scene. Kate and her friend, Reggie, ran into one of Reggie's ex-coworker at the bar, who happens to be a state policeman. Kate decided to casually date him. Unfortunately, he ended up working for the cartel in which he tried to kill her when she found out. What I did not like about this scene was how it was a coincident for both Kate and the officer to hook up, as he ended up being a corrupted officer. Realistically, a good friend would not intentionally introduce someone to an individual that would cause harm. If Reggie were to invite him out on a separate occasion, this would have been a better scene than just running into each other at a specific bar. Overall, "Sicario" was wonderfully directed; I was captivated throughout the whole movie. It was full of suspense and never had a dull moment. Denis Villeneuve invoked emotion with each scene and connected it with real life situations. This movie was an eye opener to the audience because most people never understood how corrupted the state officials can be. Working within a cartel will never end well; members will either shoot or get shot at. With a movie this realistic, people will now understand the war against drug cartels.

This is hands down the best movie of 2015 to-date. You want to see this in a theater, so go see it now. But it is not for the faint-of-heart ... I'd give it a hard-R. But it is a gripping account of the drug war that is going on with the Mexican cartel(s) with great performances from A & B list actors/actresses. One word: Wow.
Emily Blunt was exceptional, but I feel the movie was unintentionally moving away from climax. The movie itself was well done, but the content promised a lot and did not deliver.

Easily one of the most depressing movies I've ever seen, it still works as a thought provoking thriller, and boasts excellent performances by Emily Blunt, Benicio del Toro and Josh Brolin. Blunt and Del Toro have the most to work with though, and make the most of it. This movie keeps you invested in the story, but also leaves you in the dark about what's happening in a very good way. If you're thinking about going to see "Black Mass", I beg you to reconsider and take the road less taken. While "Black Mass" is fine and features a great performance by Depp, "Sicaro" is superior in EVERY way. Gorgeously shot be Deakins and superbly acted, especially by Blunt and del Toro, this is a remarkable film. Almost unbearably tense in places, it boasts a very smart script that has more to it than action set pieces. After "Enemy" and "Prisoners", and now "Sicario", Villeneuve is definitely emerging as a new, vibrant voice in cinema. See this movie.

Among Hollywood's better products. This is puzzling, unfinished and interesting. In its style, I was reminded of "The Quiet American". The quality of the production is very good. Blunt is neutral as the anglo, middle class, window-glass through which you glimpse the drug war. The film is not a star vehicle - the drug war is the focus. If you are interested in that topic, it could repay a second viewing.

Sicario ist ein Film der nur f�r bestimmte Gem�ter und echte Filmliebhaber gemacht worden ist. Den Denis Villeneuve bleib sich und seiner Filmstimmung treu. Genau wie seine zwei Vorg�ngerfilme Enemy und Prisoners ist auch hier die Stimmung d�ster. Hier w�rde es f�r mich auch den einzigen Kritikpunkt geben: 3 Filme, 3 Themen, aber immer die gleiche niederschmetternde Stimmung, da fehlt mir ein bisschen die Abwechslung. "Don't ever point a gun at me again".'Sicario' is a master-class in ramping up the tension. It's right up there with the best of them. Tense, twitchy scenes fit perfectly into the drug war story. Where something like 'Sabotage' failed (quite badly) 'Sicario' does it with ease. All film makers going for a similar plot with teh cartel, drugs DEA whatever link there is should look at this. Building the tension up, slowly twisting the screw and never really letting up completely - even when it comes to teh conclusion it still has you.As many adverts have stated 'Sicario' means hitman in Mexico. Meaning the real central character is 'Alejandro' (Benicio Del Toro) but it's lead through the eyes of 'Kate' (Emily Blunt). Displaying her skills in the opening segment (which already starts to raise things) she tackles what is meant to be a kidnap operation only to discover more and be inducted into a special operation to take out the head of the Mexican cartel - headed by 'Matt' (Josh Brolin). By the end it's hard to judge what is the right thing to do and who is doing it. It's intentionally murky with its perception of good - there's revenge, pride and manipulation at every turn.It's clich�d but the audience and 'Kate' know as much as each other. Her reaction to things synced pretty well with me, she may be part of the FBI but this is new territory for her. It's never clear what they're doing until it's already done. There's as much mystery about 'Matt' and his team as there is 'Alejandro' and his objectives. This could be tiresome and uninteresting but the intrigue and rising tension kept me glued to the film.There's also what has to be the best use of night vision iv'e ever scene and one of if not the most tense thing Iv'e ever seen on screen. Watch out for that because it blows 'Zero Dark Thirty' out of the water. Despite all the sides involved, drug empires and secret government ops there isn't all that much action and it's all teh better for it. If you're expecting something with explosive set pieces you won't get them here. It's rather, littered with more intricate constructed moments.Upping his game from 'Prisoners' 'Denis Villeneuve' has mastered his art. Where teh previous had some problems 'Sicario' never ever lets up the feeling of un-ease. Managing thanks to some clever camera work keep at a level even when there's nothing happening. 'Emily Blunt', 'Benicio Del Toro' and 'Josh Brolin' are all in excellent form here. Intense, startling and unflinchingly committed to being fair on all fronts, 'Sicario' is that rare thriller - very smart and very very good.
I found the movie slow moving and predictable but to reach their own. No a bad movie and I'm a BIG Benicio fan but this movie just didn't do it for me.

Sicario is without doubt the best film of the year beating the likes of Mad Max: Fury Road, Kingsman and Legend, and it ranks as one of my favourite films ever made. Emily Blunt and Josh Brolin give terrific performances with Blunt's character being the rookie by the book officer who's in way over her head and Blunt gives us something great to watch. The same can be said for Brolin's hard edged but very laid back character, he too clocks in a wonderful performance. But perhaps the best is Benicio Del Toro who is absolutely incredible, stealing the scene everytime he appears, his character is quiet but harbours something dark and he only reveals his true self until the end in what is one of the most intense shootout in film. The music is loud and brazen and it conveys horror whenever played, it never feels out of place and it fits the subject matter perfectly. And Roger Deakin's cinematography is outstanding, when it's dark it's dark, you can't see the character's faces and even that gives it such a realistic and gritty feel, it's Oscar worthy. Dennis Villeneuve has given us a perfect film, a film that doesn't glamourise or make the war on drugs seem cool, instead, he's offered us the most realistic take on it since Traffic. Everything is Oscar worthy and it's sure to be the most nominated movie this year. Sicario is just mesmerising, I love this film and I can't wait to watch it again.
