I believe this is one of the first movies I have seen where the trailers lead you to believe 'action' movie, but instead, Sicario stands out as one of the best ghost stories of the year.The mood. The setting. The characters. The score. The cinematography. The direction. The dialogue. Everything about it comes together as more of a horror story than any action movie ever could. In fact, everything is so tightly wound in every scene, sitting through this for two hours felt like walking through a haunted house.The entire premise for director Denis Villeneuve, who directed Prison Break and Enemy...both excellent, is to place the audience in the shoes of Emily Blunt's Kate. Just like her, you as a viewer are completely unaware of what is going on. Who do you trust? Who's the bad guy? It's not only until the final stretch do you really get an idea, not even the whole truth, of what her purpose for being there is. It's her most stoic performance yet and thrown up with the best of hers like Edge of Tomorrow.Benicio Del Toro may steal the show, however. His brooding silence. His efficiency at his job. His delivery of both dialogue and mannerisms. He is the ghost you fear. The way he and Josh Brolin play off each other leads you to believe its a symbiotic relationship, but quite frankly, there is a point in the film where even Brolin's character says to follow Del Toro's lead without question. I mean...the movie's title is really about Del Toro's character anyway. Sicario = hitman. I've seen Brolin do some good acting before, but here he hammed up the stereotype of government lackey a bit too much with his snarky and loose attitude.As far as direction goes, the car chase through Juarez must go down as one of the best sequences of the year. What a brilliant idea to keep not only the pacing of the film consistent, but a chance to get a good drive by of what makes these cartel wars so violent. There's no lingering for too long for fear you might not make it out alive.Sicario stayed small in its scope by limiting everything to Arizona and the border around Juarez and El Paso. It was a great look at how things are handled (though to a certain elevated extent most likely) without having to see Washington DC or the higher powers. Del Toro and Blunt give masterful performances in one of the best ghost stories of the year.

Sicario is an OK gritty crime drama centered around the Mexican Drug War. The cinematography and editing are good, the score is tense and the actors do well. However, I was disappointed with how irrelevant Kate Macy (Emily Blunt), our heroine, turned out to be. I understand her role was to be the bewildered moral compass of the movie but ultimately, the point of the movie is morally ambiguous, and the mysterious Alejandro (Del Toro) proves to be a vastly more interesting character. Alejandro has a harrowing back story thus rendering Kate to be a bystander in the grand scheme of things; a pawn in the war almost. What the film does well is hold you captive in suspense and keep you haunted with some disturbing imagery. Overall, I'd say it's a less well-done Traffic, only Traffic had a sprawling scope while this movie's focus is kinda narrow. The action scenes were good though.
Everybody who uses illegal drugs should see this movie!

Sicario comes at a time filled with promising cinematic features and yet manages to keep its head well above water and then waver to the top as one of the definitive films of a rather uneventful year in film so far. To say the least, enough happens in the film's first tightly acted, edited, and directed 30 minutes to propel the intrigue of its premise and adrenaline of its execution throughout the film despite some uneven pacing. When Sicario succeeds, it succeeds at such a level that some of the shallow narrative flaws and minor issues can be pushed to the side. You can feel the intensity, emotion, and dedication emanating from each scene because it's very easy to tell that this is exactly the project that director Denis Villeneuve has been building towards. It is a story rooted deep within his own interests and heritage and a story of which he surely felt needed to be told, and he mostly succeeds in emulating his personal sense of urgency and importance unto the audience. The most fascinating part of Sicario is that it isn't too heavy-handed in its approach. It manages to entertain in balanced doses while still finding a way to pass along some vital social commentary that manages to sit uncomfortably with even those of which aren't personally familiar with the events and settings being depicted. I did take issue with certain aspects of the narrative, however, that I felt to be extraneous and perhaps even unnecessary, and to me these parts really got in the way of the otherwise smooth direction of the film. I can't mention these narrative aspects specifically, but it should be clear as a good deal of time is given for these detracting subplot elements to unfold in a way that really interfered with my ability to stay focused on the central plot. And to that end, Sicario doesn't really tell all that profound or unique of a story to begin with, but given the precise, calculated plotting, confident and bare-knuckle direction, and (of course) Roger Deakins' flawlessly detailed and complex cinematic abilities, it's easy to overlook this fact. The impeccable performances all around are worth mentioning just as well with a truly defining performance given by Benicio Del Toro who basically gave me the chills through his sheer confidence and obvious passion for the role. Overall, Sicario marks itself as a notable entryway into the award season for films this year given its highly admirable round of qualities. It isn't groundbreaking or really even that original but it is told in a way that certainly pins itself as one of the better movies of the year and, for many reasons, stands out as a rather memorable film. Much more than your average entertainment fare.
One of the best thrillers I've seen recently.

This was an OK movie, CERTAINLY not worth 4 or 5 stars. This is not an extraordinary movie, nor is it thought-provoking. Shallow characters, lack of suspense, fairly dry dialogue. This is not a movie that changes the way you you think about the war on drugs. At least not anyone who is remotely aware. The acting was fine and good, the plot fine and good, the movie fine and good. But I can't imagine paying to watch this now that I have seen it. It was just disappointing, particularly after all the rave reviews. IAs it is, don't feel any better for having spent two hours of my time watching this movie.

Sicario is so so close to being a classic and it still might be, but it falls just short at the end of becoming something more. This film is an uncompromising look, generally through the eyes of an idealistic FBI agent played brilliantly by Emily Blunt, at the war on drug lords in and around Mexico and the border with the US. Blunt and Del Toro are incredible, the story is tense throughout with more than one memorable scene to think back on. Beautifully shot by Villeneuve, Sicario is a movie that makes you ask yourself how far is too far, and even if you cross that line, will it matter.
Stunning, gorgeous use of sound instead of music

With the plethora of popular fiction devoted to the doomed drug war, it's slightly hard to get excited about a movie retreading the same ground as Traffic or similar films in this genre. But Sicario is, for a lack of a better way to express this, pretty fucking great. The plot centers on a female FBI agent specializing in special tactical breach and clear missions who finds herself recruited by a shadowy team of DEA agents planning to go on the offensive against Mexican drug cartels across the border in Juarez. Emily Blunt subtly and emotionally plays this protagonist as she finds herself in over her head and struggling to maintain her moral compass amid the carnage. Josh Brolin plays a slimy CIA agent so easily that perhaps we should worry about what he does with his time when he's not acting. But it is Benicio Del Toro who steals the show. His icy, murderous double assassin acts as a sword of vengeance and a warning about those who fight monsters. Notably there is a dichotomy between the FBI characters who attempt to operate in civilian legal procedure with arrests, investigations, and public transparency, and the DEA/CIA team who are heavily militarized, use direct force, torture liberally, manipulate the criminal underworld, and engage in Special Forces style assaults.Sicario is a notably beautiful looking film for being so riddled full of grotesque violence and it demands the viewer's attention. While others may find comparisons to Traffic, I personally feel it has more in common with Zero Dark Thirty, in terms of the strong female protagonist, the direction and cinematography, and final night vision fueled spec ops raids. Of course, where Zero Dark had an uplifting, bittersweet ending, Sicario makes a salient point about the failure and futility of the drug war. It's about as on the nose as you can get, but it doesn't prove to be a fatal artistic flaw. The cold, violent nature of this piece may deter some viewers, but the rest are in for a hellish but rewarding and entertaining journey into the heart of darkness.

Mimicking a better movie (traffic), it's none-the-less incredibly suspenseful and well directed with two great performances from Brolin and Del Toro. Unfortunately Emily Blunt falls just short of a great performance, highlighted by the incredible work from her co-stars. The real hero of this movie is Roger Deakins, whose cinematography paints the desolate landscape of mexico as an eery decent into hellfire.
The acting, combined with some visually stunning shots and script make for a thriller that will also get you thinking as well

Nicely done on keeping the audience (and the central character) in the dark. Solid acting, good character development except for female lead who added little or nothing. FBI & CIA 1 W&C 0 Two US govt agencies work as a clandestine drug busting team. Their catchment area is the Mexican border. Aerial photography- possibly from a drone - enhances a bleak script in which Emily Blunt seems to be the only woman with words. She is used as bait to haul in a drug cowboy by colleagues high up in the team. We witness highly unorthodox "treatments" against the cowboy to make him talk.  Confrontations and twists occur . In different settings EB and a dead cop's wife are left holding the remnants of life together: a child totally unaware his father was a part of the problem and a police woman who'd been violated by a superior officer to catch a "sizeable" slice of the trade. EMILY Blunt is cast well as the principled young cop. She spends so long "fitting in" with the male induction story. Her role is stereotype to the modern feminist role we ought to be seeing. She cannot fit in with the time servers of old America. They can't even get the seating right.  Men fight with guns and ammo and the latest technology to plan their getaways. Mr Big stays in his private abode. The price we pay for the drugs is a fatherless family, low horizons and brutalised women at every corner.

From a filmmaker's perspective, this movie is top-notch. Every single frame in this movie looks fantastic and the acting is superb. From a average movie-goer's perspective, I can see how it can be a little boring at some parts. There were times where the movie really slowed down but at other times it was extremely intense. The whole raid into Mexico sequence with all the Jeeps is truly chilling and crazy to watch. Emily Blunt does a good job as the protagonist we relate to but the most interesting character was Benicio Del Toro's character Alejandro. He was the most exciting character to watch and he was the one who actually had an objective and took action to pursue it while Emily Blunt was just along for the ride. It works well though and didn't bother me that much. You'll be thinking of this movie long after you leave the theatre so I would highly recommend it. But this film isn't for the faint of heart. Just keep that in mind before you buy your ticket.
Saw this opening day and really enjoyed it.

Dark, engrossing mystery-thriller examination of morality with sterling performances by the 3 principals. Mr. del Toro looks like a world-weary Brad Pitt in one of his best performances, bracketed by Blunt's restrained FBI agent. The feeling of hopelessness & dread permeating the film will stay with you long after you leave the theater.

If I forget (but I don't think I will), remind me to exclude Juarez from any future travel plans. Also, I'll bet Kate (Emily Blunt) wishes she had reconsidered her decision to "volunteer" for the task force, especially because she had no clue what she was getting into until it was too late. Also, Josh Brolin is a busy guy because last week he barely survived trying to climb Mt. Everest and now, just a week later, he is fighting Mexican drug runners ...... Final observation and question: Don't mess with Benicio Del Toro and I wonder how many black Tahoes and Suburbans the movie-industry buys every year?

Blunt, Brolin and Del Toro are all top-notch here, but it is really Villeneuve and Deakins that shine with "Sicario". An immersive and truly chilling sense of dread permeates the film from the first frame to the last. And Johann Johannsson's score is one for the ages.

Sicario is the best film I've seen in theaters in 2015 thus far. Dennis Villeneuve returns once again with a complex, solid drama. This film calls upon a delicate balance between mainstream and art- house cinema, and is sure to hit a sweet spot with fans of either style. Benecio Del Toro knocks it out of the park with a dark performance that is striking in it's understated power. Emily Blunt proves solid as our lead character, who manages to give a fine performance despite having a slightly underdeveloped character. Josh Brolin proves himself great as always too, giving a charismatically unsettling performance. The cinematography in this film is gorgeous with Roger Deakins doing an (as per usual) fantastic job, particularly with his use of lighting in the nighttime scenes of the film. The soundtrack, by composer J�hann J�hannsson works well as the glue holding the film together, with perhaps his most haunting soundtrack to date. It cannot be understated, the soundtrack for this film is superb.This is a dark film, with an incredibly consistent tone which successfully evokes unease; haunting in it's elusiveness. Dennis Villeneuve has put forth yet another great film for us all to enjoy.

Denis Villeneuve's tales of revenge are never easy to sit through. Here, in a story about an idealistic FBI agent who got swept into a war against drug lords in Mexico, he makes us mull over the moral dilemma when justice is served, not according to protocol.

I was on the edge of my seat the whole way from beginning to end. The movie wasn't a bang bang the more guns the better . In essence, Sicario is a haunting study of an unbeatable war and the poison it brings to the emotional and psychological composition of the people it touches. It is evocative, well-shot and magnificently acted out.

I already heard that Sicario was great. But I never knew it was that great. And I never knew that the scale was that massive. Denis Villeneuve brought up the best in him in this drug-trafficking thriller that full with ambiguity. The scope, the cinematography, the production design, the score, and especially the cast; were massively stunning.Villeneuve was executing Taylor Sheridan's script (he's the actor from Sons of Anarchy and this was his debut script) with such precision. The blocking for every climax (owh yes, there were so many climax in this one) were immaculate. I especially loved the border ambush that involved thousands of cars and extras, and shot beatifully by veteran Roger Deakins. J�hann J�hannsson was giving another soul of this movie with his intense beat. While Joe Walker edited the film seamlessly.Kudos for Emily Blunt for another strong leading role. And most kudos for Benicio del Toro for being one of the most subtle and ambiguous character in recent years. The subtlety and ambiguity which always been a trademark of Villeneuve's works.And that was what made Sicario a strong movie with strong characters. It's a heart-thumping, mind-blowing, and intense cinematic experience with a strong execution full of great performances. Sicario surely one of the best and strongest movie I've watched this year. And for that, a deep bow for Villeneuve.

Benicio del Toro carries this film with ruthless efficiency. Brolin brings snarky grit. Blunt takes a believable turn as the chain smoking ingenue who has no idea of how things get done on the other side of the Rio Grande. Ciudad Juarez is the real star of the film. It looks just the way I remember it, complete with APVs in the streets, and big black SUV convoys zipping around. A must see.

"Sicario" is the true story of a U.S. Intelligence task force that was put together to investigate and sniff out cartel activity in Mexico. Emily Blunt is an F.B.I. Operative who is pulled into the fray by her cunning supervisor Benicio Tel Toro and his lackey played by Josh Brolin. Blunt quickly learns that this task force isn't what it purports to be. Though this film is violen perhaps unnecessarily so at times, I also applaud it for its realism. Mexico is a hostile country where nihilism abounds and its every man for himself. The movie conveys that ideology and shows that not everything in politics can be a pretty picture. Call it senseless if you will, but this film is ambitious and honest enough to accurately portray the dog eat dog world that the cartel run country is. Nothing is held back. Some may disagree but I see this as honest filmmaking and a rarity in modern cinema ------------------------------------------------- B+
Even with good actors like Emily Blunt and Benecio Del Toro..this movie was very slow, boring and had horrible cinematography. I want my two hours back.
Powerful where it needs to be and quick through the details that don't need emphasis - excellent film

Sicario draws a thin line between bad and worse, as it dives into the seedy underground of mexico's drug cartels. the trailers make it seem like they focus on blunt as a main character, but i have to say, the role was split between her and Del Toro, with a greater emphasis on Del Toro. the acting was really spot on, and if you love action films with crazy badass leads, you will love really this film. though i will say, if you can't handle brutality or gore, you might wanna stay away, because there are some messed up scenes in this movie.

Brilliant action-packed thriller about D.E.A agents battling the powerful drug cartels in Mexico will have you on the edge of your seat. The Genius here , the one who really knows what's going on is Alejandro , played by Benicio Del Toro. Is he a Hero? Is he an anti-hero? Is he a villain? We decide or maybe we don't decide. That is the greatness of this film. We just know the drug battles made him what he is. The cinematography is breathlessly good. And the scenes in which they ride in a motorcade through the streets of Juarez like it's a warzone is awesome filmmaking because you really feel like you are a part of it. A stupendous film.
this is pretty intense.
cant get my time back from this shit show
Beautifully crafted and BRUTAL. This was a great film. They dont make too many movies like this anymore.
While the story dd nothing for me, Sicario should absolutely be admired from a technical standpoint, and further cements Roger Deakins and Denis Villenueve as among the best in their field.

Such a great film. It perfectly captures the horrors going on in the world that most of us in our everyday lives fail to realize.Wonderful shots, sets, camerawork, acting, and beyond all, storytelling.

Sicario, the third Denis Villeneuve feature film after the highly successful Prisoners and Enemy from 2013 and 2014 respectively. The movie stars Emily Blunt (Edge of Tomorrow), Josh Brolin (Everest and No Country for Old Men), and Benicio Del Toro (Escobar: Paradise Lost and Traffic) in a drug-fuelled action movie set along the US-Mexico Border. The movie is a cliche storyline with characters that have been seen before. But the way that the characters are played is what makes this movie stand out. It should be noted that the posters may show that the movie might be about Emily Blunt's character Kate, but the crucial performance is the performance by Del Toro in his portrayal of Alejandro. This is a performance that hasn't been seen from Del Toro in quite a while. I would have to say that a Best Actor Nomination should easily be coming towards Del Toro's way. An honorable mention to Josh Brolin, portraying the team leader Matt. His character brought comic relief to a movie that was disturbingly serious. Now the movie itself. The first thing to note is the cinematography. The movie is beautifully shot, which is not a surprise with Director of Photography Roger Deakins (No Country for Old Men and Skyfall) at the helm. The panning birds eye view shots of Ciudad Juarez along with street side shots showed the bleak circumstances that the people in Juarez were living in. The defining message from the film is the bleakness of the War on drugs in the Southern US. It shows how agencies have to "work together" just to have a shot at a cartel leader and even getting rid of a single cartel leader just means that another leader has already propped up and ends up being a never ending circle of massacre. It's not the story that contributes to the high mark it will get, it's the characters in the movie who you connect to immediately, with audiences most likely to latch onto Alejandro's story after his background is revealed. Sicario may not get a Best Picture nomination but might have at least 1 nomination for Best Actor. Sicario gets an A grade.

"You are not a wolf. And this is the land of wolves now."Director Denis Villeneuve has crafted a brilliant thriller that holds nothing back in showing the brutal world of the War on Drugs.The stunning and beautiful cinematography by Roger Deakins greatly contrasts to the morally gray area the film operates in -- there is no black and white in a drug war that proves no winner, just the lesser of two evils that has left a path of collateral damage.The score is equally brilliant and Benicio Del Toro gives a memorable Oscar-worthy performance.10/10 -- 'Sicario' is mesmerizing. Starts with a punch to the chest that doesn't relent til its powerful closing shot. One of the year's best.

On Thursday night I went to see the new film Sicario which opened wide this weekend. I've been anticipating this film since I heard about it. Not only did it look great but it has a stellar cast and a pretty great director. The film stars Emily Blunt, Benicio Del Toro, and Josh Brolin. The director, Denis Villeneuve, directed Prisoners back in 2013 which was one of my favorite films of that year and probably of all time. He also directed Enemy which came out last year and although I didn't love it like Prisoners it was still a film worth seeing and very interesting. Roger Deakins, who has worked on films such as Prisoners, Skyfall, and No Country For Old Men, is the Cinematographer for Sicario and it really shows, giving us many breath taking scenes.I really can't say how glad I am that Sicario didn't disappoint. I loved this film. It's my favorite film of 2015 so far. The story was interesting and kept you on the edge of your seat the entire 2 hours. The cinematography was breathtaking. The directing was incredible. The acting was award worthy. The score was chilling. If you haven't seen this movie yet you need to go right away. I know a lot of people are seeing The Martian this weekend and while it might be good, Sicario is fucking great.The three things that stood out the most to me in Sicario was the cinematography, the score, and Benicio Del Toro. The score by J�hann J�hannsson was absolutely amazing and definitely added so much to the film. Emily Blunt clearly plays the lead in this film and she is great but the actor/character that steals the show is Del Toro. His character is interesting and demands your attention while he's on screen. If he doesn't get an academy award nomination this year I'll not only be surprised but incredibly upset. Out of the films I've seen so far I would nominate Blunt for Best Actress as well but that could change as I see more movies during award season. Josh Brolin is also in this film and does great in his role.

ZFF 2015. 5/5Sicario. Hitman. A drug cartel related story in the borderland between US and Mexico, CIA, FBI, local police, special forces, and all kinds of things in between. Gang members, dead and alive, smugglers, illegal immigrants, young and old. All in the violent and scary setting where death is never far. Nothing is black and white, it is all various shades of grey (more than 50, I am sure!) where things you thought were wrong are necessary and somehow just right. Emily Blunt has come far from the Devilish assistant and in addition, the film posts talent and eye candy in the form of Benicio del Toro and Josh Brolin.To note, this director has done other super films, such as Prisoners and Incendies. Both highly recommended, maybe even more than this one. Especially Incendies has stayed in my mind. Not many films do!

Denis Villeneuve's latest film is a riveting crime-drama that is lead by a duo of outstanding performances. Benicio del Toro and Emily Blunt are the most memorable, with Blunt giving a career best display. Sicario depicts the war on drugs in a new light, showcasing the brutality and the victimization of the inhabitants of the land. Corruption spreads like a plague, middle class families live in terror, and there is absolutely no hope for requiem. With Roger Deakins at the helm, Sicario is brilliantly filmed, especially the portions shot at night. It is definitely one of the best pictures of 2015.
A perfect combination of pulp and art house; the script is nothing spectacular but the performances and perspective elevate it into something special.

Sicario is a great movie that reminds you how fucked up the whole war on drugs and the supporting system around it really are. There really are no good guys and bad guys - everyone is rotten to the core. From the leaders of the cartels to the buyers on the streets, the drug world is nasty, bloody and merciless. This movie is a good film that shows the inner workings of the ant-drug enforcement world. It shows how the system is littered with corruption, loopholes, dirty money and dead ends. No one wins in this movie. Whether it's the good guys in the FBI trying to do their job or the poor devils caught in the crossfire, everyone ultimately loses. This is really an excellent movie and i strongly recommend it to anyone that wants a good time and not end brain-dead.
Dark and eye opening. This movie really gives you a look into Americas struggle with the drug cartel. Emily Blunt embodies a true sense of fear in her character. Great acting.

Incredible stuff. Between the performances, the great cinematography and more importantly the story, Denis Villeneuve rebounded after Enemy. Emily Blunt and Josh Brolin was great but Benicio del Toro stole the movie for me.

The movie was very well done. It held your attention all the way through, while providing a very thoughtful representation of what is going on today, and what might be coming. We here of the issues in Mexico, but we rarely see it

While marketed as a high octane action thriller, Sicario is a slower suspenseful drama set against the war on drugs. The film shines the light on violence facing border towns on both sides which may or may not be publicized on daily basis. In addition it examines what is necessary to fight and win in this war. Emily Blunt, Benicio Del Toro, and Josh Brolin give excellent performances respectively. Perhaps more disturbing than the visuals is the score which is the definition of foreboding and truly brings this film to life. This is a must see in theaters.

"You can't handle the truth!" That is the most famous line uttered in the film 'A Few Good Men,' by Jack Nicholson who played Colonel Nathan Jessup. If you asked Colonel Jessup to define the term 'necessary evil' in the context of defense of the United States, 'Sicario 'is the story he'd tell. Easily the best film of 2015 thus far. With tremendous acting by the triumvirate powerhouse cast of Blunt, Del Toro, and Brolin. The action sequences combined with the score, excellent pacing and cinematography, with have you peeling the upholstery off your armchair. Do yourself a favor and go see this movie, 4 stars outta 4

Mark it down now, Benicio Del Toro and Josh Brolin will be nominated for Best Supporting Actor for their roles in Sicario. What makes this thing so good is that you don't get the whole picture until the end, and that's what the main character Emily Blunt is figuring out too. The musical score is outstanding, and simply adds to the tension. Del Toro and Brolin are really good and I was at the edge of my seat pretty much the entire movie. It starts and ends with some really great stuff.

Excellent. Outstanding cast. Well written and beautifully filmed. Gritty, brutal and just intense! Commons suspicions about the drug war are revealed. Expect Del Toro to get an Oscar for his performance.

She did fine with the part she was given, but I wish she would have been given more of a role in which she contributed to more than being confused and a hindrance, tittering on annoying. At some point I thought she'd assist in making the mission a success, never happens. Loved the border scene, was expecting that kind of tension more often. Benicio Del Toro hands down is what makes this movie stand out. Happy to see him shine in a role he was meant to play. Not a great movie in my book, but a really good one. Sicario is hands down one of best thrillers of the year. Del Toro marvels the screen with his convincing, edgy and bold performance. Villeneuve delivers another master piece on the screen that will leave your heart pounding until then end.

Let me just get this out of the way. Sicario is fantastic and quite possibly the best film I've seen in 2015! The cast is incredible. Benicio Del Toro is unforgettable. The story is fascinating. The cinematography is spectacular. The pace is perfect. I basically feel like this film is just about flawless. It's thrilling, suspenseful, thought-provoking, and an absolute lock to make my Top Ten list come January! Can not wait to see it again! ~ A

Secario has a lot going for, namely how well directed and crafted by Denis Villeneuve, who's a director who's very much a star of the film. The soundtrack, cinematography also takes on the surface a basic story and elevates it to HIGH ART!The movie is excellently casted. Emily Blunt is Kate, an idealistic FBI agent in Arizona who is recruited to "special" task force lead by Josh Brolin, to get to heart of problem in the war on drugs. Where she meets Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro) a shadowy figure who you later finds out is the MOTHER FUCKER of the movie. The producers of the film would have you believe Sacario means "hitman" in Mexico. I don't speak Mexican but after seeing it I'm pretty sure it translate into "mother-fucker", because Benicio Del Toro steals this movie. The tension is HIGH and pushes the boundaries you don't often see in conventional films. The movie aims to be disturbing and fucked up and succeed in all regards. This movie is Great! Brilliant and possibly one of BEST movies of the year. If I had to think of legitimate reason someone didn't like this movie outside of being a lesser mind, id imagine it be to a "basic" story with little redeeming outcome and meaning by the end... Due to fact they can't grasp subtext and social commentary at that isn't spelled out in crayons. In the trailer, Benicio Del Toro says to Emily Blunt "nothing will make sense to your American ears... But in the end you'll understand." What does that even mean? You have watch the movie to find out.
Perhaps well executed, but overall I ended up not liking the tone.
one of the top 3 best movies of 2015

Sicario is dark, dramatic and mysterious that makes it a compelling movie to watch. Led by Benecio Del Toro performance and director Denis Villeneuve; who help bring to life the drug war and its cruelty in full effect. Overall, Sicario is a great drama thriller movie.

Sicario is by far the best film of the year with incredible performances from Emily Blunt and a stirring one from Benicio del Toro. Del Toro kills it. Villeneuve draws a bleak vision, as usual. Brolin is Brolin. Emily Blunt is a decent audience surrogate. I wish she was given more to do.

[10/3/15] Oh, boy. Where do I even begin? "Sicario" is a tense thriller that follows Emily Blunt as an FBI agent who volunteers to join, well, umm, we're not really sure and neither is she. Josh Brolin is this chill, laid-back dude who's forming a team with Benicio del Toro's character, but it becomes clear that there's more to both of their characters than what they say. At first, the operation seems simple based on the first 10 minutes: "okay, so these three are after some cartel in Juarez. Big deal." It's not nearly that simple. I'll repeat this again, we don't really know who's working with who and what the legal parameters of their actions are--is Blunt's character working with mercenaries, rogue agents, the DEA, the CIA, a different cartel, and at times, it seems like she's signed up to work alongside all of them. It's not a confusing plot [I'm typing that in case you're thinking, oh, it's one of those 'I'm not following this movie at all' type of films. No, it's just a lot of strings being pulled simultaneously]. "Sicario" touches a lot on the current situation in Mexico--since it's set in the border region--with the drug cartels and the violence, I mean, when you watch this you're literally getting a taste, just a taste, of what's going on down there. Every minute/hour/what have you. Of everyday. And at times, just the film's handling of the content is terrifying, terrifying because in the back of my mind I know that the cartel violence in real life is much worse. And for the people down there, that's their reality. Gunshots, torture, drugs, etc--that's some kid's lullaby to get him/her to sleep. To counter the more graphic content, the film gives us a few scenes where a character's relationship with his son is highlighted (because we find out that the father is delivering drugs). What I liked most about those father-son scenes is that it's a subtle way of saying "not everyone who works with the cartels does so because they're born evil. They're doing that to feed their families," doesn't make it right, sure, but it offers some perspective given the father's occupation. It hints at a greater message, I think, and I don't think the father would be involved at all if circumstances were different. If the country wasn't such a disaster. If his salary were better, etc. And I know I'm going off a tangent, the film is well-directed, it's well-acted, there's a few action scenes that put you right in the freakin' middle of all the chaos--it's great--and even if you're not completely impressed by the movie--"Sicario" definitely gets you thinking about the film and the Drug War in general. Take the fact that we get this really cool scene, sorry SPOILERS, in thermal vision as Brolin, del Toro, and Blunt's team sneaks into Mexico through a tunnel used by the cartels. Now we know that in real life, there IS cooperation between U.S Intelligence and the Mexican Government. Do events like those that unfold in the film happen [U.S forces going into Mexico to take down the cartels, in a way, committing acts of war] in reality? If it did, they'd probably have the approval of the Mexican government anyways. But what about all of that surveillance and technology that we're using on our side and also sending down the Mexicans, how are we not finding these big cartel leaders more easily? Should we even be getting involved, I mean, we already are, but should we be playing such a big role considering Mexico's infamy with corruption and bribery? Those are just some things I'd like to know. Perhaps the most thought-provoking part about the movie happens right at the end. There's a soccer game, we see the kids playing, the moms are there trying to forget about the environment's insanity...and then the gunshots start from a distance. One might say, "wait a minute, I want to see what's going on." The truth is we already saw what we needed to see. It's a giant question mark and it concerns the youth, which in turn, concerns the future. Right now, there are no answers or realistic solutions, and that's kind of how I'd describe "Sicario"--it's a film that makes you ask and ask ...but gives you no answers [per se].
Very well done - everyone is excellent; Emily Blunt does a fine job, with a flawed character who would never be that naive in real life.
Very dark, empty and tense. Excellent writing, excellent execution.

After Prisoners and Enemy in back to back years, two of the more thought provoking films of the past few years, I have been awaiting Denis Villeneuve's next project. Of course, Emily Blunt is my favorite actress right now, so in my mind the two of them were enough to get Sicario on my most anticipated list for 2015. I can assure you, the film doesn't letdown. Sicario is about an FBI agent, played by Blunt, who is brought along by a government task force to help on the border of Mexico and the U.S. as drug cartels rule the area.One of the most chilling parts about Sicario is its realistic nature. I had a Zero Dark Thirty vibe in that it doesn't hold back in its brutality. They both have a brilliant female lead as well, although much different characters by motive. Blunt is complemented by Benicio Del Toro and Josh Brolin as the main three agents. Part of the greatness of Sicario is its cast but I think the marketing was a bit misleading. We are led to believe that Blunt is the central focus of the story, but there is almost as much if not more of Del Toro than anyone else here. It's both good and bad. I was looking forward to seeing Blunt as the integral part of the story, but Del Toro was just as good. I think the real star of the film is Roger Deakins, the director of photography. He once again gives an incredibly beautiful looking film through his award winning cinematography. Even though this film may fail to get any acting nominations or any ofthe other big awards, I think it's safe to say that Deakins is a lock for cinematography. It's his panning shots of the border along with J�hann J�hannsson's score that give the film an eerie and ominous feel. It's very difficult to talk about any details without spoiling anything, but I can say that it's a really good movie. I was reading a review that talked about the intensity of a scene before the intensity really begins, if that makes sense. It wasn't the gunshots or explosions that gave me chills. It was the quiet calm scenes before the storm. It's not the mind bender that Enemy was nor the shocker that was Prisoners, but Sicario is one of the most beautifully shot and well acted films this year.+Blunt can do no wrong+Eerie score+Deakins' cinematography+Brutally real+Very very very intense9.0/10
Good action but still realistic enough to believe.
Good movie, interesting story, but too much of the action takes place off-screen or in the background.

Sicario was a bit slower than I thought it was going to be. It isn't bad, but man does the first half hour move at a snails pace. The film follows an FBI agent named Kate Macer (Emily Blunt). A by the books agent that is in charge of hostage situations. She is brought into a group led by Matt Graver (Josh Brolin) an elite government agent that doesn't always play by the rules. Graver is working with a mysterious man named Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro) who has a hidden agenda himself. Their task is to take down a drug lord through any means necessary. Macer sees things that haunt her and she questions what exactly is going on and who exactly are the people they are working for. The movie is well done and shot really well. Like i said previously it has a very slow start, but after the cogs get rolling the film has a lot of suspense and is a mystery in itself. Overall, it won't be for everyone, but if you like a slow burner thriller with a slight mystery give this one a look!

I saw the new thriller Sicario today, and it was a truly amazing & superb film.Everything about this film was outstanding. The acting was simply wonderful especially Emily Blunt and Benicio del Toro. Emily Blunt kicked some major butt in the film. In addition, the cinematography was breathtaking.This is one of those films you want to see again, and I hope I get a chance to.I wholeheartedly recommend everyone to see it.I give it a grade of an A+.ENJOY!!!!

This is a solid thriller that has peaks and valleys of great moments and boring moments. When it wants to be a thriller, it really is thrilling but the quieter scenes just aren't all that captivating. Emily Blunt makes some of the more boring stuff worth while because she just is naturally a great actress to watch (and to the executive that wanted a man in this role, this movie would have been 10 times less engaging if a man was in her role). I also like how Blunt's character wasn't down your throat about "oh I'm a woman in a man's game" nor were the people around her undermining her because she was a woman. It was nice and refreshing to see that from a modern movie. Josh Brolin has been really winning be over these past few years as I was kind of meh about him in the past. He does a great job and Benicio Del Toro also has some good moments but he wasn't given as much to do with his character overall. If he had a few more scenes, he may have stolen the show. Jon Bernthal also has a great small part in this. I love the director Denis Villeneuve that made 2013's Prisoners and I think he did a good job directing this especially the climax. Roger Deakens' cinematography is really wonderful during the climax as well. Great sound design as well and some great thrills as I said. It's solid and worth seeing but you don't have to rush out to see it right this minute

There are a number of reasons to like Sicario. This movie has amazing cinematography. It puts you in the middle of everything that's going on. At the same time, the movie intentionally keeps you in the dark, putting you in the same company as the lead, Emily Blunt. It gets frustrating, but that's part of the movie. Sicario drew a fine line between very good movie and dud, but comes through toward the end to be a very good movie. This is a solid script and is well directed. It's incredibly violent, but not just for violence's sake. Blunt's character seems a bit too whiny in the beginning, but it ends up being necessary for the movie to work.For people who have a solid idea of "good vs. evil," Sicario will seem like nothing more than Hollywood entertainment. The fact that there is a middle ground, or more people are on the "evil" side of things that one would think, could cause more people to think about what's going on and may be a catalyst for many a discussion on the reality of America's involvement in the illegal drug trade.Emily Blunt is an entertaining actress, and Josh Brolin is on top of his game as the casual DoD agent. I firmly believe that Benicio Del Toro should be in every movie made, and he reinforces why in Sicario. Sicario is worth spending money on, whether you go to the theater or a rent.
takes a while to get going, Blunt and Del Toro is great as always. Theater movie? video is just fine. Don't think it is as great movie as the critics are saying

#Sicario damm this movie stayed at 100 percent action and violence ultra violence and that camera work was some of the best the story was clear and characters motives took it all the way to the end this was training day meets the departed tactical advanced really drugs could watch this shit 5 more times

Dennis Villeneuve masterfully directs this film about the drug wars in Mexico as well as the drug trade with the U.S. The feel of the film is very reminiscent of Zero Dark Thirty with Jessica Chastain. You feel like you are right in the middle of the action from the very beginning. Emily Blunt's character is an FBI agent that gets recruited into an inter-agency operation to stop the drug trade. Her character thinks it is for her tactical experience, but she learns after awhile it is for rubber stamping the operation to give the CIA impunity on what they do on both sides of the border.

An absorbing action movie even for people like me who generally hate violence and action movies. This is because the film shows the complexities and ambiguities of the US 'war on drugs' and eschews easy attributions of 'good and'bad'. It is very well filmed, acted, and edited. Atmospheric and very engaging

Simply put, I loved Sicario! Directed expertly by Denis Villeneuve, Sicario is breathtaking in every sense of the word! From amazing Cinematography by legend Roger Deakins, Career best performances by Benicio del Toro and Josh Brolin, gripping action set pieces, haunting images, and a performance by Emily Blunt that ranks among the best this year (guaranteed Oscar nom for her work) Sicario always has something going on beneath the amazing action sequences and is one of this years first flawless films!

'Sicario' explores a very intriguing side on the war against drugs and the cartel. The story itself is nothing extraordinary, but Villeneuve's slick direction, Deakin's beautiful cinematography and the cast's great performances, especially Del Toro's, make 'Sicario' one of the better films of the year.

Denis Villeneuve is perhaps one of the most exciting directors to come into a more public eye; not that Villeneuve is a new director as he's directed several films already, but his growing popularity is getting him better and better jobs. Villeneuve has now taken on the drug trade of all things and has turned what could've been just a have been a great thriller film and has turned it into something more, he has us question the moralities of law enforcement not so much as a good cop vs bad cop but rather as the one who does it the "right" way and the one who breaks the rules willingly and regularly in order to get better results. Which is right? Which is better? Sicario isn't so much about answering it but portraying both sides and asking us to question what's right, and then threatens you with reality. Emily Blunt's Kate's crisis of morality and personal belief is brought out by Blunt's fantastic work, it's not the kind of performance that gives you grand scenes to quote, but an embodiment of a person and losing yourself to the role. Benicio Del Toro's almost polar opposite Alejandro shows the other side and is brought on by one of the veteran actor's best performances in years. His calm, cold, tactile demeanor and dead eyes convey more to us than even the most wordy of main characters. These two performances rocket Sicario's questions of morality into frame and never let up even at the end it's not entirely clear, but it's left up for the viewer to decide. It's a film that is so beautifully directed and equally haunting in it's content that it creates a brilliant contrast of beautiful horrors that actually could make Sicario one of the best horror films of this year. So utterly disturbing and yet for everything that we are more aware of and think of, it's almost like the film's just scratching the surface but we ourselves have to see how much is under that scratch itself. The result is one of the absolute best films so far this year, simply unmissable, even if it will make your ethics boil and your stomach churn
Slowly paced but drenched in dark atmosphere and eerie suspense, Sicario features fine directing from Villeneuve, incredible work by Deakins, and breathaking performances by Blunt and Del Toro

Director Denis Villeneuve is not one to shy away from the darkest aspects of human nature. While far be it from me to call the plot of his films inconsequential, the setting is merely a catalyst to show what humans are capable of when pushed to the brink of their capabilities. He keeps his filmed honed and resolute, with minimal scoring, sparse and economical characterization, and an unhurried narrative. It worked brilliantly for a movie like Prisoners, but for Sicario, the results are underwhelming. And due to the relaxed delivery of the story, it wasn't until the second act that I realized Sicario wasn't going to deliver on the narratives promises. My frustrations are centered on the screenplay. First time writer Taylor Sheridan made a name for himself as David Hale in Sons of Anarchy, a series which lasted 7 seasons and 95 episodes, so he isn't accustomed to concluding a story in just over two hours. And this is where Sicario falters; The script meanders along the narrative, which puts you in a relaxed mindset, but spontaneous bout of ultra-suspense, and a plot with too many webs to follow puts Sicario at odds with itself. It tries to be too many things; a character study, an expose on drug cartels, a nail-biting thriller, an unhurried arthouse film. The best films in history have been able to have multiple personalities, so this is not impossible, but Taylor Sheridan is too green of a screenwriter to pull it off. As a result, Sicario is decent at many things, but superb at nothing. If by some miracle this review reaches Taylor Sheridan, I have a lesson for him; A story doesn't need to tie up all (or even any) of its loose ends as long as it has a point. The moral of your story is the driving principle - the lesson an audience takes away once the credits roll and the dust settles. 'Love conquers all', 'Teens often make bad decisions', 'Don't walk across the wood at night.' That kind of thing. Decide on the moral of your story and use it to drive the action. Be aware of the contract between you and your audience. Everything that happens must happen for a reason, and the more of a big deal you make of an event, the bigger the pay off must be.

it is really getting hard to choose my favorite movie of 2015, seriously, collectively this is hands down the best movie year I can remember. This one offically lands behind Straight Outa Compton and Furious 7 for me, at #3 and I can easily seeing this film just cleaning up at the Oscars come February. Incredible acting. Sicario is Spanish for hitman. In film lingo that makes it sensational viewing, a gripping and action-packed foray into America's War on Drugs. French-Canadan filmmaker Denis Villeneuve (Incendies, Prisoners), working from a dense, heart-shattering script from Taylor Sheridan, is out to fry your nerves. Mission accomplished.The film starts off a little opaque and convoluted but hang on. Just follow along with audience surrogate Kate Macer, played by a killer good Emily Blunt. Macer is an FBI field agent and Blunt gives her a tough core that is unforgettable. If Edge of Tomorrow didn't convince you of Blunt's inherent badass-ness, Sicario should.We first meet Kate in Arizona, raiding a hideout run by a Mexican drug cartel, a house with decomposing corpses stuffed into the walls. Kate is largely unflappable till she's essentially ordered to volunteer for an agency-merging task force that seeks to pit one drug lord against another.Sound confusing? Just sit back and absorb, basically the same advice Kate gets from operations chief Matt Graver (a stellar, smarmy Josh Brolin), a laid-back man of manipulations clad in sandals who claims to be working a defense contract but in all likelihood is CIA. His associate Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro) is an ex-Mexican-prosecutor-turned-assassin who may have a larger personal agenda. You can basically see it in his intense stare. Oscar-winner Del Toro is tremendous here, giving off a toxic mix of smoldering cool and menace that throws even Kate off her game.Sicario is all build-up for a stunning climax set in a world where right and wrong, good and bad, are no longer absolutes. As Kate fights to stand her moral ground as the ground beneath her perpetually shifts, Villeneuve expertly stages on gut-wrenching action scene after another, all set to a mirthful, jittery score by Johan Johannsson. All praise as well to cinematographer Roger Deakins whose aerial shots of a white-knuckle border crossing stands in vivid contrast with a tense tunnel chase. It's a visual knockout. But the real miracles of the film are all written on Blunt's expressive face. It's pure poetry and it's dark. You won't know what hit you.

Sicario was probably one of the most intense and scariest films I've seen lately!! The saddest part is this film is speaking out loud to what's is currently happening underground between my countries and its very sad and scary!

Should I feel disappointed that Emily Blunt's character only shoots like 1 guy in this film? Here is a loss of naivete tale in war on the Mexican drug cartel. Blunt is our touchstone for perspective. There is the presentation that dark deeds must be done for the sake of our way of life, and those dancers in the dark have their souls hanging in the balance. Blunt does such a fine job as an American that I at times forget her English background. Bencio Del Toro and Josh Brolin do some solid work. The cinematography starts with a bleached out and baked color portraying the heat, and takes us into some stunning beautiful sunset and even night-vision work. My first thoughts were that the story did not seem all that original and director Denis Villeneuve didn't take a position of the soul darkening affects, so why was I being told the story. But the more I stew on the result the more I find it interesting to roll around in my head.

What are the rules of engagement in fighting the Mexican drug cartels especially if US law enforcement agencies go into foreign territories where they have no jurisdiction; does the end justify any means? Denis Villeneuve's intense new film SICARIO (which means hit man in Spanish) takes us into the tactical underbelly of those cryptic individuals who carry out US policy decisions "from on high", cloaked in legitimacy, though they are prohibited maneuvers that would be considered illegal in any court of law.The atmosphere is beautifully filmed - either pale, washed out ochers depicting the long dusty border between US and Mexico, or the rich deep blues and blacks of the evening with night - vision goggles irradiating the world around them into skeletal images. Put a young, female FBI agent into this mix - Emily Blunt as Kate, a dedicated officer, former head of a kidnap-response unit based in Phoenix, who is forced to question all that she has practiced and been taught in the Bureau; her fiercely held personal values are turned upside down by the reality of being recruited into the midst of anti- cartel "warriors" who can behave as dark and dirty as their enemy - the drug lords that control the populous by murdering and slaughtering men, women and children, stringing up body parts hanging them from electricity wires like abandoned baggage on clothes-lines.Transporting, manufacturing, shipping and controlling the wildly lucrative drug industry necessitates making alliances - everyone is corruptible from the dealers to the federales and police on both sides of the border - all partaking of the spoils, while their interior sentiments become ghosts evaporating into the surroundings. "It is not personal" are words that exemplify the cool calculations of those in power whose humanity has been shredded, and who barricade themselves with bodyguards and fancy homes from the brutality that they inflict on nameless people.Kate and her FBI partner ( a good performance by Daniel Kaluuya) are the two newcomers brought along on a mission that they were not briefed on - so the "fog of war" is indeed literally murky. Everything becomes clear with time, but meanwhile we in the audience are as mystified as the protagonists. We meet a team of hardened DEA operatives with Josh Brolin as Matt - the wise-cracking, gum chewing leader who is a cipher, offhandedly refusing to respond with a straight answer to any question put before him. Despite his Cheshire-like grin, there is a man beneath the lumbering, impenetrable veneer who is callously determined to fulfill the U.S. government's calculated goals no matter the toll.Benicio Del Toro is the "star" of SICARO, brilliant as the mercenary Alejandro - a person whose face reveals little, but whose eyes and body language betray a passionate resolve for revenge, and a history of incomparable pain and suffering at the hands of the drug-lords becoming a person for hire with no longer a "soul" to lose. He is the "enforcer," expert at torture and killing, yet despite his horrific activities, every moment he is on the screen it is filled with his abundant presence and an acute sense of heartache. Kate's sojourn from an idealistic FBI agent to an awareness of the brutal realities of the contaminated policies used by the United States to combat the "drug war" is a bit naive and inconclusive. We sense that she remains a staunch believer in the underlying principle of the "rule of law", but we know all-too-well that she is standing on shaky grounds.

First rate crime thriller thanks to a superb cast & gritty direction by Villeneuve. The cast gives career best work, with Blunt continuing her streak as one of the best females in action movies while Brolin laid back cynicism hides a ruthless nature. The standout, though, is Del Toro as Alejandro, a man of few words & all action, coming off as a walking predator. He's someone who knows what he is and is okay with and is Del Toro's best performance since "Traffic" (in many ways, this is a spiritual sequel to that movie). Behind the camera, Villeneuve directs Taylor Sheridan's gritty script to near-perfection, keeping the action moving while giving you enough character moments to make you care. Plus, while not preached outright, there is a nice ant-drug war message in the sense that in other to fight monsters like the drug cartels, you'll have to employ a monster to do so, and if you don't like that, maybe this isn't a war worth fighting. Overall, one of the best crime thrillers in years and one of the the best movies of 2015 to date.

Even with this Hollywood propaganda script to whitewash the FBI, Denis Villeneuve and Roger Deakins create something exceptional out of it. But still, who believes the FBI cares for the law? There are some idealistic agents, yes, but using this as sole point for the drama is laughable.

Sicario is unforgettable. Period. One of the best movies I've seen this year. Denis Villeneuve's thriller examines the capricious horrors of the Mexican cartel and leads to a shocking ending. The movie is gripping, excellently acted, and marvelously filmed. Cinematographer Roger Deakins deserves an Oscar for this.

ONE OF THE BEST OF THE LAST 3 YEARSBY SCREPEA WRITTEN OCTOBER 03, 2015excellent in every aspect. Blunt, her acting, out of the park The directing, story line, photography, and REALISM!!! Feel like I've just been to the drug border wars. No heroes, no winners, just pure adrenaline rush.
Dudes, seriously...see this movie. It's a rough go, but very much worth it.

Small window of time to catch a flick this past Friday and the only ones that fit my time slot was "The Intern" with DeNiro & Hathaway (great actors, movie couldn't begood) and "Sicario". Sicaro...what the heck is that? (I'm thinking I'm pretty movie savvyand have a sense of most new films)..never heard of it. Did a quick moviefone search to make sure it wasnot a Sci Fi or a Horror floc...check.NOT..good. I never want to know a thing about a flickin advance "except the type", but my eye catches that cast includes Emily Blunt; Josh Brolinand the always excellent Denicio Del Toro.How do I not know anything about this movie? How can this movie "Not" be good?Folks....my gut was right..it was good. Legendary no, will it be a box office success,no. But this was one harsh, violent in your face story of the US Federal Governmentsefforts to fight the war against drugs (coming in from Mexico) literally as a war. Conventional, legal, humanistic tactics are not used.We are talking violence, torture, killing at the blink of an eye (by both sides).This was not a slick production which actually really helped the movie along. Dirt, grime,dust, poverty, violence, faux family values and more brought this movie down tostreet level where the war is being fought (without rules).I really enjoyed and was thoroughly entertained and enthralled by the "war" Gruesomein parts yes (so I covered my eyes).This ones a sleeper folks and excellent performances by the trio above.
Unflinching look at drug cartels with an intelligent script, great direction, and solid performances by Blunt and del Toro.

Dark, thrilling and brutal, we are taken into the ugly, world of Mexican drug cartels and the battles (literally) fought by American law enforcement. The rules bend and we learn that some (Americans) are willing to do whatever it takes to solve the problems of the drug trade. Not for a moment does this film feel contrived. Not for the faint-of-heart. Extra credit for the very interesting photography. Hurray for the French Canadian director, representin'.

This movie is consistently tense all the way through. It has mild pacing issues in the middle parts but the opening moments and finale are spectacular. The best thing about this movie is that you can't predict anything that's going to happen next. It's handled in such an original way and all the performances are all great. The movie also isn't just an action movie since it carries lots of big ideas that make you think for sure. It's an intense movie that's dark and tension filled and well worth a watch.

"Sicario" is all gas and no brake. This real world flick is nearly flawess in its attempt to put you in the center of the "Drug War". Easily top five films of the 2015 so don't miss this one in the theaters. I will say even though it has a female lead it is very much a "dude flick". Think "Homeland" but faster and centered around mexican cartel instead of muslim jihadists.
powerful and relevant film

I loved this movie. It didn't feel like anything had been written or designed with typical Hollywood thrillers in mind. Every time I go to the theater it's hoping I see something this good. It isn't too hard to figure out what's really going on with the story, but I'm not looking to be completely confused and fooled either. Great performances from every actor.

A huge turnout of The Old Geezers Who Go To The Matinee Alone yesterday, fortunately most of them were going to the Robert DeNiro flic. But a goodly handful joined me for this movie about the drug trade along the southern border. The Promos have make it look like Benicio Del Toro is the main character, and indeed he is important and Del Toro delivers a chilling performance, but the movie is really about Emily Blunt's character and she comes across with a performance worthy, in my opinion, of a major award. She plays an FBI agent caught up in a shady CIA operation (is that a redundancy?) in Juarez. Her struggle with gradual corruption of the spirit is what makes this work so well. Go see it by all means, graphically violent so beware.
It might not have as much story as I would've liked, but it's beautiful, well-acted, and very thought-provoking. It's definitely one of my favorites this year.

Denis Villeneuve continues his impressive directorial streak with Sicario, thanks to its powerhouse performances, thrilling story backed by intense pacing, gorgeous cinematography, and a chilling soundtrack.

Sicario is a completely engrossing, beautifully shot, terrifically acted thriller that exceeds expectations. I didn't know what to expect from this film, but I was surprised that from the opening shot the film had me hooked. I won't give away the opening scene, but I'd find it hard to believe that you're bored after seeing that. Emily Blunt and Benicio Del Toro are easily two of the better performances I've seen this year, and as per usual Villeneuve get's terrifically dark performances from his brilliant cast. Villeneuve's taut direction, combined with beautiful cinematography, and an amazing score, make Sicario one of his best in his constantly growing filmography. The end result is a great movie, that will almost definitely get recognition at award season.

This eye-opening and chilling tale tells the story of an idealistic FBI agent played by Emily Blunt who thinks she can put a damper on the Mexican drug trade by following the rules. Josh Brolin as a CIA operative who knows with even breaking the rules not much can be done to stop this scourge. Well worth your time and the entire cast is excellent especially Benicio Del Toro as a somewhat heartless spook with a past seeking revenge on the drug lords. Will be mentioned come oscar time...
Beautiful story. Some of the scenes were too sudden (in one case, too graphic), but in general, it was well-told. Very good depictions of culture and language.

Simply put this movie is amazing. Thank you Benicio Del Toro for the unforgettable performance. This movie has some of the most intense scenes I have seen, the build up the camera work, the unflinching realism of the blurred lines of what is good and evil that this movie brings is unparalleled. A must see movie for anyone who is a fan of great films.

4.5/5* or 9/10Have you ever wondered how people like Osama Bin Laden or El Chapo come to power, and become gang lords, and then are killed/arrested at a timely convince. Well Sicario has a theory of all things mentioned above, one may say its a conspiracy theory etc but like they say there is no smoke without a fire.But all withstanding, what I saw on screen felt like a true story, and it was thought provoking. Sicario is a dark, and eerie tale about what happens just a couple miles away from the American border in Mexico. Daily many innocents Mexicans die due to the cartel drug war. And Sicario highlights the cruel killings, and how one needs to combat the drug lords. Rarely do you see a film that from the first frame not only does it engage you but it takes you into the nail biting action which is happening on screen.Numerous times I had my heart pounding, and jaw on the ground from action and suspense unfolding on the screen. Simply put Sicario has the best performances, and dialogues I have seen in a film this year. Film of the year? Well its in contention for sure.Story wise the film talks about the escalating drug war the Cartel are engaging in on American soil. After FBI agent Kate Macer invades a house in Arizona and finds about 40 dead bodies which are collateral from the Cartel drug war, she is recruited by the a government agency to take down the real players of the drug war. This agency islead by two men Matt Graver, and Alejandro a columbian man. These two men target Manuel Diaz because he can lead them to the kingpin of the cartel because he is right hand man of the kingpin( Diaz lives in the USA, and fronts as a business man). After arresting Diaz's brother Guillermo on Mexico soil in a operation, he leads them to a tunnel used to transport drugs from Mexico to the US.How this tunnel leads to Manuel, and his boss is what forms the rest of the plot.Acting wise Benicio Del Toro is just mindblowing good, I thought Johnny Depp for Black Mass was the best performance of the year, but Del Toro gives him a good match. A oscar worthy performance for sure. Josh Brolin is superb. And Emily Blunt is fantastic, she shoulders the film at many junctions.Its difficult to find any negatives in Sicario, because even the smallest details have been dealt with beautifully. The films pacing is a bit slow, but the concluding 30-45 are adrenal pumping no stop thrill and action, so that makes up for any pacing issues. Sicario being such a great film has many positives them being the dialouges, espically the ones mouthes by Del Toro,two dialogues in particular where "time to meet god", and "the wolves are taking over, and you wont be able to live with wolves so leave"(in the context of the film, there are mind blowing). Secondly the films acting which i mentioned above. Finally the film is the definition of what a perfect action thriller must be, the film is extremely detailed, its has a dark atmosphere, the way the film highlights the cartel violence, and how the americans have a hand in the drug trade, is also handled perfectly. In short in Sicario content is king, and the script and screenplay are amazing. A special mention for the absolute amazing pre-climax sequence, i got my tickets worth in just those final minutes.Overall over the years Denis Villenue has become one of my favourite directors, and with Sicario he only solidifies his title. The film is a must watch, because if you don't watch it now, you will after seeing its oscar nomination list because its just that good.4.5/5* or 9/10
Sicario might mean Hitman in Mexico. But in my world, Sicario means intense as fucking shit!
Can't wait to watch this again. It hits every right tone throughout, the final scene could have been a cliche bookender but it is not. no spoiler
You'll find very few drug-related movies that are as well-made as this one. No unnecessary over-the-top action, every single scene had a purpose. Absolutely brilliant.

Sicario is directed by Denis Villeneuve who directed Prisoners and Enemy, two movies I absolutely adored. Sicario is a tense and pulsating action crime drama with great performances,gorgeous cinematography and examines how the US government is willing to partner up with a bad guy to take out other supposedly worse enemies. The thing that impressed me most about this movie is its visuals. Every frame looks gorgeous and full credit must go to the masterful Roger Deakins. The opening immediately sets the grim and sombre mood with a thrilling rescue mission(Or so it seems) by the FBI. This is where we are introduced to FBI agent Emily Blunt. After a terrible turn of events she ends up volunteering to be part of an operation to take down a drug lord. Emily Blunt's character acts as a conduit for the audience as she is mostly clueless(Just like we are) about the shady things going around her. Just like Emily Blunt, we the audience get frustrated at points when she is confused about what exactly is happening in the mission. However, you are hooked in till the end because bits and pieces are dropped from time to time to keep you invested in what's going on. All the supporting actors are fantastic as well. My only real issue with Sicario is that there was a side plot which didn't really matter to the overall story and the fact that the middle section of the movie slows down in pace slightly compared to the first and last act. All in All, Sicario is a great crime drama that shows that the war against drugs might indeed be pointless. A-
Benicio Del Toro's swan song...
great movie and interesting story.

This is a noir-crime movie. It is not a thriller but it does have some action. It is a thoughtful movie and so it slows down, at times -- a lot! The main female character is built up as a tough person from the very beginning so it is odd to see her as a total innocent in the second half of the movie This incong ruity mars the entire movie. It's like watching James Bond feel sad and cry because someone was mean to him. It just doesn't fit the character. But it is a revealing look into both sides of the drug-trade -- the cops and the robbers. It isn't the good guys against the bad guys. It's just bad guys against bad guys, except that one side breaks the law to enforce the law and the other side breaks the law just because it can.
